为什么需要这个新版本？

Why Do You Need This New Edition?

 

如果您想知道为什么应该购买这本新版的《电影写作简短指南》，这里有七个很好的理由。

If you’re wondering why you should buy this new edition of The Short Guide to Writing about Film, here are seven good reasons.

 
  1. 关于动画和 3D 技术的新讨论认识到这两种电影方法日益重要——这两种方法都不是新的，但都通过当代技术得到了显着增强——并为在撰写电影时批判性地考虑这些技术提供了指导。
  2. New discussions of animation and 3-D technology recognize the increasing importance of these two approaches to film—neither one new, but both dramatically enhanced by contemporary technologies—and offer guidelines for considering these techniques critically when writing about film.
  3. 用于互联网研究的附加和修订资源强调了在线资源的重要性和实用性，并首次提供可以下载或流式传输剪辑和完整电影的网站。
  4. Additional and revised resources for Internet research emphasize the importance and usefulness of online sources and for the first time offer sites where clips and complete films can be downloaded or streamed.
  5. 对电影叙事、声音和改编的广泛讨论有助于阐明你可以将这三个关键主题作为你对电影的批判性思考的一部分的多种方式。
  6. Expanded discussion of film narrative, sound, and adaptation helps clarify the many ways you might engage these three critical topics as part of your critical thinking about film.
  7. 新的进一步学习推荐书籍部分为您提供了简短、精选的优秀文本列表，供您额外阅读，帮助您扩展电影分析、电影史和电影理论的知识。
  8. A new section of recommended books for further study provides you with a brief, selective list of excellent texts for additional reading to help you expand your knowledge of film analysis, film history, and film theory.
  9. 每章末尾经过修订的练习鼓励您深入理解刚刚阅读的内容，并测试您对每章材料的掌握程度。
  10. Revised exercises at the end of each chapter encourage you to engage with what you have just read and test your mastery of the material in each chapter.
  11. 除了仍然是本书重要组成部分的经典老电影之外，通篇最新电影的更新示例和插图还提供了新鲜和当前的示例。
  12. Updated examples and illustrations of recent films throughout provide fresh and current examples, in addition to the classic older films that remain a key part of this book.
  13. 该版本继续强调无声电影和早期电影，因此，这本书虽然显然不是一部全面的电影史，但却关注了传统上被视为历史主流之外的重要电影和电影制片人。
  14. A continued emphasis on silent films and early cinema is enhanced in this edition so that this book, while clearly not a comprehensive history of film, attends to important films and filmmakers traditionally considered outside the historical mainstream.

前言

Preface

 

这本书展示了——我相信是独一无二的——对电影的思考和写作是如何错综复杂地结合在一起的。同样重要的是，它利用并发展了这样一个事实：学生可以更好地写出他们知道和喜欢的主题，而且当今很少有主题比电影更受普遍喜爱和理解。一方面，《电影写作简短指南》引导学生将观看电影的乐趣和愉悦转化为表达电影想法的满足感。一路上有大量的学生和专业例子，从笔记和初稿到完善的论文和研究项目，展示了对电影的分析如何作为创作过程的一部分变得更加微妙和严谨。与此同时，这本书假设我们能够更好、更愿意地写出我们自信、轻松地参与的主题。对于今天的大多数学生来说，电影就是这个主题，《电影写作简短指南》汲取了对电影的热爱和知识——从学生容易识别的电影到他们可能只读过或听说过的电影——作为一种方式鼓励和发展写作技能。

This book demonstrates—uniquely, I believe—how thinking about and writing about film are intricately bound together. Equally important, it draws on and develops the fact that students write better about a subject they know and like and that few subjects today are enjoyed and understood more universally than the movies. On the one hand, A Short Guide to Writing about Film walks students through the process of converting the fun and pleasure of watching a movie into the satisfaction of articulating ideas about that movie. With numerous student and professional examples along the way, it moves from note taking and first drafts to polished essays and research projects, demonstrating how an analysis of a film becomes more subtle and rigorous as part of a composition process. At the same time, the book assumes that we write better and more willingly about subjects with which we engage confidently and comfortably. For most students today, the movies are that subject, and A Short Guide to Writing about Film draws on that love and knowledge of films—ranging from movies that students easily recognize to ones they may only have read or heard about—as a way of encouraging and developing writing skills.

本书的目的有三个：为电影教师节省时间，因为他们在介绍电影艺术和电影工业的复杂性时很难处理学生的写作问题；通过澄清许多教师错误地认为学生已经知道的要点，减轻学生对写作的焦虑；并在此过程中鼓励两人之间进行更愉快、更清晰的沟通。

The aim of this book is threefold: to save time for instructors of film who, in presenting the complexities of the art and industry of film, are hard put to deal with the writing problems of students; to lessen students’ anxiety about writing, by clarifying points that many instructors mistakenly presume students already know; and, in doing this, to encourage more enjoyable and articulate communication between the two.

第八版的更新和增强

UPDATES AND ENHANCEMENTS FOR THE EIGHTH EDITION

 

我认为，本书新版的挑战在于，修改和补充不能使本书变得过于繁琐。为了使本书保持最新和新鲜，第八版有七个重要修订：

The challenge of a new edition of this book is that changes and additions must not, I believe, make the book become too cumbersome. In order to keep this book up-to-date and fresh, this eighth edition features seven prominent revisions:

  • 关于动画和 3D 技术的新讨论。毫无疑问，过去十年来电影院中最明显的变化之一是动画电影以及最近的 3D 技术的出现和重要性的不断增长。虽然完全公正地评价这两种做法的影响超出了本书的范围，但当前版本增加了对这两种做法的讨论，并提供了在撰写有关它们时如何批判性考虑这两种做法的指南。
  • New discussions of animation and 3-D technology. There’s no doubt that one of the more visible shifts in the cinema during the last ten years has been the growing presence and importance of animated films and, more recently, 3-D technology. While it’s beyond the scope of this book to do complete justice to the impact of these two practices, the current edition has added discussions of both, featuring guidelines for how to critically consider both when writing about them.
  • 用于互联网研究的附加和修订资源。对于电影作家来说，互联网不断发展成为阅读、观看和研究的重要资源。因此，这些不断变化和扩展的资源需要不断更新，本版编辑并添加了学生可以找到优秀电影期刊、研究链接的网站，并且在本书中首次添加了可以查找剪辑和完整电影的网站。下载或流式传输。
  • Additional and revised resources for Internet research. For the writer about film, the Internet has continued to grow as an important resource for reading, viewing, and research. Accordingly, these changing and expanding resources require continual updating, and this edition has edited and added to those sites where students can find good film journals, research links, and, for the first time in this book, sites where clips and complete films can be downloaded or streamed.
  • 扩大了对电影叙事、声音和改编的讨论。学生和评论家认为，对电影叙事、声音和改编的必要浓缩讨论是三个领域，这些领域可以从一些额外的讨论中受益。不用说，这些新增加的内容并没有提供对这三个过程的复杂性的完整和详尽的说明，但我相信，微调已经使学生可以更清楚地了解他们可以参与批判性思考的许多方式。电影。
  • Expanded discussion of film narrative, sound, and adaptation. The necessarily condensed discussions of film narrative, sound, and adaptation are three areas that students and reviewers suggested would benefit from some additional discussion. These new additions do not, needless to say, provide full and exhaustive accounts of the complexities of these three processes, but the fine-tuning has, I believe, made clearer the many ways a student might engage them as part of their critical thinking about film.
  • 新的推荐书籍部分供进一步学习。由于本指南旨在向学生介绍电影学习，并在理想情况下激励他们继续发展这种兴趣，因此该书现在包含了“进一步阅读”的列表。这个简短的精选列表包含了扩展电影分析、电影史和电影理论讨论的优秀文本。
  • A new section of recommended books for further study. Because this guide aims to both introduce students to film study and, ideally, motive them to continue to develop that interest, the book now includes a list of “further readings.” This short, selective list includes excellent texts that expand the discussion of film analysis, film history, and film theory.
  • 每章末尾为学生修订练习。无论是否经常使用，每章末尾的简短练习仍然受到学生和教师的欢迎，当前版本对其中的许多练习进行了修改，以保持新鲜和有效。
  • Revised exercises for students at the end of each chapter. Whether they are regularly used or not, the short exercises at the end of each chapter remain popular with students and instructors, and the current edition has revised many of these to keep them fresh and effective.
  • 更新了最近电影的示例和插图。本书每个新版本的一个关键调整是将最近的电影融入到讨论和插图中。虽然我坚持认为，展示老电影或外国电影作为激发学生对他们可能不（但应该！）知道的电影的好奇心和兴趣的一种方式至关重要，但提供学生熟悉的近期当代电影的例子也至关重要。理想情况下，这种做法将使学生更多地参与中心点的讨论，从而提高写作质量。
  • Updated examples and illustrations of recent films. A key adjustments in every new edition of this book has been integrating recent films into the discussions and illustrations. While I would insist that it’s crucial to present older films or foreign films as a way of piquing students’ curiosity and interest in films they may not (but should!) know, it is also paramount to provide examples of recent contemporary movies familiar to students. Ideally, this practice will engage students more in the discussion of central points and thus lead to better writing.
  • 无声电影和早期电影。新版指南继续关注传统上被视为历史主流之外的重要电影和电影制片人。这里特别注重扩大无声电影和早期电影的覆盖范围。虽然这本书显然不是一部全面的电影史，但它确实旨在提醒学生有大量的材料、人物和主题可供用来撰写优秀的电影论文。
  • Silent films and early cinema. This new version of the guide continues to attend to important films and filmmakers traditionally considered outside the historical mainstream. Here there has been particular attention to expanding the coverage of silent films and early cinema. While this book is clearly not a comprehensive history of film, it does aim to remind students of the vast array of materials, people, and topics available for writing good essays about film.

对本书的需求

THE NEED FOR THIS BOOK

 

我们这些教电影的人很少有时间讨论关于电影的写作。我们大多数人都忙于展示电影和有关这些电影的各种书籍，而我们通常被迫做出的假设是，学生知道如何将他们所看到和想到的内容转化为可理解的书面形式。尽管这种假设可能很常见且可以原谅，但今天它比以往任何时候都更不可靠。教师们必须越来越多地困惑和哀叹那些热情的学生，他们似乎知道很多，对电影有很多话要说，但写出的论文却令人困惑和令人失望。

Those of us who teach film rarely have time to discuss writing about film. Most of us are busy presenting films and various books about those films, and the usual presumption we are forced to make is that students know how to put what they see and think into a comprehensible written form. As common and forgivable as that presumption may be, it is less reliable today than ever before. Instructors must increasingly puzzle over and bemoan those enthusiastic students who seem to know so much and are brimming with things to say about the movies but who write confused and disappointing papers.

避免这个问题的一种方法是依靠简短答案的考试。然而，尽管这种方法非常有用和必要，特别是在电影史的大型讲座课程中，但它回避了评论文章的一些有益要求，这些要求对学生的思维质量产生了真正的影响。一篇论文迫使学生使用特殊技能：产生并集中原创想法；组织、维持和支持这些想法，直到它们得到充分发展；通过修改用于描述感知的语言来微调感知；使用正确的语法和句法作为令人信服的论证的一部分；并通过明智的研究利用他人的意见。

One way to avoid this problem is to rely on examinations that elicit short answers. Yet as useful and as necessary as this method is, especially in large lecture courses on film history, it sidesteps several beneficial demands of the critical essay, demands that make real differences in the quality of a student’s thinking. An essay forces a student to use special skills: to generate and focus original ideas; to organize, sustain, and support those ideas until they are fully developed; to fine-tune perceptions by revising the language used to describe them; to employ proper grammar and syntax as part of the convincing presentation of an argument; and to make use of the opinions of others through intelligent research.

简而言之，写关于电影的文章是回应电影的最复杂的方式之一。我认为，为了激发学生思维的广度、原创性和严谨性，教师需要指导学生完成论文形式的机制。本书希望通过提炼专门适用于电影批评的写作课程来填补写作手册和电影研究教科书之间的空白。

Writing essays about films is, in short, one of the most sophisticated ways to respond to them. To elicit scope, originality, and rigor in a student’s thinking, an instructor, I believe, needs to guide that student through the mechanics of the essay form. Filling the gap between writing handbooks and film-studies textbooks by distilling writing lessons as they apply specifically to film criticism, this book hopes to be that guide.

尽管重点是大多数电影课程中的分析性写作，但这本书可以以多种方式使用，与各种其他教科书一起使用，并且可供任何认为撰写有关电影的内容是学习电影一部分的教授使用。这是一本简洁而灵活的书，可以作为补充或中心教材适用于各种写作课程或电影课程。在所有情况下，其目标都是促进关于电影的良好思考和良好写作。

Although the emphasis is on the analytical writing done in most film courses, the book can be used in many ways, with a variety of other textbooks, and by any professor who believes that writing about film is part of learning about film. This is a concise and flexible book that can be adapted to a wide variety of writing courses or film courses as a supplemental or central text. In all cases, its goal is to promote good thinking and good writing about film.

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

 

在本书的第一阶段，Marcia Stubbs 和 Sylvan Barnet 在阅读手稿和敦促修改方面始终提供帮助和要求。

During the first stages of this book, Marcia Stubbs and Sylvan Barnet were consistently helpful and demanding in reading the manuscript and urging changes.

从那时起，我感谢各个版本的许多审稿人，包括太平洋大学的 Jeffrey Barlow；奥斯汀·布里格斯，汉密尔顿学院；吉姆·柯林斯，圣母大学；大卫·库克，埃默里大学；丹尼斯·K·卡明斯，佛罗里达大学；蒂莫西·里昂斯，爱默生学院；Jill R. Deans，堪萨斯州立大学；帕梅拉·德默里 (Pamela Demery)，加州大学戴维斯分校；辛迪·亨德肖特，阿肯色州立大学；理查德·麦吉，阿肯色州立大学；托比·米勒，纽约大学；贝蒂·乔·彼得斯，莫尔黑德州立大学；克莱·雷诺兹，德克萨斯大学达拉斯分校；黛博拉·罗杰斯，缅因大学；詹姆斯·施沃赫，西北大学；查克·瓦瑟伯格，西北大学；芭芭拉·韦茨，佛罗里达国际大学；埃米特·温恩，奥本大学；汤姆·扎尼罗 (Tom Zaniello)，北肯塔基大学；Gus Amaya，佛罗里达国际大学；贝蒂·贝塔奇，科林学院；惠勒·温斯顿·迪克森，内布拉斯加大学林肯分校；Tammy Kinsey，托莱多大学；Alexis Krasilovsky，加州州立大学北岭分校；凯利·马歇尔，德克萨斯基督教大学；约翰·麦高恩-哈特曼，新奥尔良大学；和梅萨社区学院的雪莱罗德里戈。此外，林恩·特里布尔（Lyn Tribble）和杰里米·巴特勒（Jeremy Butler）的建议和忠告在考虑互联网研究方面也是不可或缺的。

Since then, I am grateful to the many reviewers of the various editions, including Jeffrey Barlow, Pacific University; Austin Briggs, Hamilton College; Jim Collins, University of Notre Dame; David Cook, Emory University; Denise K. Cummings, University of Florida; Timothy Lyons, Emerson College; Jill R. Deans, Kansas State University; Pamela Demery, University of California, Davis; Cyndy Hendershot, Arkansas State University; Richard McGhee, Arkansas State University; Toby Miller, New York University; Betty Jo Peters, Morehead State University; Clay Reynolds, The University of Texas at Dallas; Deborah Rogers, University of Maine; James Schwoch, Northwestern University; Chuck Wasserburg, Northwestern University; Barbara Weitz, Florida International University; Emmett Winn, Auburn University; Tom Zaniello, Northern Kentucky University; Gus Amaya, Florida International University; Betty Bettacchi, Collin College; Wheeler Winston Dixon, University Nebraska, Lincoln; Tammy Kinsey, University of Toledo; Alexis Krasilovsky, California State University, Northridge; Kelli Marshall, Texas Christian University; John McGowan-Hartmann, University of New Orleans; and Shelley Rodrigo, Mesa Community College. 对于第八版，以下审阅者的评论提供了很大的帮助：Kimberly Nichele Brown，德克萨斯 A&M 大学；凯尔·爱德华兹，奥克兰大学；辛西娅·里夫·汉考克，北卡罗来纳大学夏洛特分校；迈克尔·鲁宾诺夫，亚利桑那州立大学；洛林·K·斯托克，休斯顿大学；和布拉德·斯特里克兰，盖恩斯维尔州立学院。

蒂莫西·科里根

TIMOTHY CORRIGAN

电影写作简短指南

A Short Guide to Writing about Film

1

写关于电影的文章

1

WRITING ABOUT THE MOVIES

 

为什么要写电影？

WHY WRITE ABOUT THE MOVIES?

 

法国作家克里斯蒂安·梅茨（Christian Metz）在几年前评论自己的电影经历时，描述了当今电影学生仍然面临的挑战：我们都了解电影，但我们如何解释它们？

Commenting some years ago on his experience at the movies, the French writer Christian Metz described a challenge that still faces the student of movies today: We all understand the movies, but how do we explain them?

作为衡量这种共识的标准，请注意电影在多大程度上成为我们通常认为理所当然的文化生活的一部分。我们都珍视并认同某些电影——因为它们的欢笑、刺激或令人难以忘怀的恐怖画面——而电影和它们的明星经常成为我们日常生活和谈话的一部分。2010 年上映的《社交网络》戏剧化地讲述了互联网革命的分水岭，特别是讲述了 Facebook 创始人马克·扎克伯格的故事。2009 年，奥斯卡金像奖得主《拆弹部队》让美国了解了正在进行的伊拉克战争的恐怖、痛苦和混乱，而同年，《阿凡达》则通过 3D 技术让美国了解了外星战争。彻底改变我们观看电影的方式。2008年，《黑暗骑士》创下了首映日票房纪录，票房收入为6640万美元，部分原因是扮演小丑的演员希斯·莱杰的悲剧性死亡，并广为人知。1997 年，《星球大战》以一个有争议的军事项目命名；1991 年，《肯尼迪总统》再次提出了有关约翰·F·肯尼迪总统被刺杀的悬而未决的问题，这些问题在电影上映前后的几个月内出现在电视和报纸上。从某种意义上说，埃尔文·潘诺夫斯基 (Erwin Panofsky) 1934 年的话在今天可能比以往任何时候都更真实：

As a measure of that common understanding, notice the extent to which movies are a part of a cultural life that we generally take for granted. We all treasure and identify with certain movies—for their laughs, their thrills, or their haunting images of terror—and movies and their stars regularly become part of our daily lives and conversations. The 2010 release The Social Network dramatized a watershed moment in the Internet revolution, specifically as a tale about Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook. In 2009, Academy Award winner The Hurt Locker brought home to the United States the horror, pain, and confusion of the ongoing war in Iraq, while that same year Avatar brought home a war on alien planet with a 3-D technology that purportedly would revolutionize how we watch movies. In 2008, The Dark Knight set a record for an opening day with a $66.4 million gross, partly as a result of the tragic and much-publicized death of Heath Ledger, the actor who plays the Joker. In 1997, Star Wars lent its name to a controversial military project, and in 1991, JFK raised again unsettled questions about President John F. Kennedy’s assassination that appeared on television and in newspapers for months before and after the movie’s release. In a sense, Erwin Panofsky’s 1934 words are probably truer today than ever before:

如果所有严肃的抒情诗人、作曲家、画家和雕塑家都被法律强制停止他们的活动，那么一小部分公众会意识到这一事实，更一小部分人会对此感到严重遗憾。如果同样的事情发生在电影上，社会后果将是灾难性的。(234)

If all the serious lyrical poets, composers, painters and sculptors were forced by law to stop their activities, a rather small fraction of the general public would become aware of the fact and a still smaller fraction would seriously regret it. If the same thing were to happen with the movies, the social consequences would be catastrophic. (234)

 

无论是在公共场合还是私下里，我们的生活已经被电影渗透得如此之深，以至于我们很少费心去仔细思考它们——而且我们也很少想到写下它们。

Publicly and privately, our lives have become so permeated by the movies that we rarely bother to think carefully about them—and less often, if at all, do we think of writing about them.

通常情况下，我们可能会争辩说，没有什么理由费力地解释（当然不是书面形式）我们主要理解为娱乐的东西。无论是在电影院还是在深夜电视上，我们通常看电影，因为我们期待那种很少会拿起纸笔的乐趣。看完《阿凡达》（2009）后，我们可能会简短地谈论我们特别喜欢或不喜欢的某些角色或场景，但我们很少想对布景、故事结构和角色如何协同工作进行冗长的分析。人们常常有一个不言而喻的假设，即任何类型的分析都可能会干扰我们对电影的欣赏。

Normally, we might argue that there is little reason to struggle to explain—and certainly not in writing—what we understand primarily as entertainment. Whether in a movie theater or on late-night television, we usually watch films because we expect the kind of pleasure seldom associated with an inclination to pick up pen and paper. After seeing Avatar (2009), we might chat briefly about certain characters or scenes we particularly enjoyed or disliked, but we rarely want to offer a lengthy analysis of how the sets, the construction of the story, and the characters worked together. There is often an unspoken assumption that any kind of analysis might interfere with our enjoyment of the movies.

我们不太愿意分析性地思考其他形式的娱乐。例如，如果我们观看舞蹈表演或篮球比赛，我们可能会轻松愉快地讨论其中的一些复杂性，并意识到我们的评论会增加而不是减少我们对它们的享受。在这些时候，我们对事件的理解和体验的乐趣是我们的讨论提炼和阐述的批判意识的产物。没有倾向或能力反思或分析篮球或舞蹈的人可能会在某种程度上得到娱乐，但能够激活有关规则和可能性的批判性智力的人会体验到更丰富的乐趣。

We are less reluctant to think analytically about other forms of entertainment. If, for instance, we watch a dance performance or a basketball game, we may easily and happily discuss some of their intricacies and complexities, realizing that our commentary adds to rather than subtracts from our enjoyment of them. At these times, our understanding of and pleasure in experiencing the event are products of the critical awareness that our discussion refines and elaborates on. The person who has no inclination or ability to reflect on or analyze basketball or dance may be entertained on some level, but the person who is able to activate a critical intelligence about the rules and possibilities involved experiences a richer kind of pleasure.

事实上，在这些情况下，我们以分析意识做出反应的能力会增加我们的乐趣。毫不奇怪，我们欣赏电影也是如此。消息灵通的观众经常会转而阅读他们前一天晚上看过的节目的评论；我们中的许多人喜欢阅读我们从未看过的电影。关于“娱乐”的分析性思考和阅读可以激发和丰富它，而关于电影的分析性写作也提供了同样的承诺和回报。例如，当一名学生被迫仔细解释为什么喜欢《阿凡达》时，她发现她对这部电影的理解和欣赏比她最初意识到的更加复杂和微妙（图1.01）。她承认这部电影的壮观特效不容错过，她开始更多地思考不仅是什么让这部电影如此令人愉快，而且还思考它如何传达有关人性的重要思想。她开始了她的扩展回应：

In fact, in these cases our ability to respond with some analytical awareness adds to our enjoyment. And not surprisingly, the same is true of our enjoyment of the movies. Informed audiences often turn to read a review of a show they have seen the night before; many of us enjoy reading about movies we have not even seen. Analytical thinking and reading about an “entertainment” invigorate and enrich it, and analytical writing about film offers the same promises and rewards. For example, when pressured to explain carefully why she liked Avatar, one student discovered that her understanding of and appreciation for the film were more complex and subtle than she had initially realized (Figure 1.01). Acknowledging that there was no missing the spectacular special effects of the film, she began to think more about not only what makes the film so enjoyable, but about how it communicates important ideas about humanity. She began her expanded response:

虽然大多数关于 2009 年《阿凡达》的讨论无疑会集中在其革命性的 3D 技术上，但我们不应忽视这部电影巧妙地讲述人类联系和诚信的辛酸感人故事的能力。随着杰克（萨姆·沃辛顿饰）逐渐当他意识到他的企业和政治上级的帝国主义野心和残酷目标时，他经历了一段个人发现之旅，最终决定站在地球上的原住民纳美人一边。这段旅程发生在郁郁葱葱的外星领域和潘多拉星球的外星居民中间，观众几乎被传送到了另一个世界，这个世界的生存和繁荣是由于同情与合作而不是贪婪和暴力。人类吞并潘多拉的冰冷金属本质可以从他们的矿场、枪支和炸弹中看出，而纳美人则依赖自然世界，生活在树上并与其他土著物种进行物理联系。简而言之，制作这部电影的高调技术的核心是关于一种既是人性又是超越人性的生活方式的重要信息。

While most discussions of the 2009 Avatar will undoubtedly focus on its revolutionary 3-D technology, we should not overlook the film’s ability to skillfully tell a poignant, touching tale of human connection and integrity. As Jake (Sam Worthington) gradually becomes aware of the imperialist aspirations and brutal goals of his corporate and political superiors, he undergoes a journey of personal discovery that leads to his eventual decision to side with the natives of the planet, the Na’vi. This journey takes place in lush extra-terrestrial fields and amidst the alien inhabitants of the planet Pandora, and audiences are transported–almost physically—to another world, one that has survived and flourished as a result of compassion and cooperation rather than greed and violence. The cold metallic nature of humanity’s annexation of Pandora can be seen in their mining fields, guns, and bombs, while the Na’vi rely on the natural world, living in the trees and physically connecting with other indigenous species. At the center of the high-profile technology that made the film is, in short, an important message about a way of living that is both human and more than human.

 

图 1.01 关于《阿凡达》（2009）的写作可以成为澄清初步印象并将其发展为关于该电影的更成熟的想法和想法的机会。

Figure 1.01 Writing about Avatar (2009) can become an opportunity to clarify and develop initial impressions into more developed ideas and thoughts about that film.

 

如果电影告诉我们生活的许多部分，我们应该能够以多种方式享受它们，包括尝试思考、解释和写下我们观看电影的经历的挑战性乐趣。我们去看电影有很多原因：思考或不思考、凝视电影或写下电影。我们可能会去看电影，像吃棉花糖一样吃它；我们可能会去看一部电影，其中糖果成为精神食粮。正如《阿凡达》的粉丝所发现的那样，分析我们对电影的反应并不会破坏我们对电影的享受。写一部电影可以让我们以以前无法做到的方式欣赏它（以及其他电影）。如果观看和理解是电影的乐趣之一，那么写作和解释则是另一种令人兴奋的乐趣。

If the movies inform many parts of our lives, we should be able to enjoy them in many ways, including the challenging pleasure of trying to think about, explain, and write about our experience watching them. We go to the movies for many reasons: to think or not to think, to stare at them, or to write about them. We may go to a movie to consume it like cotton candy; we may go to a film where that candy becomes food for the mind. As the fan of Avatar found out, analyzing our response to a movie does not ruin our enjoyment of it. Writing about a film can allow us to enjoy it (and other films) in ways we were incapable of before. If watching and understanding is one of the pleasures of the movies, writing and explaining can be another exciting pleasure.

让我们记住，撰写关于电影的文章与我们大多数人已经做的事情相差不远：当我们在两个小时的强制沉默后离开电影院时，我们大多数人都会讨论或争论这部电影。尽管谈论和写作一个主题之间的区别是至关重要的，但从某种意义上说，写一部电影只是一种更加精致和有节制的交流，这次是与读者的交流。我们的评论可以是关于演员的表演、特定场景引发的兴奋，或者只是关于发生了什么、为什么会发生或者为什么电影对这些问题的答案不清楚的常见问题。

Let us keep in mind that writing about the movies is not so far from what most of us do already: When we leave a movie theater after two hours of enforced silence, most of us discuss or argue about the film. Although the difference between talking and writing about a subject is a crucial one, writing about a film is, in one sense, simply a more refined and measured kind of communication, this time with a reader. Our comments can be about the performance of an actor, the excitement elicited by specific scenes, or just common questions about what happened, why it happened, or why the film made the answers to these questions unclear.

通常，这些对话是从寻找正确的词或找到对序列如何发展的令人满意的描述而演变而来的：“我更喜欢基顿而不是卓别林，因为基顿更有趣。嗯，我的意思是，他讲的故事更有趣、更复杂”；“我讨厌——不，我发现《盗梦空间》（2010）的结局太可预测了。” 在谈论电影时，即使是非常随意的，我们也会寻找与我们所看到的内容以及我们对电影的反应相匹配的词语。写关于电影的文章是一个比讨论我们所看到的第一冲动更谨慎、更经过深思熟虑的一步。有了这种正常的冲动，我们甚至可以享受谈论和写一部我们不喜欢的电影。这位作家的一位朋友称赞《阿凡达》，因此他的文章开头比之前引用的学生更加消极：

Frequently, these conversations evolve from searching for the right word or finding a satisfactory description of how a sequence develops: “I prefer Keaton to Chaplin because Keaton’s funnier. Well, I mean, he tells funnier, more complicated stories”; “I hated—no, I found much too predictable—the ending of Inception (2010).” While talking about movies, even very casually, we search for words to match what we saw and how we reacted to it. Writing about film is a careful and more calculated step beyond this first impulse to discuss what we have seen. Given this normal impulse, we can even enjoy talking and writing about a movie that we didn’t like. A friend of the writer who praised Avatar thus begins his essay more negatively than the student quoted previously:

虽然《阿凡达》 （2009）的 3D 技术将当前电影的界限推向了新的水平，但所有浮华和闪亮的外星人只不过是重复了之前已经讲述过数百次的情节。这个故事——一名入侵的士兵重生并被那些曾经是他的敌人的人所接受——引人入胜，但《阿凡达》所传达的严厉的道德正直信息和人类理解的力量远远达不到其史诗般的抱负。影片的技术并没有与故事相辅相成，而是成为整部电影的焦点，几乎没有给剧情发展留下足够的空间。潘多拉星球及其众多自然奇观的长镜头变得比故事本身更有趣，让我们等待下一个 3D 物体突然出现，让观众惊叹不已，从而产生一部只不过是视觉效果的电影刺激。《阿凡达》似乎坚信，其对 3D 技术的惊人运用会让观众着迷，以至于没有人会注意到笨拙的表演和缺乏微妙的叙事。由企业利益资助的美国入侵的刻板故事在当代电影中司空见惯，而在《阿凡达》中，经典邪恶海军陆战队军官等老套角色的出现让这一故事变得更加乏味。和一个没有骨气的企业代表。不幸的是， 《阿凡达》对一个简单而真诚的概念进行了笨拙和笨拙的尝试，充其量只是一部普通的、过得去的电影，穿着闪亮的新衣服，但不太合身。

While the 3-D technology of Avatar (2009) has pushed the current bounds of cinema to new levels, all the glitz and shiny aliens do nothing but rehash a plot already told hundreds of times before. The story—an invading soldier is reborn and accepted by those who were once his enemy—is engaging, but Avatar’s heavy-handed messages of moral rectitude and the power of human understanding fall well short of its epic aspirations. The film’s technology, rather than complementing the story, becomes the focal point of the entire movie and leaves little room for sufficient plot development. The long, yawning shots of the planet Pandora and its many natural wonders become more interesting than the story itself, leaving us waiting for the next 3-D object to pop out and wow the audience and resulting in a film that is little more than visual stimulation. Avatar seems convinced that its stunning use of 3-D technology would enamor viewers to the extent that no one would notice the clunky acting and lack of narrative subtlety. The stereotypical story of American invasion funded by corporate interests is a dull commonplace in contemporary movies, made even duller in Avatar by stock characters like a classically evil marine officer and a spineless corporate representative. An unfortunately clumsy and unwieldy attempt at a simple, heartfelt concept, Avatar is, at best, an average, passable movie dressed up in shiny new clothes that never quite fit.

 

正如这两位朋友发现的那样，当我们对同一部电影的理解截然不同时，试图解释理解可以充满良好对话的全部能量。

As these two friends discovered, when we understand the same movie very differently, trying to explain that understanding can be charged with all the energy of a good conversation.

也许与大多数其他艺术和娱乐相比，电影经常引发强烈的情感或智力反应。然而，通常情况下，我们对一部电影产生特殊反应的原因仍然不清楚，直到我们有机会仔细思考并阐明是什么刺激了它。《拜见约翰·多伊》（1941）可能会引发一种令人眼花缭乱的怀旧之情，这与当今复杂的政治环境格格不入。《我爱你菲利普·莫里斯》（I Love You Phillip Morris ，2009）的一些观众可能会发现自己被对同性恋关系的深度和激情的诚实描述所吸引，但对金·凯瑞典型的夸张滑稽动作却感到厌烦；费里尼的《8 1/2》（1963）的大多数观众可能会认识到开场镜头的重要性，其中一个男人从车里漂浮在交通堵塞的上方，但他们可能很难快速解释这意味着什么接下来的故事。分析我们对主题、人物或图像的反应不仅可以更好地理解电影，而且可以更好地理解我们如何看待世界和我们所生活的文化。在下面的三段中，我们可以看到杰弗里·诺威尔-史密斯如何将他最初对安东尼奥尼电影中的一个场景的兴奋转变为对该特定场景的探索，并含蓄地讨论他对安东尼奥尼电影中人类复杂性的钦佩：

Perhaps more than most other arts and entertainments, the movies frequently elicit a strong emotional or intellectual reaction. Often, however, the reason for our particular reaction to a movie remains unclear until we have had the opportunity to think carefully about and articulate what stimulated it. Meet John Doe (1941) might elicit a giddy nostalgia ridiculously out of step with today’s political complexities; some viewers of I Love You Phillip Morris (2009) may find themselves attracted by the honest depiction of a gay relationship with depth and passion but be put off by Jim Carrey’s typically exaggerated antics; most audiences of Fellini’s 8 1/2 (1963) will probably recognize the importance of the opening sequence, in which a man floats from his car above a traffic jam, but they may be hard-pressed to explain quickly what it means in terms of the story that follows. Analyzing our reactions to themes, characters, or images like these can be a way not only of understanding a movie better, but also of understanding better how we view the world and the cultures we live in. In the following three paragraphs, we can see how Geoffrey Nowell-Smith turned his initial excitement about a scene in an Antonioni film into an exploration of that particular scene and, implicitly, into a discussion of his admiration of the human complexity in Antonioni’s films:

《奇遇》中有一个简短的场景，表面上看并不是一个非常重要的场景，但在我看来，它完美地概括了安东尼奥尼电影形式中最有效和最原创的一切。这是桑德罗和克劳迪娅偶然到达西西里岛内陆某个小村庄的场景。村子里出奇的安静。他们走了一会儿，大声喊叫。没有回复，什么也没有。渐渐地，他们意识到这个村庄完全荒芜，无人居住，甚至可能从未有人居住过。整个村子里除了他们自己，没有一个人，在一起，又孤独。他们感到不安，开始离开。影片悬停了片刻：可以说，世界暂停了两秒，也许更久。然后影片突然陷入困境，我们切换到桑德罗和克劳迪娅在田野里做爱的特写镜头——这是电影史上最令人欣喜若狂的时刻之一，而且显然没有任何正式的准备。究竟发生了什么？

There is one brief scene in L’Avventura, not on the face of it a very important one, which seems to me to epitomize perfectly everything that is most valid and original about Antonioni’s form of cinema. It is the scene where Sandro and Claudia arrive by chance at a small village somewhere in the interior of Sicily. The village is strangely quiet. They walk around for a bit, call out. No reply, nothing. Gradually it dawns on them that the village is utterly deserted, uninhabited, perhaps never was inhabited. There is no one in the whole village but themselves, together and alone. Disturbed, they start to move away. For a moment the film hovers: the world is, so to speak, suspended for two seconds, perhaps more. Then suddenly the film plunges, and we cut to a close-up of Sandro and Claudia making love in a field—one of the most ecstatic moments in the history of the cinema, and one for which there has been apparently no formal preparation whatever. What exactly has happened?

 

桑德罗和克劳迪娅并不是突然坠入爱河，或者在那一刻突然发现他们一直相爱。在另一个极端，他们的恐慌反应也不是突然害怕荒凉和孤独。这也不再是男人利用女人一时的无助来勾引她的问题。这些解释中的每一个都包含真相的一个方面，但整个真相更加复杂，最终无法分析。那一刻到底发生了什么，观众永远不会知道，而角色们是否真的知道自己也值得怀疑。克劳迪娅知道桑德罗对她感兴趣。和他一起来到村庄，她或多或少已经做出了自己的承诺，但真正致命的决定既不是她的，也不是他的。它来了，当它来的时候，是冲动的：而它的直接原因，引起反应的刺激，是看到废弃村庄所产生的空虚感和需要感。正如她的感情（以及他的感情）既不是纯粹的浪漫，也不是纯粹的身体，安东尼奥尼说，她的选择既不是纯粹决定的，也不是纯粹自由的。当然，她选择了，但她没有意识到她选择的意义，从某种意义上说，她也几乎不可能采取其他行动……

It is not the case that Sandro and Claudia have suddenly fallen in love, or suddenly discovered at that moment that they have been in love all along. Nor, at the other extreme, is theirs a panic reaction to a sudden fear of desolation and loneliness. Nor again is it a question of the man profiting from a moment of helplessness on the part of the woman in order to seduce her. Each of these explanations contains an aspect of the truth, but the whole truth is more complicated and ultimately escapes analysis. What precisely happened in that moment the spectator will never know, and it is doubtful if the characters really know for themselves. Claudia knows that Sandro is interested in her. By coming with him to the village she has already more or less committed herself, but the actual fatal decision is neither hers nor his. It comes, when it comes, impulsively: and its immediate cause, the stimulus which provokes the response, is the feeling of emptiness and need created by the sight of the deserted village. Just as her feelings (and his too for that matter) are neither purely romantic nor purely physical, so her choice, Antonioni is saying, is neither purely determined nor purely free. She chooses, certainly, but the significance of her choice escapes her, and in a sense also she could hardly have acted otherwise....

 

在这种压抑的物质和社会环境中，人物们在哪里可以找到逃避的地方？他们怎样才能摆脱自然、其他人和他们自己的情感在他们周围建立的迷宫呢？严格来说，没有办法逃脱，也不应该有。人注定要生活在这个世界上——这就是说，他注定要存在。但情况并非毫无希望。电影里有一些幸福的时刻，当它们出现时，它们来自于与物质环境或他人的和平相处，而不是从他们中退出。《奇遇》中的克劳迪娅，在游艇上，然后在岛上，在精神上与那里的其他人隔绝，并让自己完全享受周围的物质环境，直到安娜的消失，甚至这些环境似乎也变得相反并加剧而不是减轻她的痛苦。在《日食》中，维多利亚最幸福的时刻是在维罗纳的那一幕神奇的场景中，她突然的满足感似乎是从机场简单的景象和声音中提炼出来的：阳光​​、草地上的风、飞机的嗡嗡声、自动点唱机。在这种时刻，其他人只是拖累——但对他们的需求却存在。摆脱自我、远离他人的愿望以及由此带来的满足感，只能源于大部分时间意识到自己以及与他人建立随意或持久关系的实际需要。人际关系也可以成为满足感的源泉。没有任何一种陈词滥调或抽象的表述能够抓住安东尼奥尼版本的人类喜剧的鲜活本质。(355, 363)

Where in this oppressive physical and social environment do the characters find any escape? How can they break out of the labyrinth which nature and other men and their own sensibilities have built up around them? Properly speaking there is no escape, nor should there be. Man is doomed to living in the world—this is to say no more than that he is doomed to exist. But the situation is not hopeless. There are moments of happiness in the films, which come, when they come, from being at peace with the physical environment, or with others, not in withdrawing from them. Claudia in L’Avventura, on the yacht and then on the island, is cut off, mentally, from the other people there, and gives herself over to undiluted enjoyment of her physical surroundings, until with Anna’s disappearance even these surroundings seem to turn against her and aggravate rather than alleviate her pain. In The Eclipse Vittoria’s happiest moment is during that miraculous scene at Verona when her sudden contentment seems to be distilled out of the simple sights and sounds of the airport: sun, the wind in the grass, the drone of an aeroplane, a jukebox. At such moments other people are only a drag—and yet the need for them exists. The desire to get away from oneself, away from other people, and the satisfaction this gives, arise only from the practical necessity for most of the time of being aware of oneself and of forming casual or durable relationships with other people. And the relationships too can be a source of fulfillment. No single trite or abstract formulation can catch the living essence of Antonioni’s version of the human comedy. (355, 363)

 

在这个例子中，一个场景成为这篇文章的刺激因素。作者对这一场景进行了探究和质疑：到底发生了什么，这意味着什么？作为一名作家，他明显的满足感来自于分析这一场景，就好像这是一个有待解决的谜团一样。在他的分析过程中，他最初的好奇心导致他对其他安东尼奥尼电影进行了更广泛的阅读，并最终在最初引起他注意的令人不安的困境中发现了安慰。对于这位作家来说，追随好奇心的乐趣带来了更多地了解现代生活和幸福的更大乐趣。

In this example, a single scene becomes the stimulus for the essay. The author probes and questions this scene: What exactly has happened, and what does it mean? His obvious satisfaction as a writer comes from analyzing this scene as if it were a mystery to be solved. In the process of his analysis, his original curiosity leads to broader readings of other Antonioni movies and, finally, to his discovery of a consolation in the disturbing predicament that first caught his eye. For this writer, the pleasure of following his curiosity leads to the larger pleasure of understanding more about life and happiness in modern times.

你的观众和影评的目的

YOUR AUDIENCE AND THE AIMS OF FILM CRITICISM

 

撰写有关电影的文章可以起到多种作用之一。它可以帮助您执行以下操作：

Writing about film can serve one of several functions. It can help you do the following:

  • 更好地了解自己对电影的反应
  • Understand your own response to a movie better
  • 说服别人为什么你喜欢或不喜欢一部电影
  • Convince others why you like or dislike a film
  • 解释或介绍读者可能不知道的有关电影、电影制片人或一组电影的内容
  • Explain or introduce something about a movie, a filmmaker, or a group of movies that your readers may not know
  • 对一部电影和其他电影进行比较和对比，以更好地理解它们
  • Make comparisons and contrasts between one movie and others as a way of understanding them better
  • 在电影和其他文化领域之间建立联系，以阐明文化及其制作的电影
  • Make connections between a movie and other areas of culture to illuminate both the culture and the movies it produces

成为你写作的一部分或核心的目的有时完全取决于你的观众：例如，一篇介绍新电影的文章通常是为没有看过这部电影的观众写的。然而，即使这个目的是独立决定的——也许是出于对西班牙电影和西班牙文化之间关系的个人兴趣——你所说的也总是会受到你对观众的看法的影响，尤其是你认为这些读者知道或了解的内容。想知道。

The purposes that become part of or central to your writing will sometimes depend entirely on your audience: An essay introducing a new movie, for example, is usually written for an audience that has not seen the film. However, even when that purpose is decided on independently—perhaps out of a personal interest in the relation between Spanish films and Spanish culture—what you say will always be shaped by your notion of your audience and especially by what you presume those readers know or want to know.

如果你认为写作在某些方面类似于对话，你就会发现观众的概念如何帮助塑造你所说的内容。例如，如果您正在与非美国人讨论一部美国电影，例如《弱点》（2​​009 年），那么您表达电影观点的方式以及观点本身可能都将取决于您的观点。相信个人了解并且想要了解美国文化和电影。（例如，非美国人可能需要更多有关美式橄榄球和大学招募高中球员的信息，而美国人则需要很少的信息。）同样，在与可能没有看过这部电影的人讨论一部电影时，我可能会首先对这部电影进行总体概述，总结情节和主题，以此说服那个人看或不看这部电影。另一方面，如果我正在谈论一部我和朋友都看过好几次的电影，例如《贫民窟的百万富翁》（2008），我就不必提醒那个人情节或主要角色。正如我们对电影的讨论因谈话对象的不同而不同一样，我们写电影的方式甚至我们选择的批评立场也因我们所针对的观众而异。

If you think of writing as, in some ways, resembling conversation, you will see how the notion of an audience helps shape what you say. If, for example, you are discussing an American movie, such as The Blind Side (2009), with a non-American, both the way you make your point about the film and, perhaps, the point itself will be determined by what you believe that individual knows and wants to know about American culture and about the movie. (A non-American, for example, may need more information about American football and college recruitment of high-school players, while an American will need very little information.) Similarly, in discussing a film with someone who may not have seen it, I would probably first describe that film with a general overview, summarizing the plot and themes as a way to convince that person to see the film or not to see it. If, on the other hand, I am talking about a movie that a friend and I have both seen several times, such as Slumdog Millioniare (2008), I do not have to remind that person of the plot or of the main characters. Just as our conversations about movies differ according to the individuals we are speaking with, the way we write about film and even the critical position we choose vary depending on the audience we are writing for.

指示作者可能设想的不同受众的一种示意性传统方法是区分以下各项：

One schematic and traditional way to indicate the different audiences a writer might envision is to distinguish among the following:

  • 筛查报告
  • A screening report
  • 电影评论
  • A movie review
  • 理论论文
  • A theoretical essay
  • 一篇批判性文章
  • A critical essay

如今，大量有关电影的文章出现在互联网上，而这种开放论坛确实往往会模糊这些区别，就像它模糊了不同类型文章的目标受众的清晰界限一样。虽然这四种写作模式并不是详尽无遗或完全不同的，但它们应该表明将读者牢记在心作为确定风格和目标的一种方式的重要性。

A great deal of writing about film today now appears on the Internet, and this kind of open forum does tend to blur these distinctions, just as it blurs a clear sense of the intended audience for different kinds of writing. While these four modes of writing are hardly exhaustive or completely distinct, they should indicate the importance of keeping your audience in mind as a way of determining your style and goals.

筛选报告

The Screening Report

筛选报告是一篇简短的文章，为课堂讨论和考试做准备。主要是组织电影笔记的描述性作业（参见第 23-25 页），报告应包含大约三到四个段落（大约一到两页），重点关注与课程主题相关的两到四个点或教师提出的具体问题（此类写作的目标受众）。与评论或批评文章不同，筛选报告避免强烈的意见或特定的论点。相反，它的目标是尽可能客观和具体，尽可能包括音频和视觉细节。在公路电影课程中，一名学生这样开始他的泰伦斯·马利克的《荒原》 （1973）的放映报告：

A screening report is a short piece of writing that acts as a preparation for class discussions and examinations. Primarily a descriptive assignment that organizes notes on a film (see pp. 23–25), the report should contain about three or four paragraphs (about one to two pages) focused on two to four points related to the topics of the course or to specific questions provided by the instructor (your target audience for this kind of writing). Unlike a review or critical essay, a screening report avoids strong opinions or a particular argument. Instead, it aims to be as objective and concrete as possible, including audio and visual detail wherever possible. For a class on the road movie, one student begins his screening report of Terrence Malick’s Badlands (1973) this way:

1. 《荒原》作为公路电影：叙事。这种类型的特点是远离家乡并走上开阔道路的旅程。与其他公路电影一样，除了飞行之外，这里没有明显的目标，情节发展为一系列偶发事件和遭遇。霍莉的父亲被谋杀后，她和基特几乎随意杀人路上的遭遇，就像是对其他公路电影中暴力的模仿。

1. Badlands as Road Movie: Narrative. Characteristic of this genre is the journey away from home and onto an open road. Like other road movies, here there are no apparent goals, except flight, and the plot develops as a series of episodic events and encounters. After the murder of Holly’s father, she and Kit almost randomly kill people they encounter on the road, as a kind of parody of the violence found in other road movies.

 

2.荒地与公路电影：作品。公路电影最明显的标志是载着基特和霍莉沿着西部开阔道路行驶的汽车的移动视角。这部电影中的众多镜头的取景唤起了人们对角色周围广阔而空旷的空间的关注，但与更现实的公路电影不同，荒地的发光图像常常创造出超现实的风景。配乐是该类型的一个不寻常的变体：霍莉的画外音旁白让这个故事看起来像一本廉价的浪漫小说，音乐范围从歌剧到下流酒吧。

2. Badlands and the Road Movie: Compositions. The most obvious emblem of a road movie is the moving perspective of the car that carries Kit and Holly along the open roads of the West. The framing of numerous shots in this film call attention to the vast and empty spaces that surround the characters, but unlike more realistic road movies, the luminous images of Badlands often create surreal landscapes. The sound track is an unusual variation on the genre: Holly’s voice-over narration makes the story seem like a cheap romantic novel, and the music ranges from the operatic to honky-tonk.

 

由于这是报告的第一个草图，因此必须稍后添加更多具体细节。对几个镜头和场景的精确描述将为课堂讨论和考试准备提供令人信服的支持。

Since this is a first sketch of the report, more specific details must be added later. Precise description of several shots and scenes will then provide compelling support for discussions in class and for preparation for examinations.

电影评论

The Movie Review

电影评论是我们大多数人最熟悉的电影分析类型，因为它几乎出现在每份报纸上。通常，评论针对的是尽可能广泛的观众，即对电影没有特殊了解的公众。相应地，它的功能就是介绍未知的电影并推荐或不推荐它们。因为它假定观众没有看过它所讨论的电影，所以文章的大部分内容都致力于总结情节或将电影置于另一个背景（导演的其他作品、同一类型的电影等）中，这可能会有所帮助读者明白了。在此，文森特·坎比 (Vincent Canby) 的评论向《纽约时报》的读者介绍了马利克的荒地(1973)：

The movie review is the type of film analysis with which most of us are chiefly familiar, since it appears in almost every newspaper. Normally, a review aims at the broadest possible audience, the general public with no special knowledge of film. Accordingly, its function is to introduce unknown films and to recommend or not recommend them. Because it presumes that an audience has not seen the movie it discusses, much of the essay is devoted to summarizing the plot or placing the film in another context (the director’s other work, films of the same genre, and so on) that might help the reader understand it. Here, Vincent Canby’s review introduces the readers of the New York Times to Malick’s Badlands (1973):

泰伦斯·马利克（Terrence Malick）的冷静、有时精彩、总是凶猛的美国电影《荒原》（Badlands）标志着马利克首次作为导演，基特和霍莉在中西部北部进行了一次全美国式的欢乐之旅，在这部电影的结尾，超过六名观众有人被基特开枪打死，通常是近距离射击。《荒原》是马利克先生的第一部故事片。马利克先生是一位 29 岁的前罗德学者和哲学系学生，他唯一的另一部电影作品是担任奇特的《零用钱》的剧本作者。《荒原》的灵感来自于查尔斯·斯塔克威瑟 (Charles Starkweather) 的简短血腥传奇，1958 年 1 月，19 岁的他在 14 岁女友卡罗尔·福盖特 (Carol Fugate) 的明显配合下，开始了一场疯狂的谋杀，导致了10名受害者。斯塔克韦瑟后来被电椅处决，富盖特小姐被判处终身监禁。

In Terrence Malick’s cool, sometimes brilliant, always ferociously American film, “Badlands,” which marks Malick’s debut as a director, Kit and Holly take an all-American joyride across the upper Middle West, at the end of which more than half a dozen people have been shot to death by Kit, usually at point blank range. “Badlands” is the first feature by Mr. Malick, a 29-year-old former Rhodes Scholar and philosophy student whose only other film credit is as the author of the screenplay for the nicely idiosyncratic “Pocket Money.” “Badlands” was inspired by the short, bloody saga of Charles Starkweather who, at age 19, in January, 1958, with the apparent cooperation of his 14-year-old girlfriend, Carol Fugate, went off on a murder spree that resulted in 10 victims. Starkweather was later executed in the electric chair and Miss Fugate given life imprisonment.

 

《荒原》不可避免地会与其他三部重要的美国电影——阿瑟·佩恩的《雌雄大盗》和弗里茨·朗的《狂怒》和《雷霆万钧》进行比较——但它对暴力和死亡有着截然不同的看法。马利克先生并没有花大量时间援引弗洛伊德来解释基特和霍莉的行为，也没有任何抑郁症要负最终责任。如果有的话，社会是良性的......

“Badlands” inevitably invites comparisons with three other important American films—Arthur Penn’s “Bonnie and Clyde” and Fritz Lang’s “Fury” and “You Only Live Once”—but it has a very different vision of violence and death. Mr. Malick spends no great amount of time invoking Freud to explain the behavior of Kit and Holly, nor is there any Depression to be held ultimately responsible. Society is, if anything, benign....

 

《荒原》由霍莉用平淡的中西部鼻音和《真实浪漫史》中故事的语法来叙述。“我几乎没有意识到，”她在影片开头告诉我们，“从这个小镇的小巷和小道开始的一切最终会在蒙大拿州的荒地结束。” 最后，在经历了六起谋杀案之后，她决定不再“跟那些顽固的人在一起”。

“Badlands” is narrated by Holly in the flat, nasal accents of the Middle West and in the syntax of a story in True Romances. “Little did I realize,” she tells us at the beginning of the film, “that what began in the alleys and by-ways of this small town would end in the Badlands of Montana.” At the end, after half a dozen murders, she resolves never again to “tag around with the hell-bent type.”

 

基特和霍莉与邦妮和克莱德一样，对自己的新闻报道和一夜成名都着迷（“全世界都在寻找我们，”霍莉说，“因为谁知道基特下一步会袭击哪里？”），但缺乏激情使他们有别于三十年代的浮华亡命之徒。在他们的欢乐之旅即将结束时，无聊的霍莉告诉我们，她坐在基特旁边的前座上，用舌头在上颚拼出完整的句子，以此打发时间。

Kit and Holly share with Bonnie and Clyde a fascination with their own press coverage, with their overnight fame (“The whole world was looking for us,” says Holly, “for who knew where Kit would strike next?”), but a lack of passion differentiates them from the gaudy desperados of the thirties. Toward the end of their joyride, the bored Holly tells us she passed the time, as she sat in the front seat beside Kit, spelling out complete sentences with her tongue on the roof of her mouth.

 

马利克先生尽量不把凶手浪漫化，除了基特和霍莉躲在树屋里的一个镜头外，他很成功，这和米高梅艺术部门为泰山和简设计的树屋一样精致。辛先生和斯派塞克小姐出色地扮演了我们这个时代自私、残忍、甚至可能患有精神病的孩子，配角们也是如此，包括饰演霍莉父亲的沃伦·奥茨。

Mr. Malick tries not to romanticize his killers, and he is successful except for one sequence in which Kit and Holly hide out in a tree house as elaborate as anything the MGM art department ever designed for Tarzan and Jane. Mr. Sheen and Miss Spacek are splendid as the self-absorbed, cruel, possibly psychotic children of our time, as are the members of the supporting cast, including Warren Oates as Holly’s father.

 

人们可以合理地争论马利克先生的愿景的有效性，但我认为不能争论他巨大的才华。《荒地》是一部最重要、最激动人心的电影。(40)

One may legitimately debate the validity of Mr. Malick’s vision, but not, I think, his immense talent. “Badlands” is a most important and exciting film. (40)

 

我们可以在这篇文章中识别出不止一个函数。坎比的目的是让他的读者相信《荒地》是一部值得一看的重要电影，他通过介绍马利克和他的资历、描述情节和该情节的历史背景、评估表演以及将马利克的电影放在一边来做到这一点。在其他类似电影的背景下（特别是《邦妮和克莱德》 [1967]以及两部弗里茨·朗的电影）。然而，同样重要的是他对读者的清晰认识：读者可能了解流行的邦妮和克莱德，但对马利克和荒地的背景知之甚少。这些读者还没有看过电影，想了解故事的梗概以及一些人物和演员的信息（图1.02）。

We can identify more than one function in this essay. Canby aims to convince his reader that Badlands is an important movie that is worth seeing, and he does this by introducing Malick and his credentials, by describing the plot and the historical background of that plot, by evaluating the acting, and by placing Malick’s movie in the context of other films like it (specifically, Bonnie and Clyde [1967] and the two Fritz Lang movies). Equally important, however, is his clear sense of his audience: readers who probably know the popular Bonnie and Clyde but little about Malick and the background of Badlands. These are readers who have not yet seen the film and would like to know the outline of the story and a little about the characters and actors (Figure 1.02).

图 1.02 像大多数电影一样，《荒原》（1973）引发了多种思考和写作的方式：放映报告、评论、评论文章和理论反思。

Figure 1.02 Like most films, Badlands (1973) provokes a variety of ways to think and write about it: screening reports, reviews, critical essays, and theoretical reflections.

 

理论论文

The Theoretical Essay

更具理论性的文章——例如，一篇关于电影与现实的关系、关于电影业的政治或意识形态基础的文章，或者关于电影叙事与文学叙事有何不同的文章——则处于该范围的另一端。这样的文章通常假设读者拥有大量关于特定电影、电影史和其他有关电影的著作的知识。它的目标受众通常是高年级学生或电影研究教授，通常对电影非常了解。也许是为了争论电影表现的独特之处，或者也许是为了展示电影与其他艺术的共同点，一篇主要是理论性的电影文章提供了一个解释模型，可以阐明不止一部电影，旨在解释电影中一些更大、更复杂的结构。电影以及我们如何理解它们。请注意风格、用词的选择以及对读者知识的假设的变化，这些变化表明了作者 1953 年对读者的概念：

The more theoretical essay—for instance, an essay on the relation of film and reality, on the political or ideological foundations of the movie industry, or on how film narrative is unlike literary narrative—is at the other end of the spectrum. Such an essay often supposes that the reader possesses a great deal of knowledge about specific films, film history, and other writings about film. Its target audience, often advanced students or people who teach film studies, is usually very knowledgeable about the movies. Perhaps arguing what is unique about cinematic representation or perhaps showing what the cinema shares with other arts, a film essay that is primarily theoretical offers an explanatory model that illuminate more than one film, aiming to explain some of the larger and more complex structures of the cinema and how we understand them. Note the changes in style, choice of words, and assumptions about the reader’s knowledge that point to this writer’s 1953 conception of her audience:

这是新艺术。几十年来，它似乎只不过是戏剧领域的一种新技术设备，一种保存和零售戏剧表演的新方式。但今天它的发展已经推翻了这个假设。银幕不是舞台，电影的构思和实现中所创造的东西也不是戏剧。现在还为时过早系统化了这种新艺术的任何理论，但我认为，即使在目前的原始状态下，它也毫无疑问地展示了——不仅是一种新技术，而且是一种新的诗意模式。（兰格411）

Here is new art. For a few decades it seemed like nothing more than a new technical device in the sphere of drama, a new way of preserving and retailing dramatic performances. But today its development has already belied this assumption. The screen is not a stage, and what is created in the conception and realization of a film is not a play. It is too early to systematize any theory of this new art, but even in its present pristine state it exhibits quite beyond any doubt, I think—not only a new technique, but a new poetic mode. (Langer 411)

 

虽然坎比可以使用适合评论的表达方式，例如“俗气的亡命之徒”、“全美欢乐之旅”和“重要而令人兴奋的电影”，但这些短语在哲学家苏珊娜·兰格的文章中似乎不合适。并不是说一种风格比另一种更正确；而是一种风格更正确。这只是观众的问题。电影研究的新手可能会对兰格相对通俗易懂的电影理论论文感到有些迷失。原因在于，新手并不是笔者设想的受众；她想象观众有历史、美学和哲学研究经验，并且对舞台剧与电影的争论有一定的了解。她文章的目的不难看出（让她的读者相信电影作为一门艺术的重要性），但是当我们意识到她正在向当时的学术和知识界发表讲话时，她如何论证她的观点是可以理解的，对电影作为艺术的地位表示怀疑。

Whereas Canby could use expressions suitable to a review, such as “gaudy desperados,” “all-American joyride,” and “important and exciting film,” the phrases might seem out of place in an essay by the philosopher Susanne Langer. It is not that one style is more correct than the other; it is simply a question of audience. A novice to film studies might feel somewhat lost in Langer’s comparatively accessible essay on film theory. The reason is that novices are not the audience that this writer supposes; she imagines an audience with experience in the study of history, aesthetics, and philosophy and some understanding of the debates about stage drama versus movies. The purpose of her essay is not difficult to see (to convince her readers of the significance of film as an art), but how she argues her point is understandable when we realize that she is addressing an academic and intellectual community that, at the time, was suspicious of the status of the movies as an art.

批判性文章

The Critical Essay

电影课程中通常期望的评论文章介于理论文章和电影评论之间。这类文章的作者假定他或她的读者已经看过或至少熟悉所讨论的电影，尽管该读者可能没有广泛思考过它。因此，作者可能会提醒读者情节的关键主题和元素，但对电影故事的冗长重述既没有必要，也不可接受。这篇文章的重点比评论的重点要具体得多，因为作者希望揭示观众在第一次甚至第二次观看时可能没有注意到的微妙之处或复杂性。因此，本文可能会关注电影开头的一个简短序列或与特定角色相关的摄像机角度。在下面的摘录中，布莱恩·亨德森还讨论了《荒地》，但坎比的观众是一份大报纸的读者，而亨德森的观众则更具学术性，类似于学生在电影课程中可能讲到的观众：

The critical essay usually expected in film courses falls between the theoretical essay and the movie review. The writer of this kind of essay presumes that his or her reader has seen or is at least familiar with the film under discussion, although that reader may not have thought extensively about it. This writer might therefore remind the reader of key themes and elements of the plot, but a lengthy retelling of the story of the film is neither needed nor acceptable. The focus of the essay is far more specific than that of a review, because the writer hopes to reveal subtleties or complexities that may have escaped viewers on the first or even the second viewing. Thus the essay might focus on a short sequence at the beginning of the film or on a camera angle that becomes associated with a specific character. In the following excerpt, Brian Henderson also discusses Badlands, but whereas Canby’s audience was the reader of a large newspaper, Henderson’s audience is more academic, similar to the one a student might address in a film course:

无论他们的意愿如何，泰伦斯·马利克的《荒原》（1973）的批评者们都陷入了争论。支持这部电影的作家们为它辩护，反对那些在它首次出现时称其为失败的人以及那些从那以后忽视它的人。1978 年马利克的《天堂之日》的发行使这个问题变得更加复杂，争论也重新燃起。

Whatever their wishes, critics of Terrence Malick’s Badlands (1973) have been drawn into polemical dispute. Writers favorable to the film have defended it against those who called it a failure when it first appeared and against those who have ignored it since then. The issue has been further complicated, and polemics renewed, by the release in 1978 of Malick’s Days of Heaven.

 

这并不是对任何作品进行严肃批评的有利背景，更不用说对于新的、未经研究的作品所引发的开放式探索而言。我相信《荒原》是 20 世纪 70 年代最杰出的美国电影之一，但我没有兴趣在这里讨论反对它的论点。无论如何，我认为这部电影将在未来很长一段时间内被观看和研究。

This is not a favorable background for the serious criticism of any work, still less for that open-ended exploration which a new and unstudied work invites. I believe Badlands is one of the most remarkable American films of the 1970s, but I have no interest here in addressing the arguments against it. I assume, at any rate, that the film will be seen and studied for a long time to come.

 

这里尝试的是对荒地的初步分析，或者也许是几个开始。我采取一个明显的出发点：霍莉的电影画外音旁白——实际上只是它的第一部分，大约是电影的前十六分钟。需要强调的是，这只是这部电影的一种处理方式，而不是一种特权方式。对霍莉的叙述的思考会开辟其他话题并导致其他分析，但任何方法都会这样做。

What is attempted here is a beginning analysis of Badlands, or perhaps several beginnings. I take an obvious point of departure: the film’s voiceover narration by Holly—indeed only its first part, approximately the film’s first sixteen minutes. This is, emphatically, just one approach to the film and not a privileged one. A consideration of Holly’s narration opens up other topics and leads to other analyses, but any approach does this.

 

要按照我的意愿对待霍莉的叙述，有必要提前说一下电影的戏剧结构、表演风格和语言的运用。不用说，这些重要的主题值得比我的序言所提供的更全面的处理。

To treat Holly’s narration as I wish to do it is necessary to say something in advance about the film’s dramaturgy, acting style and use of language. These important topics deserve, needless to say, fuller treatment than my prefatory remarks provide.

 

不可否认，荒地的人物塑造方式是现代的。基特和霍莉既茫然又不茫然，无感情又充满感情，无视自己的命运却又深陷其中，专注于琐碎的事情，但又瞥见了本质。他们是空的，因此不断地用无用的物品、纪念品、电影杂志八卦填满自己；他们对自己进行测试，尝试不同的化妆、服装、态度、角色。这是一种“存在主义”的性格观，毫无疑问会导致与传统标准的矛盾。因此基特和霍莉相爱了，只为他们在一起度过的时光而活。但他们在乡下打牌无聊，甚至觉得性很无聊。霍莉和她的父亲一起玩耍，当他去世时（几乎）哭泣，但几个小时后带着凶手逃跑了……

Badlands’ approach to character is undeniably modern. Kit and Holly are both blank and not blank, emotionless and filled with emotion, oblivious to their fates and caught up in them, committed to the trivial but aware—glancingly—of the essential. They are empty, hence constantly fill themselves up with useless objects, souvenirs, movie-magazine gossip; they pose tests for themselves and try on different make-up, clothes, attitudes, roles. This is an “existential” view of character, and it undoubtedly leads to contradictions by conventional standards. Thus Kit and Holly are in love, living only for the moments they spend together; but they play cards with boredom in the country and even find sex boring. Holly kids with her father and (almost) weeps when he dies, but runs away with his killer a few hours later....

 

每种电影模式都有其独特的戏剧创作模式以及相应的独特表演或表演风格。《荒原》本身可能代表了一种电影模式，它需要一种特殊的表演来占据一席之地，但又不能扰乱场景调度、叙事、画外音、音乐等的非常微妙的平衡。能够看着基特和霍莉，有时交替地、有时同时地审视他们。这就需要一种既平淡又华丽、现实又戏剧化的表演风格。即使我们在关注其他事物，我们的目光也必须集中在人物身上。我们的注意力不断地被吸引到人物身上，并从他们身上分散开来。辛和斯派塞克出色地实现了这些要求，让影片充满了他们有趣的声音和动作但永远不会解决任何事情，永远不会实体化、定义或“成为”角色。也许更正确的是，他们的一系列姿势可以准确地解读为那样，或者作为古怪的性格。就像布莱希特一样，很难将表演者的表演风格与人物的本质区分开来。(38–40)

Every mode of cinema has a mode of dramaturgy distinctive to it and a corresponding distinctive acting or performance style. Badlands, which may represent a cinematic mode in and of itself, requires a special kind of acting to take its place within, but not upset, a very delicate balance of mise-en-scène, narrative, voiceover, music, etc. We must be able to look at Kit and Holly and to look through them sometimes alternately, sometimes simultaneously. This requires an acting style at once flat and flamboyant, realistic and theatrical. Our eyes must be on the characters even as we are paying attention to other things. Our attention is continually drawn toward the characters, and distracted away from them. Sheen and Spacek realize these requirements superbly, filling the film with their interesting sounds and motions but never resolving into anything, never substantializing, defining or “becoming” characters. Perhaps more correctly, their series of poses is readable as exactly that, or as eccentric character. As in Brecht, it is difficult to distinguish the acting style of the performers from the nature of the characters. (38–40)

 

坎比和亨德森的文章都是对荒地的积极回应，而且他们有着相似的兴趣。然而，它们在目标和受众方面存在显着差异。至少正如亨德森所说，他的文章的目的并不是说服读者喜欢或不喜欢这部电影，而是增加他们对这部电影的理解。他认为他的读者将继续观看和研究这部电影，或许还会增加有关它的学术辩论。他还理所当然地认为他的观众了解故事、了解人物，并且熟悉场景调度等术语。因此，他可以选择电影中非常具体的部分——霍莉的旁白和表演风格——来证明他的观点，即《荒原》有重要的创新。最后，即使在本文的这一部分，人们也看到了一个典型的良好批评论证的组织：作者首先将电影置于其他批评和学术观点的背景下，宣布他的目标，然后从对人物的分析开始和表演风格得出关于如何理解这种风格的一些一般性结论。

Canby and Henderson’s essays are both positive responses to Badlands, and they share similar interests. They differ significantly, however, in aim and audience. At least as Henderson declares it, the purpose of his essay is not so much to convince his readers to like or dislike the film but to add to their understanding of it. He assumes that his readers will continue to see and study the movie and, perhaps, to add to the academic debate about it. He also takes for granted that his audience knows the story, knows the characters, and is familiar with terms like mise-en-scène; accordingly, he can choose very specific parts of the film—Holly’s narration and the acting style—to demonstrate his point that there are important innovations in Badlands. Finally, even in this section of the essay, one sees an organization typical of a good critical argument: The writer begins by placing the film in the context of other critical and scholarly views, announces his aim, and then moves from an analysis of character and acting style to some general conclusions about how to understand this style.

对于学生作家来说，这三篇文章中强调的观众问题对于电影写作同样重要。有时，讲师可能会给你布置一项针对特定受众的作业，并测试你向该受众演讲的能力：“为《时代》杂志的读者写一篇《严肃的人》（2009）的评论。” 更多时候，你的导师只会要求你写一篇评论文章。请记住，在这些情况下，你的听众既不是你的老师（你可能会想象，他们无法从你身上学到任何东西），也不是街上一些不知名的公众（你可能倾向于向他们讲述关于他们的最明显的事实）。电影）。相反，在大多数情况下，将你的观众想象为你的同学，那些看过这部电影并且可能了解一些但没有仔细研究过的人。这些观众可能不需要被告知“绿野仙踪是一部已成为儿童经典的美国老电影”；然而，如果您注意到“《绿野仙踪》是由维克多·弗莱明执导，同年（1939 年）拍摄了《飘》”，他们可能会感兴趣。同样，很少有观众需要知道“奥菲尔的《悲伤与遗憾》（1970 年）是一部关于二战的很长的法国电影”，但他们可能会对开场镜头的详细描述着迷。

For the student writer, the question of audience, highlighted in these three essays, is equally central to writing about film. Sometimes, an instructor may give you an assignment aimed at a specific audience and testing your ability to address that audience: “Write a review of A Serious Man (2009) for the readers of Time magazine.” More often, your instructor will simply ask you to write a critical essay. Keep in mind that your audience in these cases is neither your instructor alone (who, you might imagine, can learn nothing from you) nor some large and unknown public in the streets (to whom you might be prone to tell the most obvious facts about a movie). Rather, envision your audience in most situations as your fellow students, individuals who have seen the movie and may know something about it but who have not studied it closely. This audience will probably not need to be told that “The Wizard of Oz is an old American film that has become a children’s classic”; they may, however, be interested if you note that “The Wizard of Oz was directed by Victor Fleming, who the same year (1939) made Gone with the Wind.” Likewise, few of your fellow viewers need to be told that “Ophul’s The Sorrow and the Pity (1970) is a very long French movie about World War II,” but they may be fascinated by a detailed description of the opening shots.

意见与评价

Opinion and Evaluation

当你写电影时，个人观点和品味必然会成为你论点的一部分。例如，一些评论家对外国电影有意识或无意识的偏见。其他人则喜欢单一导演的作品，例如约翰·休斯顿或韦斯·安德森。还有一些人对文学改编感到恼火，除非它们忠实于原著，他们不喜欢莎士比亚的《奥赛罗》的当代版本《O》（2001）等电影，但捍卫肯尼思·布拉纳的莎士比亚电影。即使那些看起来主要是描述性或分析性的文章——传记或历史著作或旨在对一系列镜头进行客观分析的文章——也包含一定程度的个人选择和评价。在一些文章中，事实描述可能比评价性判断更为突出，但差异只是程度而非种类。大多数有关电影的文章都涉及一些个人观点和评价。

When you write about film, personal opinion and taste will necessarily become part of your argument. Some critics, for example, have a conscious or unconscious prejudice against foreign films. Others favor the work of a single director, such as John Huston or Wes Anderson. Still others, annoyed by literary adaptations unless they are faithful to the original, dislike films such as the contemporary version of Shakespeare’s Othello called O (2001) but defend the Shakespeare films of Kenneth Branagh. Even those essays that appear to be chiefly descriptive or analytical—biographical or historical writings or essays that aim at an objective analysis of a sequence of shots—involve a certain amount of personal choice and evaluation. In some essays, factual description may be more prominent than evaluative judgments, but the differences are of degree, not kind. Most writing about film involves some personal opinion and evaluation.

当然，没有读者会对一个利用个人观点来回避或掩饰坚定的批评立场的作家感到满意。一名学生在观看劳伦斯·奥利维尔 (Laurence Olivier) 改编的莎士比亚戏剧《亨利五世》 (1944) 后写道，

No reader, of course, will be satisfied with a writer who uses his personal opinions to avoid or disguise a solid critical position. After watching Laurence Olivier’s adaptation of Shakespeare’s Henry V (1944), one student wrote,

虽然我没有读过很多莎士比亚戏剧，但这是我第一次喜欢的莎士比亚戏剧。我认为，开头是最有趣的部分，也是最先引起我注意的部分，因为在我看来，它确实将我觉得枯燥的戏剧变成了一部令人兴奋的电影，同时，对戏剧和电影的区别。在这些开场图像中，在我看来，奥利维尔承认了戏剧的原始舞台世界，并展示了电影如何超越戏剧的限制。他让这部戏对我来说更加生动。

Although I have not read that many Shakespeare plays, this is the first one I ever liked. The opening, I think, is the most interesting part and the section that first grabbed my attention, because, in my opinion, it literally transforms what I feel is a dry play into an exciting film and, at the same time, comments on the difference between drama and film. In those opening images, it seems to me that Olivier acknowledges the original stage world of the drama and shows, I feel, how the movies can transcend dramatic limits. He makes the play much more alive for me.

 

这里过多的“我”和个人限定词削弱了作者想要表达的观点，而且令人怀疑的是，诸如作者对莎士比亚戏剧的有限经验之类的特殊问题是否对任何读者都没有兴趣。然而，删除所有对作者个人电影经历的引用只会导致散文更加僵硬但同样不确定：

Here the excess of I’s and personal qualifiers weakens the point the writer wishes to make, and it is doubtful that idiosyncratic problems, such as the writer’s limited experience with the Shakespeare plays, are of the faintest interest to any reader. However, removing all references to the writer’s personal experience of the film results only in stiffer but equally unsure prose:

开场是《亨利五世》（1944）最有趣的部分，因为它评论了戏剧和电影之间的核心区别。在这些开场图片中，奥利维尔承认了戏剧的原始舞台世界，并展示了电影如何超越这些戏剧性的限制。

The opening is the most interesting part of Henry V (1944), because it comments on the central difference between drama and film. In these opening images, Olivier acknowledges the original stage world of the drama and shows how the movies can transcend those dramatic limits.

 

在两者之间的某个地方，作者找到了个人经历和客观观察之间的适当平衡，明智地将那些可能对其他观众也有效的个人经历和对电影的感受结合起来：

Somewhere in between, the writer finds the proper balance of personal experience and objective observation, judiciously integrating those personal experiences and feelings about the film that are probably also valid for other viewers:

即使对于对莎士比亚戏剧感到不安的观众来说，奥利维尔的《亨利五世》（1944）也是一次引人入胜的体验。对我来说，开场是最有趣的部分，也是最有可能吸引不情愿的观众的部分，因为它确实将对某些人来说可能是枯燥的戏剧变成了一部广阔的电影，同时评论了戏剧和电影之间的主要区别。在这些开场图片中，奥利维尔承认了戏剧的原始舞台世界，并展示了电影如何超越这些戏剧性的限制。对于像我这样的观众来说，莎士比亚突然变得栩栩如生。

Even for the viewer uneasy with a Shakespeare play, Olivier’s Henry V (1944) is an engaging experience. For me, the opening is the most interesting part and the section which is most likely to attract a reluctant viewer, because it literally transforms what, for some, might be a dry play into an expansive film and, at the same time, comments on the central difference between drama and film. In these opening images, Olivier acknowledges the original stage world of the drama and shows how the movies can transcend those dramatic limits. For viewers like myself, Shakespeare suddenly comes alive.

 

这里有用的经验法则是尝试了解你的个人观点和感受何时以及如何进入你的批评，以及它们在多大程度上有价值或无价值——简而言之，当这些判断似乎不仅仅对你自己来说是正确的时，但对其他人来说也是如此。当作者仔细思考并提供这种厌恶的原因时，个人对动作片或慢节奏的浪漫故事的厌恶可能会成为文章的丰富部分。或者，作为一个主要观看好莱坞电影的人，我的期望可能对分析我对墨西哥电影制片人吉列尔莫·德尔·托罗的电影（例如《潘神的迷宫》（2006））的轻微困惑和迷恋至关重要，因为其他观众经常也有同样的困惑。

The useful rule of thumb here is to try to be aware of when and how your personal perspective and feelings enter your criticism and to what degree they are valuable or not—when, in short, those judgments seem to say something true not only for yourself, but for others, as well. A personal distaste for action films or, say, for slow-paced romantic stories could become a rich part of an essay when the writer carefully thinks through and offers reasons for that distaste. Or my expectations, as someone who mainly sees slick Hollywood films, could be crucial in analyzing my slight confusion yet fascination with a film by the Mexican filmmaker Guillermo del Toro—such as Pan’s Labyrinth (2006)—because other viewers have often shared that confusion.

在前面使用的例子中，坎比和亨德森都公开地将自己的观点和个性引入到他们的论点中。两人都毫不犹豫地用“我”来强调他的观点的存在：“人们可以合理地争论马利克先生电影的有效性，但我认为，他的巨大才华却不能”（坎比）；“我采取一个明显的出发点：电影的画外音由霍莉进行旁白......强调，这只是电影的一种方法，而不是一种特权”（亨德森）。坎比的我可能是一个更加固执己见的我；亨德森则更加超然和谨慎。然而，坎比和亨德森都利用他们的个人立场来帮助形成和激发他们对马利克电影的不同反应。有人可能会说，“我”的这些用法只是文章中许多其他评价和判断的最直率和直接的指示：坎比对两个亡命之徒隐藏的浪漫、丛林般的环境的批评，以及亨德森对叙事和理论问题的兴趣。 “表现。”

In the examples used earlier, both Canby and Henderson openly introduce their own opinions and personalities into their argument. Neither balks at using I to underline the presence of his perspective: “One may legitimately debate the validity of Mr. Malick’s movie, but not, I think, his immense talent” (Canby); “I take an obvious point of departure: the film’s voiceover narration by Holly.... This is, emphatically, just one approach to the film and not a privileged one” (Henderson). Canby’s is perhaps a more opinionated I; Henderson’s is more detached and cautious. Yet both Canby and Henderson use their personal positions to help form and energize their different responses to Malick’s film. One might say that these uses of I are only the most forthright and direct indication of the many other evaluations and judgments that enter the essays: Canby’s criticism of the romantic, junglelike setting where the two outlaws hide and Henderson’s interest in narrative and theoretical questions about “performance.”

当你写电影时，个人感受、期望和反应可能是明智批评的开始，但它们必须严格反思这些感受、期望和反应的来源，以及它们与有关电影的更客观因素的关系：它在电影史上的地位、文化背景和形式策略。弗朗索瓦·特吕弗既是一位聪明的电影制片人，也是一位敏锐的评论家，他观察到“与其沉溺于批评的热情，不如至少尝试带着某种目的进行批评……有趣的不是宣布一部电影好或坏，但解释原因”（370）。

When you write about the movies, personal feelings, expectations, and reactions may be the beginning of an intelligent critique, but they must be balanced with rigorous reflection on where those feelings and expectations and reactions come from and how they relate to more objective factors concerning the movie in question: its place in film history, its cultural background, and its formal strategies. François Truffaut, both an intelligent filmmaker and a perceptive critic, has observed that “instead of indulging passions in criticism, one must at least try to be critical with some purpose.... What is interesting is not pronouncing a film good or bad, but explaining why” (370).

那么，关于电影的写作无疑是复杂的。它也可以是令人兴奋和有益的。1908 年，列夫·托尔斯泰 (Leo Tolstoy) 在谈到电影时说道：“你可以看到，这个带有旋转手柄的小装置将给我们的生活——作家的生活带来一场革命”（410）。尝试以同样的兴趣和精明来对待电影。尝试将自己想象成一名作家，与您观看和喜欢的电影有着同样有目的和动态的关系。或者，用《惊悚片》 ( Thriller ) (1979)、《奥兰多》( Orlando ) (1992)、 《探戈课》( The Tango Lesson) (1997) 和《愤怒》( Rage ) (2009) 的导演萨莉·波特 (Sally Potter) 的话来说，请记住，“分析、解开和思考是一种乐趣” ”（帕姆·库克 27）。

Writing about film, then, is admittedly complex. It can also be exciting and rewarding. In 1908, Leo Tolstoy remarked about the movies, “You can see that this little clicking contraption with the revolving handle will make a revolution in our life—in the life of writers” (410). Try to approach films with the same interest and shrewdness. Try to conceive of yourself as a writer with an equally purposeful and dynamic relationship with the movies you watch and enjoy. Or, in the words of filmmaker Sally Potter, director of Thriller (1979), Orlando (1992), The Tango Lesson (1997), and Rage (2009), remember that there is a “pleasure in analysis, in unravelling, in thinking” (Pam Cook 27).

练习

Exercises

  1. 在关于一部电影的辩论中采取相反的立场。写一篇批评这部电影的段落，然后写一篇捍卫它的段落。在这两种情况下，都集中在一个场景上来表达你的观点。
  2. Take opposite sides in a debate about a single film. Write one paragraph criticizing the film and then one paragraph defending it. In both cases, focus on a single scene to make your point.
  3. 写一篇电影的放映报告，然后写三到四个段落的评论。然后将评论重写为批判性文章。简要解释一下你设想的读者群、每篇文章的主要区别以及每篇文章的收获和损失。
  4. Write a screening report on a film and then a review of three or four paragraphs. Then rewrite the review as a critical essay. Explain briefly the audiences you envisioned, the main differences in each piece of writing, and what is gained and lost in each.

2

开始思考、准备观看并开始写作

2

BEGINNING TO THINK, PREPARING TO WATCH, AND STARTING TO WRITE

 

在写电影的几个困难中，最突出的一个是如何把握具有如此多不同层次的体验。简而言之，您应该选择分析和撰写什么内容？故事？演技？编辑？观看电影涉及到一切，从我们观看电影的地点、我们支付的价格、屏幕的大小、故事的节奏，以及用作故事背景的音乐类型。用让·谷克多的话来说，“电影缪斯太丰富了。” 正如科克托所说，作为明智观看的第一步，观众需要打破“用眼角余光”观看电影的习惯（217）。这就是分析开始的地方。

Of the several difficulties in writing about film, one of the most prominent is getting a handle on an experience that has so many different layers. Put simply, what should you choose to analyze and to write about? The story? The acting? The editing? Watching a film involves everything from the place where we see it and the price we pay to the size of the screen, the pace of the story, and the kind of music used as the background for that story. In Jean Cocteau’s words, “The cinema muse is too rich.” As the first step to an intelligent viewing, spectators need to break the habit of watching films “out of the corners of their eyes,” as Cocteau puts it (217). This is where analysis begins.

当然，我们对一部电影的主要体验是第一次观看它时的独特的、也许是私人的体验——人们希望能够参与并享受它，但可能会感到恼火，但仍然有些参与。正如让-吕克·戈达尔 1983 年的电影《名字：卡门》（由戈达尔本人饰演）中的导演所写，“看得不好，说得也不好”：全神贯注地看一部电影是开始写一部电影的唯一方法——即使是一部你不喜欢。然而，无论是作为放映前的准备还是放映后不久，作为编剧的你都需要按照可管理的思路整理个人和主要经历，而这种整理应该成为你分析电影的基础。应该谈谈角色吗？关于技术创新？关于这部电影对观众的影响？你应该从哪里开始集中你的注意力和分析，这样你就不会给自己完成写整部电影的不可能的任务？因为你在屏幕上看到的电影是多种不同力量的产物——编剧、制作需求、技术成本以及数百种其他力量——从某种意义上说，这些力量先于你正在观看的图像，所以有必要以对其中一些基本问题、影响和问题的敏感性。在电影中，大量的精力和时间投入到“前期制作”活动中，即导演和制片人概述和准备剧本和拍摄策略；如果您同样至少花一些时间在一般性的初步问题上，您的分析将会更好。据，直到...为止可能的话，为看电影做好准备；甚至在开始之前，就询问有关它的问题以及您自己对它的潜在兴趣：

Certainly our primary experience of a movie is the singular and, perhaps, private one of watching it for the first time—involved and enjoying it, one hopes, but possibly annoyed yet still somewhat involved. As the director in Jean-Luc Godard’s 1983 film First Name: Carmen (played by Godard himself) writes, “Badly seen, badly said”: Seeing a movie with all your attention is the only way to begin writing about a film—even one you don’t like. Either as preparation before the screening or shortly afterward, however, you, as the writer, need to sort out that personal and primary experience along manageable lines, and this sorting out should become the groundwork for your analysis of the movie. Should you talk about the characters? About technological innovations? About the film’s effect on an audience? Where should you start to direct your attention and your analysis so that you do not give yourself the impossible task of writing about the whole movie? Because the movies you see on the screen are a product of many different forces—writers, production demands, the cost of technology, and hundreds of others—that in a sense precede the images you are watching, it is necessary to approach those movies with sensitivity to some of these basic questions, influences, and problems. In the movies, much energy and time go into “preproduction” activity, when directors and producers outline and prepare scripts and filming strategies; your analysis will be better if you similarly spend at least some time on general, preliminary questions. As far as possible, prepare yourself for a movie; even before it starts, ask questions about it and about your own potential interest in it:

1. 作为一种艺术形式，电影涉及文学、绘画和造型艺术、音乐、舞蹈、戏剧，甚至建筑。因此，对建筑感兴趣的学生可能会对爱森斯坦或安东尼奥尼的电影产生敏锐的反应，如果他或她能够将兴趣转移到这些电影制片人如何利用建筑空间来添加他们所呈现的戏剧中。音乐或艺术学生可能会被某些艺术或实验电影所吸引，例如柏林：城市交响曲（1927），或电影的音乐或艺术特征（图2.01）。问问自己哪种艺术形式您最感兴趣以及您最了解哪种艺术形式。你能用你的文学或绘画知识来指导一部特定的电影吗？最近大量改编著名小说，例如米拉·奈尔 (Mira Nair) 改编的威廉·萨克雷 (William Thackeray) 小说《名利场》 ( Vanity Fair) (2004)，或科恩兄弟 (Cohen brothers) 改编的科马克·麦卡锡 (Cormac McCarthy) 小说《路》 ( The Road , 2009)，背后可能隐藏着什么？您对流行音乐或古典音乐的兴趣可能会建议您在《假日酒店》（1942 年）、《西城故事》（1961 年）、《红磨坊》等电影中寻找主题！（2001），还是《理发师陶德》（2007）？

1. As an art form, the movies involve literature, the pictorial and plastic arts, music, dance, theater, and even architecture. The student interested in architecture might thus respond keenly to an Eisenstein or Antonioni movie if he or she can direct that interest to how these filmmakers use architectural space to add to the drama they are presenting. A music or art student might be drawn to certain art or experimental films, such as Berlin: Symphony of a City (1927), or to the musical or artistic features of a movie (Figure 2.01). Ask yourself which art forms interest you most and which you know the most about. Could you use your knowledge of literature or painting as a guide to a particular film? What might be behind the large number of recent adaptations of famous novels, like Mira Nair’s version of a William Thackeray novel, Vanity Fair (2004), or the Cohen brothers’ adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s The Road (2009)? Might your interest in popular or classical music suggest that you look for a topic in movies like Holiday Inn (1942), West Side Story (1961), Moulin Rouge! (2001), or Sweeney Todd (2007)?

图 2.01 沟口健二的《歌麻吕和他的五个女人》（1946 年）讲述了日本最著名的视觉艺术家之一的故事。他的名气依赖于他在 19 世纪初创作的精彩浮世绘木版画，而沟口对那段生活的电影再现向艺术学生提出了许多问题：例如，流行艺术与现代艺术之间是否存在联系？电影和浮世绘版画的流行艺术？这部电影是否再现了该艺术传统的某些技巧或特征？

Figure 2.01 Kenji Mizoguchi’s Utamaro and His Five Women (1946) tells the tale of one of Japan’s most renowned visual artists. His celebrity rests on the brilliant ukiyo-e wood-block prints he produced in the early nineteenth century, and Mizoguchi’s cinematic recreation of that life raises many questions for the student of art: For instance, is there a connection here between the popular art of the movies and the popular art of ukiyo-e prints? Does the film recreate certain techniques or features of that artistic tradition?

 

2. 电影业依赖于技术的变化，并对技术的变化做出快速反应。在习惯了当代好莱坞电影后，我们大多数人发现我们对无声电影或黑白电影的反应有所不同——这是制作这些电影的早期技术如何决定我们如何观看它们的明显例子。许多其他行业工具——各种声音技术、色彩库存或特效——同样可以成为揭示性分析的起点。无论一部电影是为大屏幕制作还是为电视屏幕制作，都可以很大程度上说明故事的内容（请注意，像《十诫》 [1956]这样的史诗电影在电视上看起来并不一样）。正如一些评论家所说，《黑客帝国》（1999）中使用的计算机技术可能是该电影最有趣的话题。如果您对技术感兴趣，请准备好记下可能依赖于技术的电影特征及其故事。导演是否特别使用黑白胶片？为什么？声音技术似乎在电影中发挥了很大作用吗？相机的移动（或不移动）是否与所使用的相机类型有关（例如法国新浪潮的手持相机，传达了一种现场现实感）？特别是近年来，所谓的“数字融合”对电影行业的影响越来越大：越来越多的电影用数码相机拍摄；越来越多的电影采用数码相机拍摄。现在大多数电影都是用数字非线性编辑程序进行编辑的（见第68-69页）；计算机生成的图像使电影制作者不仅可以添加记录现实的形状和颜色，还可以创造全新的现实；最后，电影通过互联网和手持设备的发行和放映有望极大地改变我们观看和理解电影的方式。问问自己，在某些电影中到底如何体现这一最新的技术革命。数字化是否改变了电影角色的描绘方式？故事是如何构建的？什么看起来现实或不现实？追寻这些和其他最初的问题通常需要一些后续的研究和思考才能得到充分的回答，并与电影的分析相关联。然而，最初对电影的工业和技术方面有一些兴趣的学生，如果他或她在电影中寻找技术在电影中扮演的角色，通常会找到很好的材料来写一篇强有力的论文。

2. The film industry depends on and responds quickly to changes in technology. Having grown used to contemporary Hollywood movies, most of us find that we react differently to a silent movie or to one in black and white—an obvious example of how the early technology that produced these movies determines how we view them. Many other tools of the trade—various sound technologies, color stocks, or special effects—can likewise become the starting point for a revealing analysis. Whether a movie is made for a large screen or for a television screen can say a great deal about the story (note how epic movies like The Ten Commandments [1956] just don’t seem the same on television). As some commentators have suggested, the computer technology used in The Matrix (1999) may be the most interesting topic concerning that movie. If you are interested in technology, prepare to note features of the movie and its story that might depend on technology. Does the director make special use of black-and-white film stocks? Why? Does sound technology seem to play a large part in the movie? Is the movement (or lack of movement) of the camera related to the kind of camera used (like the handheld cameras of the French New Wave, which conveyed a sense of on-the-spot realism)? Especially in recent years, what is known as “digital convergence” has had an increasing impact on the film industry: More and more films are shot with digital cameras; the majority of movies are now edited with digital nonlinear editing programs (see pp. 68–69); computer-generated images have allowed filmmakers to not only add to the shape and colors of recorded realities, but also to create entirely new realities; and, finally, the distribution and exhibition of movies across the Internet and through handheld devices promises to change dramatically the way we see and understand films. Ask yourself how exactly this latest technological revolution can be seen in certain movies. Has digitalization altered how film characters are portrayed? How stories are constructed? What seems realistic or not? Pursuing these and other initial questions will usually require some later research and thinking to be answered adequately and to become related to an analysis of the movie. The student with some initial interest in the industrial and technological side of the movies, however, will often find good material for a strong essay if he or she approaches movies on the lookout for the role technology plays in them.

3. 电影技术、制作和发行是商业经济企业。在观看任何电影时记住这一点至关重要。例如，如果观众要在当地的艺术影院观看一部低成本的独立电影（例如迈克尔·斯诺的《波长》 [1967]），那么对该电影的期望将会（而且应该）与对光鲜亮丽的电影的期望有所不同。预算超亿美元的大片（如雷德利·斯科特的《罗宾汉》 [2010]）在展示电影院。没有一部电影因其商业或经济限制和自由而必然好坏，但调整期望的能力确实可以让观众更准确地评估电影的成败。因此，对于一些来自南美洲或非洲的电影来说，粗糙和未经雕琢的外观不仅是财政拮据不可避免的副产品，而且在某些情况下也是一种有意识的政治标志，用于将它们与好莱坞光鲜亮丽的产品区分开来。经济规模的另一端是好莱坞的大规模制作，其庞大的预算意味着它们必须吸引尽可能多的观众，因此必须承担很少的可能疏远部分观众的风险。虽然这种对电影的角度如果要发展成一篇文章，需要进行一些研究，但对任何电影背后的经济和商业决定因素的认识或敏感性可以帮助你对电影中的图像做出更明智和更复杂的反应。屏幕。保持开放的态度和怀疑的态度：如果它看起来像是一部低成本制作的电影，那么成本的降低是否允许它做和说一些大预算电影可能无法做到的事情？相反，一些好莱坞电影如何利用大预算或创造性地利用小预算？大部分资金流向何处？星星？特效？促销？为什么？这部电影看起来特别朴实或商业化，还是试图在两者之间达成妥协？为什么？这部电影的目标观众是谁？青少年？中产阶级？知识分子？男人？女性？

3. Film technology, production, and distribution are commercial and economic enterprises. It is crucial to keep this in mind when approaching any movie. If, for instance, a viewer is going to see a low-budget independent film (such as Michael Snow’s Wavelength [1967]) at the local art house, the expectations about that movie will—and should—be different from those about a glossy blockbuster with a budget over $100 million (such as Ridley Scott’s Robin Hood [2010]) at a showcase cinema. No film is necessarily good or bad because of its commercial or economic constraints and freedoms, but the ability to adjust one’s expectations does allow a viewer to more accurately assess the achievements or failures of a movie. Thus, for some films from South America or Africa, the often rough and unpolished look is not only an unavoidable by-product of financial constraints but, in some cases, also a conscious political sign used to distinguish them from the glossy products of Hollywood. At the other end of the economic scale are the massive Hollywood productions, with gargantuan budgets that mean they must capture the largest possible audience and so must take very few risks that might alienate part of that audience. Although this sort of angle on a movie will require some research if it is to develop into an essay, an awareness of or sensitivity to the economic and commercial determinants behind any movie can prepare you for a more intelligent and complex response to the images on the screen. Be open-minded and suspicious: If it looks like a movie that was made inexpensively, does this reduced cost allow it to do and say things that a big-budget movie might not be able to? Conversely, how do some Hollywood movies take advantage of a big budget or make creative use of a small budget? Where is much of the money directed? The stars? The special effects? The promotion?
