尽管大多数优秀的电影都赋予场景及其物体与人物几乎同样的意义，但电影在如何利用与人物和故事相关的场景方面存在很大差异。场景和背景可能暗示着一种历史现实主义，如《父辈的旗帜》（2006）（图3.06）；提供人物思想的图像，如卡里加里博士的内阁；描述电影的中心主题，以及电影的中心地位《Meet Me in St. Louis》（1944 年）中的房子/家；或者变得像故事或人物本身一样复杂和重要，就像《杜鲁门的世界》 （1998）一样，其中主角（金凯瑞）发现他的生活是一部电视节目，他在电视上生活和工作设置（图3.07）。然而，在写背景时，我们必须做的不仅仅是描述它：我们必须寻求发现它与电影的主要主题或电影的其他方面（其生产系统或历史时期，例如实例）。这样的关注将有助于解释为什么场景及其构建方式很重要。

Although most good films give the setting and its objects nearly as much meaning as the characters, films differ greatly in how they use their settings in relation to characters and stories. Sets and settings may suggest a historical realism, as in Flags of Our Fathers (2006) (Figure 3.06); provide images of a character’s mind, as in The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari; describe the central theme of the film, as does the centrality of the house/home in Meet Me in St. Louis (1944); or become as complex and important as the story or characters themselves, as, perhaps, in The Truman Show (1998), in which the main character (Jim Carrey) discovers that his life is a television show and that he lives and works on television set (Figure 3.07). In writing about setting, however, one must do more than just describe it: One must seek to discover its significance in relation to the major themes of the film or to other aspects of the film (its system of production or its historical period, for instance). Such a focus will help explain why the setting and the way it is constructed are important.

图3.06 克林特·伊斯特伍德的《父亲的旗帜》（2006）是一部关于二战的当代电影，依靠高度的历史现实主义使其场景布置准确而令人信服。

Figure 3.06 Clint Eastwood’s Flags of Our Father (2006) is a contemporary film about World War II that relies on a high degree of historical realism to make its mise-en-scène accurate and convincing.

 

在讨论场景调度的其他元素时使用相同的经验法则。无论您的兴趣是表演风格、服装还是灯光，精确的描述都必须与它们为何重要以及它们如何增加电影的意义相结合——也就是说，它们如何成为分析主题的一部分。我们都知道演员是在电影中扮演角色的个人。但表演风格——演员如何扮演一个角色——在不同的电影和不同的十年之间有很大的不同。如果深思熟虑的话，表演风格是一个具有挑战性的话题，或者是集中分析特定对象的目标。电影。例如，作家可以将意大利新现实主义电影《偷自行车的人》（1948）中的表演风格与英国或英国电影的矫揉造作的风格进行比较，其中一些演员是因为没有表演经验而被选出来的。像玛吉·史密斯这样的美国演员，她对现实表演的理解包括大量经过深思熟虑的技巧。丹麦导演卡尔·德雷尔说：“在摄影棚里，没有比亲眼目睹一张敏感的面孔在神秘的灵感力量下的表情更美妙的体验了”，而他在著名的电影《雷妮·法尔科内蒂》中向蕾妮·法尔科内蒂请来的正是这种表演。他的《圣女贞德受难记》（1928）的特写镜头。在下面的段落中，詹姆斯·纳雷莫尔以堪称典范的细节感描述了《喜剧之王》（1982）中桑德拉·伯恩哈德饰演玛莎的非凡表演风格：

Use the same rule of thumb in discussing other elements of the mise-en-scène. Whether your interest is acting styles, costumes, or lighting, precise description must be coupled with a sense of why they are important and how they add to the meaning of the movie—that is, how they can become part of a topic for analysis. We all know that an actor is the individual who plays the part of a character in a movie. But acting style—how an actor plays a part—differs considerably from film to film and from one decade to the next. When looked at thoughtfully, acting style is a challenging topic to address or a target for focusing an analysis of a specific movie. A writer might, for instance, compare the acting style in an Italian neorealist movie such as The Bicycle Thieves (1948), in which some of the actors were people chosen precisely because they had no acting experience, with the mannered style of a British or American actor, like Maggie Smith, whose notion of a realistic performance includes a great deal of studied artifice. The Danish director Carl Dreyer said, “There is no greater experience in a studio than to witness the expression of a sensitive face under the mysterious power of inspiration,” and it is precisely that kind of performance that he solicited from Renée Falconetti in the famous close-ups of his The Passion of Joan of Arc (1928). In the following paragraph, James Naremore describes, with exemplary sense of details, the remarkable acting style of Sandra Bernhard as Marsha in The King of Comedy (1982):

图 3.07 在《喜剧之王》（1982 年）中，桑德拉·伯恩哈德 (Sandra Bernhard) 饰演的玛莎 (Marsha) 戏剧化地展现了演员及其风格如何使身体和手势成为场景中动态的一部分。

Figure 3.07 In King of Comedy (1982), Sandra Bernhard’s performance as Marsha dramatizes how actors and their styles can make bodies and gestures a dynamic part of a the mise-en-scène.

 

伯恩哈德实际上是一名俱乐部喜剧演员，在很多方面她都依赖于小丑的传统手段。她缺乏方达或斯特里普等“严肃”演员的对称面孔，因此她将自己的五官推向怪诞的极端——伸出嘴唇或将嘴唇卷曲在长鼻子上，皱着眉头或让下巴松弛。当她移动时，她的角度各不相同，是一个身材瘦长的简笔人物，看起来就像一个厌食症的短发女郎；当她说话时，她的音调就达到了纽约青少年的语调歇斯底里的边缘。尽管如此，她夸张的行为方式与范妮·布莱斯或玛莎·雷等老式滑稽人物截然不同。她的喜剧是一部神经症的喜剧，混合着焦虑和欢笑，她的表现就好像俄狄浦斯情节的全部重担都落在了她的肩上。(282)

Bernhard is in fact a club comic, and in many ways she relies on the conventional devices of clowns. She lacks the symmetrical face of “serious” actors like Fonda or Streep, so she pushes her features into grotesque extremes—poking out her lips or curling them up against her long nose, frowning or letting her jaw hang lax. When she moves, she is all angles, a gangling stick figure who looks like an anorexic bobbysoxer; when she speaks, her voice pitches up to the register of a New York teenager on the verge of hysteria. Nevertheless she inflects her exaggerated behavior in ways quite different from old-fashioned zanies like Fanny Brice or Martha Raye. Hers is a comedy of neurosis, a mingling of anxiety and laughter, and she behaves as if the whole weight of an Oedipal scenario were on her shoulders. (282)

 

众所周知，服装就是人物所穿的衣服。与场景布置的其他方面一样，它们的范围也从现实到奢华不等。通常，它们为作家提供了了解角色身份的关键。詹姆斯·邦德经常穿燕尾服，但西尔维斯特·史泰龙饰演的洛基则喜欢穿得尽可能少。在这两种情况下，我们都从服装中了解了一些关于角色的信息。有些电影，如《Tootsie》（1982）和《海德薇与愤怒的英寸》（Hedwig and the Angry Inch，2001），主要是关于服装和通过服饰和化妆改变外表，这两部电影都是关于男人如何穿得像女人，以面对或处理关于性角色的传统态度。白帽子不再一定代表良好的性格，但你应该继续质疑为什么角色的外表和穿着是这样的。他们的服装是否暗示了他们如何看待自己，或者他们希望别人如何看待他们？角色是否会改变服装，就像在《周末夜狂热》（1977）中那样，约翰·特拉沃尔塔在晚上穿上舞衣，变成了另一个人？这些变化是否能告诉你有关个性或社会的任何信息？服装是否有一个特殊特征，例如《大逃亡》（1962 年）中史蒂夫·麦奎因的棒球手套，可以帮助您分析该角色？再次强调，不要认为场景的服装是理所当然的。

Costumes, as we all know, are the clothes the characters wear. Like other aspects of the mise-en-scène, they vary along a spectrum from realistic to extravagant; often, they provide a writer with the key to a character’s identity. James Bond often wears a tuxedo, but Sylvester Stallone’s Rocky prefers to wear as little as possible. In both cases, we learn something about the character from the costume. Some films, like Tootsie (1982) and Hedwig and the Angry Inch (2001), are largely about costuming and changing appearances through dress and makeup, and both films are about how men dress like women to confront or deal with conventional attitudes about sexual roles. White hats no longer necessarily indicate a good character, but you should continue to question why characters look and dress the way they do. Do their costumes suggest how they view themselves, or how they wish to be viewed by others? Does a character change clothing, as in Saturday Night Fever (1977), when John Travolta becomes a different person by donning his dancing clothes at night? Do those changes tell you anything about the personality or the society? Is there a special feature of a costume, such as the baseball glove that identifies Steve McQueen in The Great Escape (1962), that helps you analyze that character? Again, do not take the costumes of the mise-en-scène for granted.

照明描述了人物、物体或场景被自然阳光或人造光源（例如灯）照亮的各种方式。它允许电影制片人以某种方式引导观众的注意力或营造某种氛围。我们都认识到很大的区别，例如西部片中户外场景的明亮灯光与黑帮电影中小巷中阴暗的黑暗之间的区别。我们可能注意到，在第一种情况下，灯光营造出一种清晰和乐观的感觉，而在第二种情况下，灯光营造出一种压抑和阴郁的感觉。一项更艰巨的任务是记录和评论更微妙的照明渐变和模式，这些照明本身不会引起人们的注意。例如，在伯特兰·塔维尼尔 (Bertrand Tavernier) 的《乡村星期天》(Sunday in the Country )（1984 年）中，柔和的室内和室外灯光似乎再现了印象派绘画中的灯光，或者更准确地说，再现了 1930 年代让·雷诺阿 (Jean Renoir) 电影中的氛围灯光，从而复活了一种视觉效果。那部电影中画家祖父所知道的世界正在消失。在斯坦利·库布里克 (Stanley Kubrick) 的《巴里·林登》( Barry Lyndon，1978) 中，一些场景使用了非常低的光线（事实上是烛光）来强调人物怪异孤立的面孔，他们彼此隔绝，也与周围黑暗中的世界隔绝。无论您是否立即注意到灯光，都要准备好寻找光和阴影的图案。是否有为了突出电影中的一个场景或一组场景而创建的重要图形模式（例如锐利的阴影）？灯光或色彩看起来完全自然还是异常人造？一些实验电影使电影的整个主题成为对光的艺术操纵，但任何智能叙事电影都像绘画一样使用灯光，了解其可能性和目的（图3.08）。

Lighting describes the various ways a character or an object or a scene can be illuminated, either by natural sunlight or from artificial sources (such as lamps). It allows a filmmaker to direct a viewer’s attention in a certain way or to create a certain atmosphere. We all recognize large distinctions, such as the difference between the bright lighting of an outdoor scene in a western and the shadowy darkness used in the alleyways of a gangster film. We probably notice that, in the first case, the lighting creates a feeling of clarity and optimism, and in the second, a feeling of oppression and gloom. A more demanding task would be to note and comment on the more subtle gradations and patterns of lighting that do not dramatically call attention to themselves. In Bertrand Tavernier’s Sunday in the Country (1984), for instance, the softly lit interiors and exteriors seem to recreate the lighting found in impressionist paintings or, more exactly, the atmospheric lighting found in the 1930s cinema of Jean Renoir, thus resurrecting a vision of the world that the painter grandfather in that movie knows is fading. In Stanley Kubrick’s Barry Lyndon (1978), some scenes use very low light (candlelight, in fact) to emphasize the grotesquely isolated faces of characters who are cut off from one another and from the world that exists in the darkness around them. Whether you notice the lighting immediately or not, be prepared to look for patterns of light and shadows. Are there important graphic patterns (such as sharp shadows), created to highlight a scene or a group of scenes in a movie? Does the lighting or coloring seem totally natural or unusually artificial? Some experimental films make the entire subject of the film the artistic manipulation of light, but any intelligent narrative movie uses lighting with as much a sense of its possibilities and purpose as a painting does (Figure 3.08).

那么，场景调度是关于空间的戏剧性的，因为该空间是为摄像机构建的。这种对空间的利用——空间的布置方式以及演员和物体在其中的关系——可以产生令人兴奋的电影话题和评论。场面调度中人物或不同平面之间的平衡或不平衡有时比对话更能说明这一动作：例如，一个角色是否总是位于另一个角色之上？人总是活在阴影里吗？同样，在比较电影中的两个场景或场景时，您可能会发现原本不会被注意到的重要主题：例如，灾难只发生在城市中，还是只发生在陆地上？电影的场面调度与戏剧的场面调度不同，但同样复杂，而作家则关于电影应该追求与巴斯特·基顿的《我们的款待》（1923）中的场景调度（特别是背景）分析中所展示的同样的敏锐性和微妙性：

Mise-en-scène, then, is about the theatrics of space as that space is constructed for the camera. This use of space—how it is arranged and how the actors and objects relate within it—can generate exciting topics and commentary on film. The balance or imbalance that relates figures or various planes in the mise-en-scène sometimes says more about that action than does the dialogue: Is, for instance, one character always positioned above another? Is one always in shadows? Likewise, in comparing two sets or settings in a film, you may discover important themes that would otherwise not be noticed: Do catastrophes, for instance, occur only in the city, or only on land? A cinematic mise-en-scène is different from but as complex as a theatrical mise-en-scène, and a writer about film should aim for the same acuteness and subtlety demonstrated in the following analysis of the mise-en-scène (specifically the setting) in Buster Keaton’s Our Hospitality (1923):

图 3.08 在《第三类接触》（1977 年）中，壮观的灯光技术和图形是电影的核心。

Figure 3.08 In Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), spectacular lighting techniques and graphics are the heart of the movie.

 

场景调度的作用不是在孤立的时刻，而是与整个电影的叙事系统相关。像巴斯特·基顿的大多数电影一样，《我们的款待》体现了场景调度如何经济地推进叙事并创造一种主题模式。而由于这部电影是一部喜剧，我们会发现场景布景也产生了笑点。那么，我们的热情好客体现了我们在研究每一种电影技术时将会发现的东西：一个单独的元素几乎总是具有多种功能，而不仅仅是一种功能。

Mise-en-scène functions, not in isolated moments, but in relation to the narrative system of the entire film. Our Hospitality, like most of Buster Keaton’s films, exemplifies how mise-en-scène can economically advance the narrative and create a pattern of motifs. And since the film is a comedy, we shall find that the mise-en-scène also creates gags. Our Hospitality, then, exemplifies what we shall find in our study of every film technique: an individual element will almost always have several functions, not just one.

 

例如，考虑一下背景如何在《我们的款待》的叙述中发挥作用。它们有助于将电影划分为多个场景并对比这些场景。影片以序言开头，展示了麦凯家族和坎菲尔德家族之间的不和如何导致年轻的坎菲尔德和麦凯家族的丈夫的死亡。我们看到麦凯一家住在一间小屋里，并对婴儿威利的命运充满悬念。威利的母亲带着她的儿子从南方的家逃到北方（主要通过字幕向我们讲述这一行动）。主要故事发生在几年后，长大后的威利住在纽约。有许多关于十九世纪早期大都市生活的笑点，与序幕场景形成鲜明对比。我们不禁想知道这个地方与南方的景色有何关系，很快威利就收到消息说他继承了父母在南方的家。当他乘坐原始火车返回他的出生地时，发生了一系列有趣的短场景。在这里，基顿使用了真实的风景，但通过以不同的方式铺设铁轨，他利用风景产生了令人惊讶和不寻常的喜剧效果。影片的其余部分讲述了威利在南部城镇及附近地区的活动。抵达当天，他到处闲逛，陷入了许多滑稽的场景。那天晚上，他住在坎菲尔德的房子里，因为好客法则使它成为他唯一安全的地方。最后，第二天发生了一场长时间的追逐，穿过乡村，回到坎菲尔德的房子，以结束世仇。因此，故事的情节在很大程度上取决于背景的转变，这些转变确立了威利作为婴儿和成年后的两次旅程，以及后来他四处游荡以逃避敌人的追捕。一旦威利到达南方，叙述就相对不受限制，在他和坎菲尔德家族成员之间穿梭。我们通常比威利更了解他们在哪里，而且故事通过展示他们走向威利藏身的地方而产生悬念。

Consider, for example, how the settings function within the narrative of Our Hospitality. They help divide the film into scenes and contrast those scenes. The film begins with a prologue showing how the feud between the McKays and the Canfields results in the deaths of the young Canfield and the husband of the McKay family. We see the McKays living in a shack and are left in suspense about the fate of the baby, Willie. Willie’s mother flees with her son from their southern home to the North (action narrated to us mainly by an intertitle). The main action begins years later, with the grown-up Willie living in New York. There are a number of gags concerning early nineteenth-century life in the metropolis, contrasting sharply with the prologue scene. We are led to wonder how this locale will relate to the southern scenes, and soon Willie receives word that he has inherited his parents’ home in the South. A series of amusing short scenes follows as he takes a primitive train back to his birthplace. Here Keaton uses real landscapes, but by laying the railroad tracks in different ways, he exploits the landscapes for surprising and unusual comic effects. The rest of the film deals with Willie’s movements in the southern town and in the vicinity. On the day of his arrival he wanders around and gets into a number of comic situations. That night he stays in the Canfield house itself, since the law of hospitality has made it the only safe place for him. And, finally, an extended chase occurs the next day, moving through the countryside and back to the Canfield house for the end of the feud. Thus the action depends heavily on shifts of setting that establish Willie’s two journeys, as baby and as man, and later his wanderings around to escape his enemies’ pursuit. The narration is relatively unrestricted once Willie reaches the South, moving between him and members of the Canfield family. We usually know more about where they are than Willie does, and the narrative generates suspense by showing them coming toward the places where Willie is hiding.

 

特定的场景实现了不同的叙事功能。威利想象中的麦凯“庄园”是一座豪宅，结果却是一座破旧的棚屋。麦凯庄园与坎菲尔德家族富丽堂皇的种植园住宅平行（形成鲜明对比）。从叙述的角度来看，当坎菲尔德的父亲禁止他的儿子们在家里杀死威利时，坎菲尔德的家就变得更加重要：“我们的荣誉准则禁止我们在他作为我们家的客人时射杀他。” （威利无意中听到这件事后，他决定永远不会离开。）因此，具有讽刺意味的是，威利敌人的家成为镇上唯一的安全点，许多场景都是围绕坎菲尔德兄弟试图引诱威利而展开的。在影片的结尾，另一个场景变得有意义：坎菲尔德一家追赶威利的草地、山脉、河岸、急流和瀑布。最后，这场不和最终回到了坎菲尔德的房子里，威利现在作为女儿的丈夫受到欢迎。故事的发展模式很清晰：从麦凯家的开场枪战打散了威利的家，到坎菲尔德家的最后一幕，威利成为了新家庭的一员。通过这种方式，每个场景都受到因果、平行和对比以及整体发展的叙事系统的高度推动。（波德韦尔和汤普森 142-43）

Specific settings fulfill distinct narrative functions. The McKay “estate,” which Willie envisions as a mansion, turns out to be a tumbledown shack. The McKay place is paralleled to (contrasted with) the Canfields’ palatial plantation home. In narrative terms the Canfield home gains even more functional importance when the Canfield father forbids his sons to kill Willie on the premises: “our code of honor forbids us to shoot him while he is a guest in our house.” (Once Willie overhears this, he determines never to leave.) Thus, ironically, the home of Willie’s enemies becomes the only safe spot in town, and many scenes are organized around the Canfield brothers’ attempts to lure Willie out. At the end of the film another setting takes on significance: the meadows, mountains, river banks, rapids, and waterfalls across which the Canfields pursue Willie. Finally, the feud ends back in the Canfield house itself, with Willie now welcomed as the daughter’s husband. The pattern of development is clear: from the opening shoot-out at the McKay house that breaks up Willie’s home, to the final scene in the Canfield house with Willie becoming part of a new family. In such ways every setting becomes highly motivated by the narrative’s system of causes and effects, parallels and contrasts, and overall development. (Bordwell and Thompson 142–43)

 

构图和图像

COMPOSITION AND THE IMAGE

 

在任何电影中，最终拍摄场景的都是摄像机：当您观看电影时，您不仅会看到布景、演员和灯光，还会看到所有这些被记录和投影的元素。通过电影形象来构建场景是电影与戏剧的区别，也是一个优秀作家应该能够讨论的电影的另一个重要维度。当您观看家庭视频时，您可能首先会认出您和您的朋友参加的聚会。然而，仔细观察后，您可能还会评论这些图像如何由于角度或颜色而使其中一些朋友看起来比实际身高更高或更黑。同样，电影图像可能会影响您观看场景或场景中角色的方式。以“场景中有三个角色......”开头的学生似乎不如以“场景中的视角使三个人物出现......”开头的学生那么专心和洞察力。本节考虑了一些您可以用来讨论这些组合特征的术语。

In any movie, it is the camera that eventually films a mise-en-scène: When you watch a movie, you see not only the setting, actors, and lighting, but all these elements as they are recorded and then projected. The composition of a scene through the film image is what distinguishes film from drama, and it is another important dimension of the movies that a good writer should be able to discuss. When you watch a home video, you might first recognize a party with you and your friends. However, with a closer look, you might also comment on how the images, because of the angles or coloring, make some of those friends look taller or darker than they really are. In the same way, a film image may influence the way you see a scene or a character in that scene. The student who begins by writing, “The scene had three characters ...” will seem less attentive and perceptive than the student who begins, “The visual angle on the scene made the three characters appear...” This section considers some of the terminology you can use to discuss these compositional features.

镜头

The Shot

镜头是在胶片切换到不同图像之前您在屏幕上看到的单个图像。与照片不同，单个镜头可以包含各种动作或运动，并且包含图像的帧甚至可以移动。一张照片可能会显示酒吧里的牛仔，然后通过将相机移近来放大该人物。当图像切换到牛仔的另一个位置和视角时（例如，从酒吧的另一侧），影片已切换到第二个镜头。在撰写有关电影的文章时，您应该对镜头的两个主要维度敏感：

The shot is the single image you see on the screen before the film cuts to a different image. Unlike a photograph, a single shot can include a variety of action or movement, and the frame that contains the image may even move. One shot may show a cowboy at a bar and then magnify the figure by moving the camera closer. When the image switches to another position and point of view on the cowboy—say, from the opposite side of the bar—the film has cut to a second shot. In writing about film, you should be sensitive to the two primary dimensions of the shot:

  • 它的照相特性
  • its photographic properties
  • 它的移动框架
  • its moving frame

镜头的摄影特性是指任何照片中的胶片图像的质量，加上拍摄场景的速度。这些属性包括色调、胶片速度以及图像创建的各种视角。色调是指电影图像中颜色的范围和纹理。《绿野仙踪》 （1939）等电影使用充满红色和黄色的特艺色彩方案来暗示一个与黑白堪萨斯截然不同的奇幻世界。有些电影，例如乔治·克鲁尼的《晚安，好运》 (2005)，使用黑白色调来暗示较古老的电影类型或过去的历史时期，就像克鲁尼在有关爱德华·默罗的黑白电影中所做的那样20世纪50年代的电视广播。伍迪·艾伦在《Zelig》（1983）中故意用颗粒状的黑白色调讲述了一个故事，使他的现代电影的某些部分看起来像一部古老的纪录片，而在《辛德勒的名单》中，史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格偶尔会用黑白的方式打断一个可怕的故事。瞥见了孩子鲜红色的外套。询问颜色是否真实。如果没有，为什么不呢？电影使用特定颜色或颜色组的方式是否存在某种模式？这部电影是否象征性地使用了颜色，就像英格玛·伯格曼在《呼喊与细语》（1972）中使用红色来暗示暴力和激情一样？如果电影是黑白的，那么黑白如何添加到电影中，特别是如果电影制作人可以使用彩色？颜色和色调与电影主题有何关系？

The photographic properties of a shot are the qualities of the film image that are found in any photograph, plus the speed at which the scene is filmed. These properties include tone, film speed, and the various perspectives created by the image. Tone refers to the range and texture of the colors in a film image. A movie such as The Wizard of Oz (1939) uses a Technicolor scheme full of primary reds and yellows to suggest a fantasy world very different from the black-and-white Kansas. Some films, such as George Clooney’s Goodnight, and Good Luck (2005), use black-and-white tones to suggest an older movie genre or past historical period, as Clooney does in his film about Edward R. Murrow’s black-and-white television broadcasts of the 1950s. Woody Allen in Zelig (1983) tells a story with intentionally grainy black-and-white tones to make parts of his modern movie look like an old documentary, and in Schindler’s List, Steven Spielberg occasionally disrupts a horrific story in black and white with the fleeting glimpse of a child’s bright red coat. Ask if the colors are realistic. If not, why not? Is there a pattern in the way a film uses a particular color or group of colors? Does the film use colors symbolically, as Ingmar Bergman uses red in Cries and Whispers (1972) to suggest both violence and passion? If the movie is in black and white, how does the black and white add to the movie, especially if the filmmaker could have used color? How do the colors and tones relate to the themes of the film?

胶片速度是指拍摄胶片的速率；这在慢动作或快动作的情况下最为明显。慢动作或快动作通常表明正在发生的事情的性质发生了变化，或者观众应该如何看待正在发生的事情。有时，慢动作用于表明该动作是角色梦境的一部分；有时，快速动作是对场景进行滑稽评论的一种方式，例如，当装配线上的动作突然以超人的速度移动时。当胶片速度不再正常时很容易注意到；准备好研究为什么电影制片人会挑选这些时刻。在大岛渚的《圣诞快乐，劳伦斯先生》（1982）中，大卫·鲍伊用慢动作拍摄的两个吻面对他的日本对手；很明显，这是大岛强调的方式他们的关系达到了令人震惊的高潮。但请记住，许多较老的无声电影是以每秒 16 帧的速率拍摄和打印的，当以每秒 24 帧的现代标准放映时，它们的动作可能看起来更快。

Film speed is the rate at which the film is shot; it is most obvious in instances of slow or fast motion. Action in slow or fast motion usually indicates a change in the nature of what is happening or how the audience is supposed to perceive what is happening. Sometimes, slow motion is used to indicate that the action is part of a character’s dream; sometimes, fast motion is a way of commenting comically on a scene—when, for instance, action on an assembly line suddenly moves at superhuman speed. It is easy to note when the speed of the film is no longer normal; be prepared to examine why these moments are singled out by the filmmaker. In Nagisa Oshima’s Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (1982), David Bowie confronts his Japanese adversary with two kisses that are filmed in slow motion; it is clear that this is Oshima’s way of underlining this shattering climax in their relationship. Keep in mind, however, that many older silent movies were filmed and printed at the rate of sixteen frames per second, and their action may look faster when shown at the modern standard of twenty-four frames per second.

图像的透视是指图像在其拍摄的不同物体和人物之间建立的空间关系。这些不同的关系是不同种类的镜头以及这些镜头的使用方式的产物。因此，一部电影可能会不断呈现具有很大深度或深焦点的场景，以便观众可以像看到前景中的人物一样清晰地看到背景中的人物。另一部电影（通常是较老的电影）可能希望仅隔离或突出显示图像中的某些角色或事件，因此它使用浅焦点，仅清晰地显示图像中的一个平面，例如持枪站立的人前景中除了背景中模糊的人群之外。不太常见的是机架对焦的奇怪时刻，即在同一镜头内焦点快速从一个人物或物体转移或拉到另一个人物或物体时，就像图像从一个对着钢琴说话的男人的脸切换焦点时一样在背景中从窗户掉下来。

The perspective of the image refers to the kind of spatial relationship an image establishes between the different objects and figures it is photographing. These different relationships are the products of different kinds of lenses and the way those lenses are used. Thus one movie may constantly present scenes with a great deal of depth or deep focus so that the audience can see characters in the background as sharply as it sees characters in the foreground. Another movie (often an older one) may wish to isolate or highlight only certain characters or events in the image, and it consequently uses a shallow focus that will clearly show only one plane in the image, such as the man with a gun who stands in the foreground apart from the blurry crowd in the background. Much less commonly seen is the odd moment of rack focus, when the focus is quickly changed, or pulled, from one figure or object to another within the same shot, as when the image switches focus from the face of a man talking to a piano falling out the window in the background.

还有其他类型的透视关系可用于创建图像，但即使您正在学习这些其他技术术语，您也可以通过询问一些基本问题来开始分析透视关系：图像中的焦点是谁或什么，以及为什么？这些图像是否创造了一个有深度的世界，或者这个世界看起来异常平坦？您如何描述特定图像中的空间？拥挤吗？打开？宽的？扭曲了？当特定的宽银幕图像将人物淹没在太空中时，这对他们和他们的世界意味着什么？让图像本身的力量在你的写作中生动起来。让你的文章主题不仅仅是你所看到的东西，还包括图像如何让你以某种方式看待人和事物以及彼此之间的某种关系。下面是一个例子，学生在 Nicolas Roeg 的《Don't Look Now》（1973 年）中简要了解了颜色、色调和空间关系：

Still other kinds of perspective relationships can be used in creating an image, but even while you are learning these other technical terms, you can begin to analyze perspective relationships by asking some basic questions: Who or what is in focus in an image, and why? Do the images create a world with depth, or does that world seem unusually flat? How would you describe the space in a particular image? Is it crowded? Open? Wide? Distorted? When a specific wide-screen image drowns the characters in space, what does this say about them and their world? Make the power of the image itself come alive in your writing. Make the subject of your essays not just what you see, but also how the image makes you see people and things in a certain way and in a certain relationship to one another. Here is an example in which the student briefly looks at color, tone, and spatial relations in Nicolas Roeg’s Don’t Look Now (1973):

N·辛格潘兹

N. Singerpanz

 

《现在别看》（1973）是一部关于不想看到红色但又无法不看到红色的电影。这个故事讲述了一对夫妇的小女儿不幸溺水身亡。后来，他们去了威尼斯，他在那里从事修复一座正在慢慢下沉的旧教堂的工作。他们都想忘记他们的可怕死亡女儿，但在威尼斯，他们——还有我们这些惊恐的观众——都被一种颜色所追逐，那就是女儿去世时所穿的雨衣的鲜红光芒。

Don’t Look Now (1973) is a movie about not wanting to see red but being unable not to see red. The story concerns a man and a woman whose young daughter dies tragically by drowning. Later, they go to Venice, where he has a job restoring an old church that is slowly sinking. They both want to forget the horrible death of their daughter, but in Venice, they—and we, the frightened viewers—are pursued by a color, the bright red glow of the raincoat the daughter was wearing when she died.

 

甚至在她去世之前，这种色彩就从电影中跃出。当父亲正在研究他要修复的教堂的幻灯片时，图像中红色的色调和纹理开始振动，然后像血液一样渗出。仿佛这是一种预感，他冲到外面，发现自己的孩子脸朝下躺在池塘里，她的外套颜色与幻灯片中的红色相同。

Even before her death the color leaps out of the film. While the father is studying slides of the church he will repair, the tone and texture of the red in the image begin to vibrate and then ooze like blood. As if it is a premonition, he dashes outside to find his child face down in a pond, her coat the same color as the red in the slide.

 

威尼斯在这部电影中是一座相当灰色的城市，但无论父亲走到哪里，明亮的红色似乎都会吸引他的目光，仿佛它有自己的生命，或者正在从另一个世界召唤。在一秒钟或更长时间里，彩色玻璃窗、衣服或一辆驶过的汽车似乎都带有红色的阴影，我们和他已经将这种红色视为死去的女儿。红色是一种常见的颜色，如果是一种令人震惊的颜色，只会增加神秘和混乱，因为这种简单的颜色变得越来越催眠和可怕。它似乎与威尼斯普通的灰色生活形成鲜明对比，而且，由于城市狭窄、多风的街道使视觉空间变得如此幽闭恐怖，我们和父亲在背景中瞥见一个逃跑的红色人物成为了真实的时刻恐怖。

Venice is a rather gray city in this movie, but wherever the father turns the bright shade of red seems to catch his eye, as if it has a life of its own or is beckoning from another world. For a second or longer, stained-glass windows, pieces of clothing, or a passing car appear to bear the shade of red which we and he have come to identify with the dead daughter. That red is a common color, if a shocking one, only adds to the mystery and confusion as this simple color grows more and more hypnotic and frightening. It seems to contrast with the ordinary gray life of Venice, and, since visual space is made so claustrophobic by the narrow, windy streets of the city, the glimpses we and the father catch of a fleeing red figure in the background become moments of true terror.

 

这种颜色本身就成为一种生命，一种意味着死亡的生命。威尼斯的灰色和街道迷宫般的空间使这种颜色不容错过，而且更加迷人，因为它总是消失在深处。当我们和父亲最终把颜色逼到绝境时，最后一幕的震撼表明我们已经被罗伊格图像的力量所深深吸引。

This color becomes a life in itself, a life that comes to mean death. The grays of Venice and the mazelike spaces of its streets make this color impossible to miss and more fascinating because it is always vanishing into the depths. The shock of the final scene, when we and the father finally corner the color, suggests that we have been horribly seduced by the power of Roeg’s images.

 

电影图像的框架形成其边界并包含场景。许多电影，例如让·雷诺阿的《大幻觉》（1937 年）和阿尔弗雷德·希区柯克的《后窗》（1954 年），在场景布景中都充满了窗户、门口或舞台布景的内部框架，以引起人们的注意。故事框架和观点的重要性。然而，几乎每一部电影都必须对电影屏幕的框架和摄像机的框架保持一定的意识（图3.09）。宽银幕画面特别适合捕捉西部片中的开阔空间或科幻电影中广阔的星空。较小的标准框架也许最适合更个人化的室内戏剧或情节剧等类型，小框架可以带来从家庭舒适和亲密到幽闭恐惧症等任何感觉。在电影的拍摄过程中，还会有一些关于框架的其他更具体的问题需要询问：

The frame of the movie image forms its border and contains the mise-en-scène. Many movies, such as Jean Renoir’s Grand Illusion (1937) and Alfred Hitchcock’s Rear Window (1954), fill their mise-en-scène with the internal frames of windows or doorways or stage sets to call attention to the importance of frames and point of view in the story. Almost every film, though, must maintain a certain consciousness about the frame of the movie screen and the frame of the camera (Figure 3.09). A wide-screen frame is especially suited to catching the open spaces of a western or the vast stellar spaces of sci-fi films. The smaller standard frame is, perhaps, best suited to more personal interior dramas or genres like the melodrama, to which a small frame can contribute a sense of anything from domestic comfort and closeness to claustrophobia. Through the course of a film, there will be a number of other more particular questions to ask about the framing:

  • 摄像机画面代表动作的角度是多少？它会创建一个高角度（从上方观看主体）还是低角度（从下方观看动作）？当两个人的对话通过一组交替的高角度和低角度拍摄时，可能意味着一个角色很高，另一个角色很矮；也可以说两者之一是更占主导地位的人格。
  • What is the angle at which the camera frame represents the action? Does it create a high angle, viewing its subject from above, or a low angle, viewing the action from below? When a conversation between two people is shot through a group of alternating high angles and low angles, it could mean that one character is tall and the other is short; it could also say that one of the two is the more dominant personality.
  • 画面的高度是否符合镜头前人和物体的正常关系；也就是说，它们是否或多或少处于视线水平？或者相机似乎放置在在一个奇怪的高度，太高还是太低？例如，在《无因的反叛》 （1955）的开头，摄像机被放置在地面上，捕捉到詹姆斯·迪恩倒在地上时绝望而可怜地拥抱一个小玩具的情景。

    图 3.09 是什么让《驱魔人》（1973）中的这个镜头如此令人不安？

     
  • Does the height of the frame correspond to a normal relationship to the people and objects before the camera; that is, are they at eye level, more or less? Or does the camera seem to be placed at an odd height, too high or too low? At the beginning of Rebel without a Cause (1955), for instance, the camera is positioned at ground level to capture James Dean’s desperate and pathetic embrace of a small toy as he crumbles to the ground.

    Figure 3.09 What makes this shot from The Exorcist (1973) so disturbing?

     
  • 相机框架相对于空间和动作是否显得不平衡（称为倾斜框架）？如果是这样，为什么会出现这种情况？它是否重新创建了一个角色从一个奇怪的角度观察动作的视角，使建筑物呈现对角线而不是垂直的？它是为了重现一个醉汉的视角，还是可能是一种更微妙的评论方式，例如，对一个缺乏和谐与平衡的社区的评论？
  • Does the camera frame ever seem unbalanced in relation to the space and action (called a canted frame)? If so, why does this occur when it does? Is it recreating the perspective of a character looking at the action from an odd angle so that the buildings appear diagonal rather than vertical? Is it meant to recreate the perspective of a drunk, or might it be a more subtle way of commenting, for instance, on a community that lacks harmony and balance?
  • 画面与其拍摄对象保持什么样的距离？影片是否使用了很多特写镜头（例如，仅显示角色的脸部）、中景镜头（显示角色的大部分身体）或长镜头（从远处显示全身）？也许一个场景使用了一系列这样的镜头，从街上一个人的长镜头开始，然后显示他看着商店橱窗的中景镜头，最后以他看到某物时惊讶的脸的特写镜头结束在窗口中。这部电影是否开发了一种更复杂的组合，可以根据某种有意义的模式进行解释：例如，爱情场景的特写镜头和战斗场景的长镜头？
  • What kind of distance does the frame maintain from its subject? Does the film use many close-ups (for instance, showing just the characters’ faces), medium shots (showing most of a character’s body), or long shots (showing full bodies from a distance)? Perhaps a scene uses a series of these shots, beginning with a long shot of a man on the street, then showing a medium shot of him looking in a store window, and concluding with a close-up of his surprised face as he sees something in the window. Does the movie develop a more elaborate combination of these that might be interpreted according to some meaningful pattern: close-ups for love scenes and long shots for battle scenes, for instance?
  • 除了描述和包含动作之外，框架是否暗示了其边界之外的其他动作或空间？重要的事件或声音是否发生在画面边界之外——屏幕外的空间？这个银幕外的空间有什么意义，或者它与画面内看到的东西的关系是什么？银幕外的空间是否被用于喜剧效果，如巴斯特·基顿的电影《将军》（1927）中那样，我们发现他所坐的车轮是位于画面外且即将移动的火车的一部分？或者它是否具有严肃的意义，就像在罗伯特·布列松的电影中一样，银幕外的空间暗示着一种他的角色无法掌握或理解的精神现实，因为它实际上超出了他们的世界框架？
  • Besides describing and containing the action, does the frame suggest other action or space outside its borders? Do important events or sounds occur outside the borders of the frame—in offscreen space? What is the significance of this offscreen space or its relation to what is seen within the frame? Is offscreen space used for comic effect, as in Buster Keaton’s movie The General (1927), in which we discover that the wheel he is sitting on is part of a train located outside the frame and about to move? Or does it have a serious meaning, as in Robert Bresson’s films, in which offscreen space suggests a type of spiritual reality his characters are unable to grasp or understand because it is literally beyond the frame of their world?

在一个场景中，当相机通过改变其相对于被拍摄对象的位置来创建移动帧时，任何这些构图都可能发生变化。例如，两个恋人窃窃私语的浪漫特写镜头，如果相机画面向后移动，使它们成为充满观众的长镜头的一部分，那么它的意义可能会突然改变：通过画面的移动，最初的浪漫变成了浪漫。 ，漫画。这种框架行为称为重新框架，可以通过以下方式完成：完全依赖于画面的移动，而不是通过剪辑来编辑图像（见第64-70页）。

Within one scene, any of these compositions may change as the camera creates a moving frame by altering its position in relation to the object being filmed. A romantic close-up of two lovers whispering, for example, may suddenly change its meaning if the camera frame moves backward and makes them part of a long shot full of spectators: What was at first romantic has become, through the movement of the frame, comic. This kind of framing action, called reframing, can be done in ways that rely entirely on the movement of the frame, not on the editing of images through cuts (see pp. 64–70).

当画面转移到高高的吊车镜头（俯视动作）时，我们都意识到视角发生了巨大的变化：电影可能强调角色相对于他或她的其他空间的渺小，或者可能揭示其他行动，例如山脉另一侧的骑兵逼近。当画面上下移动、从一个位置倾斜时，它可能只是跟随角色上下观察的视角，但也可能是表达物体高低的一种方式（大约，例如，对纽约市的摩天大楼感到不知所措的游客）。另一种移动框架是平移，其中框架从一侧移动到另一侧，而不改变相机的位置或观看场景的点：观察他面前的街道，角色可能会慢慢地从左边看向右，镜头可能会平移以重现他的视线的连续移动。相比之下，跟踪或移动拍摄不是静止的，而是通过移动相机的位置（通常在小轨道上）来跟随或插入动作，从而使画面向前、向后或围绕拍摄对象。在鸡尾酒会场景中，影片可能会通过使用移动镜头跟随角色穿过人群来重现聚会中流动的亲密感。如果这个动作是通过手持拍摄来实现的，其中相机是由摄影师携带的，那么镜头可能会更不稳定（并且在某些方面可能看起来更真实）。

When the frame moves to high, overhead crane shots, which look down on the action, we all realize there has been a dramatic change in perspective: The film may be emphasizing the smallness of the character in relation to the rest of his or her space, or it may be revealing other action, such as the approach of the cavalry on the other side of the mountain range. When the frame moves up and down, tilting from one position, it may simply be following the point of view of a character who is looking up and down, but it may also be a way of making a statement about high and low objects (about, for instance, the tourist who feels overwhelmed by the skyscrapers of New York City). Another kind of mobile frame is the pan, in which the frame moves from side to side without a change in the position of the camera or the point from which the scene is viewed: Surveying the street before him, a character may look slowly from left to right, and the camera may pan to recreate the continuous movement of his gaze. In contrast, a tracking or dolly shot is not stationary but follows or intrudes on the action by moving the position of the camera (often on small tracks) and thus taking the frame forward, backward, or around the subject. During a cocktail-party scene, the film may recreate the roving intimacy of the gathering by using a dolly shot that follows a character through the crowd. If this action is achieved by a handheld shot, in which the camera is carried by the camera operator, the shot may be jerkier (and may, in some ways, seem more realistic).

由于框架意味着对世界或某些角色的视角，因此它们的移动性或缺乏移动性可以指向您在这些框架中看到的世界的基础。您所看到的世界是一个活跃的世界，还是一个看似僵化、静态的世界？这个世界的复杂性往往会随着框架的移动和变化而显现出来，你越准确地注意到这些框架，你的分析就会越深刻。在某些时候，尝试将你对角色或情况的分析完全建立在描述它们的框架动作的基础上。你能看到什么模式？这个角色是否总是通过追踪人群和情境的特写镜头来观察世界，而没有以更广阔的视角来看待它们？这种一致的行动方式是否表明他参与了但从未真正看到整个画面？

Since frames imply a perspective on the world or on certain characters, their mobility or lack of it can point to the very foundation of the world you see in those frames. Is it an active world you are seeing, or one that seems rigid and static? The complexities of that world are often revealed as the frames move and change, and the more exactly you can note these frames, the more incisive your analysis will be. Try, at some point, to base your analysis of a character or a situation exclusively on the framing action that describes them. What patterns can you see? Does this character always look at the world through close-ups that track through crowds and situations, without ever getting a larger perspective on them? Does that consistent way of framing the action suggest that he participates but never really sees the whole picture?

请记住，框架及其行为没有普遍意义。正如颜色不具有不变的象征价值一样，摄像机角度和动作在不同的电影中也不一定具有相同的含义。低角度镜头并不总是意味着统治，高角度镜头也不总是意味着压迫（有时人们认为如此）。尽管在一部电影中，低角度镜头可能会提醒观众，一个弱角色是被一个更强大、更危险的人看着，在另一部电影中，低角度镜头可以用来描述一个孩子看着她所爱的人的惊奇。如果您首先仔细注意视觉细节，您可以反思特定电影中特定的取景动作如何发挥作用，以及它们如何引发有关这些电影及其主题的某些问题。无尽的特写镜头系列在为美国电视制作的电影中意味着一件事，它可能强调个体角色的重要性，而在欧洲艺术电影中则意味着另一件事，它可能暗示人脸的不可知品质。在小津的电影中，导演框架的低高度可能意味着日本人从榻榻米房间的地板上看世界时更加轻松、冥想的视角，但比利时电影制片人尚塔尔·阿克曼声称，低高度她的框架出现是因为她矮！这个教训应该很清楚：不要简单地描述技术细节并期望它们是不言自明的。相反，让它们发挥作用来传达关于框架及其观点运作的各种方式以及它们在特定电影、特定文化和特定时间中意味着什么的想法。

Remember that frames and their actions have no universal meaning. Just as colors do not have unchanging symbolic value, camera angles and movements do not have to mean the same thing in different movies. Low-angle shots do not always signify dominance, nor do high-angle shots always suggest oppression (as is sometimes thought). Although in one movie a low-angle shot may remind the viewer that a weak character is being looked at by a stronger, more dangerous person, in another movie that low-angle shot may be used to describe the wonder of a child looking at a person she loves. If you begin by noting visual details carefully, you can reflect on how particular framing actions work in specific films and on how they provoke certain questions about those films and their themes. An endless series of close-ups means one thing in a movie made for American television, where it may underline the importance of the individual character, and another thing in a European art film, where it may suggest the unknowable quality of the human face. In an Ozu film, the low height of the director’s frame may be meant to suggest the more relaxed, meditative perspective of a Japanese person looking at the world from the floor of a tatami room, but the Belgian filmmaker Chantal Akerman claims that the low height of her frames occurs because she is short! The lesson should be clear: Don’t simply describe technical details and expect them to be self-explanatory. Rather, put them to work to convey an idea about the various ways that frames and their points of view operate and what they mean in specific films, in specific cultures, and at specific times.

编辑后的图像

The Edited Image

从最简单的意义上来说，剪辑就是连接两个不同的镜头（在旧电影中是将两个不同的胶片拼接在一起的产物，但今天是通过连接不同的数字图像来制作的）。通常，剪辑遵循某种发展逻辑（例如，先是一个女人的图像，然后是她正在看的物体），或者是为了做出某种声明（先是一个自负的沙皇的图像，然后是一个孔雀的图像）。 ）。回想一下酒吧里的牛仔：当一个长镜头显示他在酒吧，然后慢慢靠近以近距离捕捉他时，这是在一个镜头内重新构图。但是，如果在第一张图像之后，摄像机停止并移动到另一个位置（可能是酒吧另一侧的低角度），则重新构图的长镜头现在已被编辑为两个镜头。两个图像之间的间隔就是剪切。

In the simplest sense, editing is the linking of two different shots (in older films the product of splicing together two different pieces of film but today produced by linking different digital images). Usually, the editing follows some logic of development (an image of a woman and then the object she is looking at, for example) or is meant to make a statement of some sort (an image of an egotistical czar and then one of a peacock). Recall the cowboy at the bar: When a long shot shows him at the bar and then slowly tracks in closer to capture him close up, this is reframing within a single shot. But if, after that first image, the camera stops and moves to another position (maybe a low angle on the other side of the bar), that reframed long shot has now been edited into two shots. The break between the two images is a cut.

一个镜头可以在屏幕上停留任意时间，结果就是一定的剪辑节奏或节奏。因为剪辑的节奏是相对的，所以我们应该尽量注意一部电影或电影的一部分为什么以及如何按照一定的节奏进行剪辑。我们期望一个追逐场景能够被快速剪辑（有很多快速剪辑和简短的镜头），但为了让我们滑稽地意识到我们对剪辑的期望，可以用非常慢的节奏和很少的剪辑来剪辑追逐场景。作为练习，准确观察任何电影中单个图像在屏幕上停留的时间，然后反思为什么电影制作者会在该时间切换到另一个角度或图像观点。导演是否主要使用长镜头，即在场景或物体上保留异常长时间的镜头（就像泰伦斯·马利克在《细细的红线》 [1999]中所做的那样，当时他将图像保持在草地或树枝上神秘地长时间）期）？或者电影是否像《谍影重重》（2007）中的追逐场景一样从一个画面快速切换到另一个画面？剪辑的节奏是否会随着场景的变化而变化，例如，在街道上使用快速剪辑，在家里使用缓慢的长镜头？

A shot can be held on the screen for any length of time, the result being a certain editing pace or rhythm. Because the pace of the editing is relative, we should try to note why and how a film or part of a film is edited according to a certain rhythm. We expect a chase scene to be rapidly edited (with lots of quick cuts and brief shots), but to make us comically aware of our expectations about editing, that chase scene could be edited with very slow rhythms and few cuts. As an exercise, observe exactly how long a single image remains on the screen in any movie and then reflect on why the filmmaker cuts to another angle or image at that point. Does the director use mostly long takes, shots that remain on a scene or object for an unusually long time (as Terrence Malick did in The Thin Red Line [1999] when he held the image on grassy fields or the branches of trees for mystically long periods)? Or does the film cut rapidly from one image to another, as in chase sequences in The Bourne Ultimatum (2007)? Does the pace of the editing change with the scene, for example, by using quick cuts on the streets and slow, long takes inside the home?

从更广泛的意义上来说，剪辑是指如何将镜头构建成电影的更大片段，从而构建更大的意义单元。因此，可以将一系列镜头仔细地组合起来以创建一个场景，该场景通常是仅限于一个地点和时间的动作：例如，在简·坎皮恩（Jane Campion）的《钢琴》（1993）中，艾达（霍利·亨特）到达的场景十九世纪新西兰的一个偏远海滩，或者《战舰波将金号》（1925）中，军官们检查腐肉的场景。后者一开始是一群愤怒的水手聚集在甲板上，围着一块长满蛆虫的肉。船上的外科医生检查了特写镜头中的肉，并宣布这些蛆只是死苍蝇；当另一名军官驱散愤怒的水手时，场景结束。

In the larger sense, editing refers to how shots are built into larger pieces of a movie and, hence, larger units of meaning. A series of shots can thus be carefully joined to create a single scene, which is usually an action confined to one place and time: for example, in Jane Campion’s The Piano (1993), the scene in which Ada (Holly Hunter) arrives on a remote beach in nineteenth-century New Zealand, or, in The Battleship Potemkin (1925), the scene in which the officers inspect the rotten meat. The latter begins with a group of angry sailors gathered on deck around a piece of maggot-infested meat; the ship’s surgeon inspects the meat, which is shown in close-up, and announces that the maggots are simply dead flies; the scene ends as another officer disperses the outraged sailors.

当这些镜头描述更多的动作、更多的时间和多个地点时，所产生的一组交织且统一的镜头或场景通常被称为序列。在《钢琴》中，当艾达遇见并带领她穿过丛林到达她未来的家时，海滩场景成为了更大的到达序列的一部分；在《战舰波将金号》中，戏剧性地表现了水手们日益增长的不满情绪，使这些场景成为导致他们叛乱的复杂序列的一部分。作为上一个练习的一部分，看看您现在是否可以标记电影的各个部分，以展示如何将镜头编辑成复杂的关系，从而创建统一的场景或序列。

When these shots describe significantly more action and more time and more than one location, the interwoven and unified group of shots or scenes that results is often called a sequence. In The Piano, the beach scene becomes part of a larger arrival sequence when Ada is met and led through the jungle to her future home; in The Battleship Potemkin, the scenes that dramatize the sailors’ mounting discontent make those scenes part of a complicated sequence leading to their rebellion. As part of the previous exercise, see if you can now mark off sections of a film that show how shots can be edited into complex relationships that create unified scenes or sequences.

我们大多数人很少有意识地关注剪辑，因为我们最了解并喜欢经典电影的连续剪辑。这种剪辑风格被恰当地称为隐形剪辑，因为电影制片人不希望剪辑分散对故事的注意力，因此避免了过于明显的图像之间的剪切和过渡。电影制作者试图通过各种手段隐藏电影剪辑，以便我们将图像视为连续的画面。因此，尽管《马耳他之鹰》（1941）是一部剪辑得非常巧妙和时尚的电影——仔细平衡了萨姆·斯佩德的出入口以及他注意到房间细节的敏锐方法——但我们将其视为一个连续的动作，其中突兀的剪辑将看起来格格不入。

Most of us pay little conscious attention to editing because we know and enjoy most the continuity editing of classical cinema. This editing style is appropriately called invisible editing, because the filmmaker, not wanting the editing to distract from the story, avoids cuts and transitions between images that would be too obvious. Through various means, the filmmaker attempts to hide the film editing so that we view the images as a continuous picture. Thus, even though The Maltese Falcon (1941) is a very skillfully and stylishly edited movie—carefully balancing Sam Spade’s entrances and exits and his keen method of noticing the details in a room—we view it as a continuous action in which obtrusive cuts would seem out of place.

然而，连续性剪辑依赖于一些精心设计的剪辑技术，这些技术经过分析后可以揭示有关人物和故事的重要观点。例如，建立镜头是开始一个场景或序列的镜头，作为在将该序列划分为更详细的镜头之前将场景清楚地定位在某个位置的一种方式。《卡萨布兰卡》（1942）以一系列定场镜头开始，描述了地图上的城市、城里的人，最后描述了里克歌舞厅的外面。直到那时，影片才进入内部，开始讲述瑞克的故事。镜头/反镜头或镜头/反镜头模式也是连续性编辑的基本组成部分。通过这种技术，两个角色（或一个角色和一个物体）之间的交流被编辑为通过从说话或看的人切换到被处理或看到的物体或人，从而显得逻辑和自然；例如，一个镜头显示亨弗莱·鲍嘉向英格丽·褒曼提问，然后切入她的回答。当考虑一部使用连续性剪辑的电影时，编剧可以像现实主义本身一样，首先质疑所使用技术的基本目的：

Yet, continuity editing depends on some highly crafted editing techniques, techniques that, when analyzed, reveal important points about the characters and story. Establishing shots, for instance, are the shots that begin a scene or sequence as a way of locating a scene clearly in a certain place before dividing that sequence into more detailed shots. Casablanca (1942) begins with a series of establishing shots that describe the city on the map, the kind of people in the city, and, finally, the outside of Rick’s cabaret. Only then does the film move inside to begin its story about Rick. The shot/reverse-shot, or shot/countershot, pattern is also a fundamental part of continuity editing. With this technique, an exchange between two characters (or a character and an object) is edited to appear logical and natural by cutting from the person speaking or looking to the object or person being addressed or seen; for instance, a shot shows Humphrey Bogart asking Ingrid Bergman a question and then cuts to her responding. When considering a film that uses continuity editing, a writer can begin, as with realism itself, by questioning the basic purposes of the techniques used:

  • “连续性”是否对世界和社会有更大的影响？这部电影是否试图营造一种逻辑或安全的世界感？例如，确定的镜头是否表明角色（和观众）知道他们在哪里并且应该有宾至如归的感觉？连续性是否有助于建立一种逻辑上的必然性感，即事件和关系必须走向自然结局，即赫本和格兰特将再婚，就像《费城故事》 （1940）中那样？
  • Are there larger implications concerning the world and society in the “continuity”? Is the movie trying to create a sense of a logical or safe world? Do establishing shots, for instance, indicate that the characters (and the audience) know where they are and should feel at home? Does the continuity help establish, as in The Philadelphia Story (1940), a sense of logical inevitability, a feeling that events and relationships have to move toward a natural conclusion, that Hepburn and Grant will remarry?
  • 是否对连续性剪辑进行了调整以适应流派或创造某些情感反应？公路电影是否剪辑更少、长镜头更长？在西部片中，正镜头/反镜头模式是否更多地涉及人和事物而不是人和其他人？
  • Has the continuity editing been adjusted to fit a genre or to create certain emotional responses? Do road movies have fewer cuts and more long takes? In westerns, do the shot/reverse-shot patterns involve people and things more than people and other people?
  • 当剪辑呈现一个基本连续且统一的世界时，这种连续性是否有时会被破坏？如果是这样，为什么？例如，在《上海女郎》（1947）中，奥逊·威尔斯经常通过叙述者奥哈拉的可信度受到质疑，以及通过视觉扭曲（例如结尾的镜厅）来扰乱观众的空间感和时间感。电影的。在这种情况下，破坏性的图像和编辑意味着一个无法维持旧确定性的世界的崩溃。
  • When the editing presents a fundamentally continuous and unified world, are there times when that continuity is disrupted? If so, why? In The Lady from Shanghai (1947), for instance, Orson Welles regularly disrupts the viewer’s sense of space and time through the questionable reliability of the narrator, O’Hara, and through visual distortions, such as in the hall of mirrors at the end of the movie. In this case, the disrupting images and editing imply the collapse of a world incapable of maintaining old certainties.
  • 特定序列中的镜头/反镜头模式是否告诉您有关所涉及角色的任何信息，或者他们如何看待世界和彼此？是给一个人还是另一个人注射了更多的镜头？剪辑是否会创造出一种模式，其中一个角色的眼睛永远不会与另一个角色相交？
  • Does the shot/reverse-shot pattern in a particular sequence tell you anything about the characters involved or how they see the world and each other? Are considerably more shots given to one person or the other? Does the editing create a pattern in which one character’s eyes never meet the other’s?
  • 您如何区分像《疤面煞星》 （1932 年）这样的老经典电影的连续剪辑和像《盐》（2010 年）这样更现代的好莱坞电影的连续剪辑？一个人使用更多的长镜头，另一个人使用更多的快切镜头吗？您如何区分欧洲电影（如《游戏规则》（1939 年））和同一时期的美国电影（如《愤怒的葡萄》（1940 年））中的连续性剪辑？第一个是否更多地依赖于移动框架来强调角色周围的世界，而第二个则更多地依赖于强调角色本身的平滑编辑技术？
  • How would you distinguish between the continuity editing of an older, classic movie like Scarface (1932) and that of a more modern Hollywood film like Salt (2010)? Does one use more long takes and the other more quick cuts? How would you differentiate between the continuity editing in a European movie such as The Rules of the Game (1939) and an American movie of the same period such as The Grapes of Wrath (1940)? Does the first rely more on a moving frame to emphasize the world around the characters and the second more on smooth editing techniques that emphasize the characters themselves?

连续性编辑还可以使用更引人注目和风格化的方法，这些方法通常与老电影相关。其中包括以下内容：

Continuity editing can also use more noticeable and stylized methods, which are often associated with older movies. These include the following:

  • 淡入或淡出：图像变暗或变亮，使其出现或消失。
  • Fade-in or fade-out: An image is darkened or lightened so that it appears or disappears.
  • 光圈入或光圈出：新图像在旧图像中间显示为扩展的圆圈，或者旧图像变成收缩的圆圈，消失在新图像中。
  • Iris-in or iris-out: The new image appears as an expanding circle in the middle of the old image, or the old image becomes a contracting circle that disappears into the new image.
  • 擦除：一条线在图像上移动，逐渐清除一个镜头并引入另一个镜头。
  • Wipe: A line moves across an image to gradually clear one shot and introduce another.
  • 溶解：新镜头短暂叠加在褪色的旧镜头上。
  • Dissolve: A new shot is briefly superimposed on the fading old shot.

当这些技术在电影中使用时，问问它们的目的是什么。在老电影中使用，它们创造了从一个时间或地点到另一个时间或地点的逻辑过渡。在 DW Griffith 的电影中，淡入淡出可能会说“当天晚些时候”，因为镜头显示的是晚上的同一个厨房；当法院内部被图像上的一条线擦拭掉时，擦拭可能会暗示“在城镇的另一部分”，并且在线的另一侧出现了一个中国鸦片馆。当观看一部较旧的电影时，询问一种技术是否用于一种链接（例如，连接不同位置的擦除），而另一种技术是否用于其他情况（表示时间变化的溶解）。在分析现代电影时，问问剪辑师为什么会选择这些较旧的连续性设备。伍迪·艾伦使用虹膜是否只是为了达到幽默效果，因为它们在当代电影中如此不寻常？在《棉花俱乐部》（The Cotton Club，1984）中，擦拭巾仅仅是对故事发生的 1920 年代的提及，还是它们是强调时间和历史的流逝（电影的主题之一）的戏剧性手段？

When these techniques are used in a movie, ask what they are meant to achieve. Used in older movies, they create logical transitions from one time or place to another. In a D. W. Griffith film, a fade might be saying, “Later that same day,” as the shot reveals the same kitchen in the evening; a wipe could suggest, “In another part of town,” when the interior of the courthouse is wiped off by a line across the image and a Chinese opium den appears on the other side of the line. When watching an older film, ask if one technique is used for one kind of linkage (a wipe connecting different places, for example) and another technique for other situations (a dissolve indicating changes in time). When analyzing modern movies, ask why the editor would choose these older continuity devices. Does Woody Allen use irises just for a humorous effect because they are so unusual in a contemporary movie? In The Cotton Club (1984), are the wipes simply a reference to the 1920s, when the story takes place, or are they a dramatic means of emphasizing the passage of time and history—one of the main themes of the film?

除了认识连续性剪辑的技术之外，您还应该学会识别、理解和分析电影如何破坏或挑战您对连续性剪辑的期望。尤其是在更现代的电影中，开始注意电影何时与连续性编辑的标准，并开始提出以下问题：

Besides recognizing the techniques of continuity editing, you should learn to recognize, make sense of, and analyze how films undermine or challenge your expectations about continuity editing. Especially in more contemporary films, begin to notice when a film breaks with the standards of continuity editing and begin to ask questions such as the following:

  • 为什么某部电影中的定场镜头如此之少？因为场景是从一个角色的特写镜头开始的，还是在一个身份不明的房间里开始的，所以很难说动作发生在哪里吗？这些角色似乎和我们一样迷失方向吗？这种迷失方向与电影的主题有关吗？
  • Why are there so few establishing shots in a particular movie? Is it difficult to say where an action takes place because the scene begins with a close-up of a character or inside an unidentified room? Do the characters seem to share our disorientation? Is this disorientation related to the themes of the film?
  • 为什么电影中的时间连续性会以如此令人困惑的方式被打破？剪辑是否使用了多次跳切，连续镜头突然中断，图像跳到新的人物或另一个背景，甚至相同的背景但在不同的时间？例如，当一个角色讨论她的生活时，独白可能会在某些地方被中断，而房间里的光线会随着每次跳切而变化，以表明时间的流逝。电影制片人是想让我们更多地意识到时间的流逝，还是在讽刺这个角色无聊的生活故事？
  • Why is the temporal continuity within a film broken up in such a confusing fashion? Does the editing use a number of jump cuts, in which a continuous shot is suddenly broken and the image jumps to new figures or another background or even the same background but at a different time? As a character discusses her life, for instance, the monologue may be broken in places, while the light in the room changes with each jump cut to indicate the passage of time. Is the filmmaker trying to make us more aware of the passage of time, or is he or she commenting ironically on this character’s boring life story?
  • 为什么没有我们可以认同的观点？这是否与缺乏让我们能够识别角色视角的正镜头/反镜头场景有关？电影制片人是否会像沃纳·赫尔佐格在他的电影中经常做的那样，强迫观众与普通人保持距离，而认同动物、疯子或侏儒？影片中是否包含一些在故事中似乎不存在的图像？一部关于战争的电影可能会一次又一次莫名其妙地切入樱花树的形象。它是一个符号吗？它是角色记忆的一部分吗？为什么这个无法解释的图像打破了动作的连续性？
  • Why is there no point of view with which we can identify? Does this have something to do with the lack of shot/reverse-shot scenes that would allow us to identify with the perspective of a character? Does the filmmaker, as Werner Herzog often does in his films, force his audience to remain detached from the ordinary people and to identify instead with animals, lunatics, or dwarfs? Does the film contain images that seem to have no place in the story? A movie about war may inexplicably cut to an image of a cherry tree, time and time again. Is it a symbol? Is it part of a character’s memory? Why is the continuity of the action broken by this unexplained image?

在这些情况下，剪辑本身引起了人们的注意，而这种唐突的代价是人们最初对剪辑为何扰乱了人们对世界的通常看法感到困惑。当这种混乱导致有关电影主题和历史背景的更大问题（也许还有答案）时，作者开始勾画一个论文主题。在思考了一部赫尔佐格的电影后，一名学生意识到他的论文将讨论赫尔佐格的非传统剪辑，特别是他对镜头/倒转镜头交换的破坏，是如何让观众摆脱传统上人类社会的逻辑模式的努力的一部分位于世界的中心，这是赫尔佐格对自然世界的愿景的一部分，这个自然世界比个体的男人和女人更重要。

In these cases, the editing calls attention to itself, and the trade-off for that obtrusiveness is an initial confusion about why the editing has upset the usual perception of the world. When that confusion leads to larger questions (and, perhaps, to answers) about the themes and the historical context of the film, the writer is beginning to sketch a paper topic. After thinking about a Herzog movie, one student realized his paper would discuss how Herzog’s unconventional editing, particularly his undermining of a shot/reverse-shot exchange, is part of an effort to move the audience outside the logical patterns that have traditionally placed human society at the center of the world, part of Herzog’s vision of a natural world that is more important than individual men and women.

近几十年来，编辑已经进入数字时代，抛弃了更古老、更费力、更昂贵的流程在 Moviola 上手动编辑图像，或稍后在平板编辑台上编辑图像。现在，编辑几乎完全是通过基于计算机的非线性数字编辑系统完成的。通过数字非线性编辑，图像存储在大容量计算机的硬盘驱动器上，以便当今的电影剪辑师可以快速轻松地访问声音片段和图像，并将不同关系的声音片段和图像进行组合和重新组合。从理论上讲，数字电影制作可以让一个镜头持续几乎无限的时间，并可以创造出电影中那种不间断的即时性和随机性，例如 2008 年的《科洛弗档案》（Cloverfield），这是一部虚构的电影，讲述了怪物入侵纽约市的故事，记录在角色的数字电影中。相机。除了这些相当明显的效果之外，还可以考虑非线性数字编辑塑造电影的其他方式。数字剪辑是否在一些当代电影中创造了音乐和图像之间的新关系？数字图像的持续时间较长是否会鼓励在帧内而不是在编辑的帧之间进行更多创造性和动态的构图？数字电影制作和剪辑对最近​​的纪录片有何影响？

In recent decades, editing has entered the digital age, leaving behind the older, more laborious, and more expensive processes of editing images by hand on a Moviola or later on a flatbed editing table. Now editing is almost exclusively accomplished through computer-based nonlinear digital editing systems. With digital nonlinear editing, images are stored on the hard drives of high-capacity computers so that editors of movies today can quickly and easily access both sound bits and images and combine and recombine those in different relationships. Digital filmmaking theoretically allows a shot to last an almost unlimited amount of time and can create the kind of nonstop immediacy and randomness seen in a film such as the 2008 Cloverfield, a fictional movie about a monster’s invasion of New York City recorded on a character’s digital camera. Besides these fairly obvious effects, consider other ways nonlinear digital editing can shape a film. Has digital editing created new relationships between music and image in some contemporary films? Has the longer duration of the digital image encouraged more creative and dynamic compositions within the frame rather than between edited frames? How has digital filmmaking and editing impacted recent documentaries?

在检查传统和现代剪辑策略以及镜头之间的关系时，首先要了解一些关于要寻找什么的一般准则，但要对其进行调整以处理每部电影中具体和特定的用途和变化。

When examining both traditional and contemporary editing strategies and the relationships between shots, begin with some general guidelines about what to look for but adapt them to deal with concrete and specific uses and variations in each film.

首先，观察镜头的剪辑如何在物体和动作之间建立某种关系。剪辑是否在所展示的人、事物和行为之间建立了联系或对立？在《笑到最后》（1924）中，门卫经常与旋转门的形象联系在一起，两者的认同预示着这个人的好运的逆转。在《2001太空漫游》（1968）中，一只史前猿将一根骨头抛向空中，然后骨头变成了一艘宇宙飞船的图像。这个著名的动作匹配——将两个图像编辑在一起作为平行的动作或动作——具体化了数千年来由暴力和征服人民和领土的需要推动的人类发展。

First, observe how the editing of the shots establishes certain relationships between the objects and actions. Does the editing establish connections or oppositions among the people, things, and actions being shown? In The Last Laugh (1924), the doorman is frequently linked to the image of the revolving door, and the identification of the two predicts the reversal of the man’s good fortune. In 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968), a prehistoric ape tosses a bone into the air, which then becomes the image of a spaceship. This famous match-on-action—two images being edited together as parallel actions or motions—crystallizes thousands of years of human development propelled by violence and the need to conquer people and territory.

其次，让自己习惯于注意图像之间更抽象的关系。这是一个更困难的实践，但是，正如爱森斯坦的《战舰波将金号》中的例子所示（参见第 28-33 页），编辑的这些更抽象的方面可以出色地用于某些效果。当这些镜头连接起来时，不同图像中人物的方向和运动是否匹配，例如创造一种朝单一方向驱动的视觉和情感力量？图形对比或相似性是通过不同镜头中空间的使用（例如，通过交替大空间和小空间）创建的吗？剪辑是否通过严格控制长度来设置一定的节奏？每次射击？（虽然我们大多数人最了解追逐序列的加速节奏，但剪辑可以塑造许多其他类型的节奏。）请记住，这些形式模式本身没有最终和普遍的意义，它们在电影史上的演变并不独立于其他历史问题。尽管编辑可以被视为在时间和空间上组织图像的正式方式，但通常涉及的不仅仅是形式或技术问题。仔细观察剪辑，但让它引导你更多地思考电影的意义和意义。在下面的学生论文中，作者研究了《公民凯恩》（1941）中的一个非常短的序列，并将图像的编辑和构图与特定主题联系起来：

Second, accustom yourself to noticing more abstract relationships between images. This is a more difficult practice, but, as the example from Eisenstein’s The Battleship Potemkin shows (see pp. 28–33), these more abstract aspects of editing can be brilliantly used for certain effects. Does the direction and movement of the figures in the different images match when these shots are connected, creating, for example, a kind of visual and emotional force driving in a single direction? Are graphic contrasts or similarities created through the use of space in the different shots, for example, by alternating large and small spaces? Does the editing set up certain rhythms by strictly controlling the length of each shot? (Although most of us know best the accelerated rhythms of a chase sequence, the editing can fashion many other kinds of rhythms.) Remember, these formal patterns have no final and universal meaning in themselves, and their evolution through film history is not independent of other historical questions. Although editing can be seen as a formal way of organizing images in time and space, more than just formal or technical issues are usually involved. Look precisely at editing, but let it lead you to think more about how and what films mean. In the following student essay, the writer examined a very short sequence in Citizen Kane (1941) and related the editing and the composition of the image to a specific theme:

斯科特·理查森

Scott Richardson

 

在《公民凯恩》中编辑早餐

Editing Breakfast in Citizen Kane

 

查尔斯·福斯特·凯恩 (Charles Foster Kane) 与艾米丽 (Emily) 结婚后不久，艾米丽是他的梦中情人，就像他的一尊雕像一样从欧洲带回来，但他们的婚姻开始破裂。这种崩溃的严重性和强度在一个两分钟的片段中得到了体现，这仍然是威尔斯在《公民凯恩》中令人回味且经济的剪辑中最引人注目的例子之一。

Soon after Charles Foster Kane marries Emily, the woman of his dreams who is brought back from Europe like one of his statues, their marriage begins to collapse. The severity and intensity of this collapse are captured in one two-minute sequence, which remains one of the most striking examples of Welles’s evocative and economical editing in Citizen Kane.

 

该序列以凯恩和艾米丽在相对温暖的光线下的中景两张镜头开始。他们的谈话是调侃而亲密的，通过镜头/反向镜头交换充满爱意的眼神，在视觉上强化了这一点：他告诉她她很漂亮，当她抱怨他不得不离开去他的报社办公室时，他说他会打电话并改变他的想法。约会。接下来是五对短镜头/反镜头对，在每对镜头中，这对夫妇的眼神变得越来越怀疑和严厉。谈话逐渐变得充满敌意和简短，报纸成为他们日益分裂的视觉和口头象征。在中间部分的第一个场景中，她抱怨道：“查尔斯，如果我不信任你……你半夜看报纸做什么？” 第三，艾米丽恳求他停止在报纸上攻击她的叔叔总统。到了第五，他甚至不让她把话说完：

The sequence begins with a medium two-shot of Kane and Emily in relatively warm light. Their conversation is teasing and intimate, visually reinforced by a shot/reverse-shot exchange of loving looks: He tells her she is beautiful, and when she complains about his having to leave for his newspaper office, he says he will call and change his appointments. That exchange is followed by five more short shot/reverse-shot pairs, and in each, the eyes of the couple grow increasingly suspicious and severe. The conversations are progressively hostile and clipped, and the newspaper becomes both a visual and a verbal symbol of their growing division. In the first scene of this middle section, she complains, “Charles, if I didn’t trust you.... What do you do on a newspaper in the middle of the night?” In the third, Emily pleads with him to stop attacking her uncle, the president, in his newspaper. By the fifth, he is not even allowing her to finish her sentence:

 

艾米丽：真的，查尔斯，人们有权利期待......

EMILY: Really, Charles, people have a right to expect....

 

查尔斯：我想给他们什么。

CHARLES: What I care to give them.

 

纵观整个序列，服装和场景布景等方面的变化都表明时间的流逝也是情感亲密的渐行渐远。凯恩从浪漫的燕尾服换成了西装。他们的环境从畅通无阻的封闭空间变成了充满植物、鲜花和报纸的受阻空间。

Through the entire sequence, the changes in the clothing and other aspects of the mise-en-scène indicate that the passage of time is also a passage away from emotional intimacy. Kane changes from a romantic tuxedo to a business suit. Their setting alters from an unobstructed and close space to an obstructed space cluttered with plants, flowers, and newspapers.

 

然后，通过一个镜头/反向镜头，然后另一个两个镜头，有力地结束了剪辑的简洁逻辑。在正镜头/反镜头中，目光不再相遇或匹配，因为他们现在都在阅读不同的报纸——他，他自己的（《询问者报》），她，竞争对手（《纪事报》）。中长的两镜头在形式上平衡了序列的开头，光线更冷、更暗。这两位前恋人被明显地放置在画面的两侧。

The succinct logic of the editing is then powerfully concluded with a shot/reverse-shot and then another two-shot. In the shot/reverse-shot, the eyes no longer meet or match, since they are now both reading separate newspapers—he, his own (The Inquirer), she, the rival (The Chronicle). Formally balancing the opening of the sequence, the medium-long two-shot has much colder and darker lighting. The two former lovers are placed conspicuously at opposite sides of the frame.

 

这个序列描述的真实时间可能是很多年。然而，通过对编辑空间的严格和创造性的使用以及该空间内的一系列对话，威尔斯描绘的不仅仅是一场失败婚姻的概要。他还用闪光灯将六次遭遇恰如其分地联系起来，以简洁而电影化的方式讲述了《公民凯恩》的整个故事：凯恩最大的愿望如何在实现后几乎立即化为灰烬，以及他如何因此成为一个人总是疏远于他周围的广阔空间。

The real time that this sequence describes is probably many years. Yet, through a rigorous and creative use of an edited space and a series of conversations within that space, Welles depicts more than just the synopsis of a failed marriage. Linking the six encounters, appropriately, with flash pans, he also tells a succinct and cinematic version of the entire tale of Citizen Kane: of how Kane’s greatest desires seem to turn to dust almost immediately after he achieves them and of how he consequently becomes a man always alienated in the great spaces that surround him.

 

声音

SOUND

 

在 1992 年的《白人跳不了》中，两个打篮球的伙伴——西德尼（韦斯利·斯奈普斯饰）和比利（伍迪·哈里森饰）——在汽车收音机上听吉米·亨德里克斯的歌曲。尽管他们都在专心听讲，西德尼还是责骂比利，指出：“你在听，但你却在听”。没听见。” 类似地，许多电影观众听电影，但大多数情况下并没有学会听电影。这种常见的失败对于刚接触电影的好奇的学生来说意味着，许多与电影声音有关的话题和问题最近才开始被解决，并等待好的耳朵来解决它们。如果学生对音乐和声音感兴趣，并将兴趣集中在一部电影或一组特定的电影上，他们就会处理一些原创和挑衅性的材料。

In the 1992 White Men Can’t Jump, two basketball-playing buddies—Sidney (Wesley Snipes) and Billy (Woody Harrelson)—listen to a Jimi Hendrix tune on their car radio. Although they are both listening attentively, Sidney scolds Billy by pointing out, “You’re listening, but you’re not hearing it.” In a similar sense, many moviegoers listen to films but in most cases have not learned to hear them. What this common failure means to new and curious students of the movies is that many topics and problems having to do with film sound have only recently begun to be addressed and are waiting for good ears to take them up. If students with an interest in music and sound direct and concentrate that interest on a movie or a specific group of movies, they will tackle some original and provocative material.

请记住，三十多年来，直到 1927 年，无声电影显然没有技术资源来开发可以记录声音并将其与拍摄图像匹配的同步声音。然而事实上，这些所谓的无声电影是在剧院里被管弦乐和其他音乐伴奏和音效所包围的。这些电影不仅有时在图像和配乐之间存在复杂的关系，而且还为学生提供了丰富的分析机会，让他们探索创造性的方式：（1）声音和沉默可以暗示或暗示，（2）字幕适应文学描述和电影对话。

Keep in mind that for over thirty years, until 1927, silent films obviously did not have the technological resources to develop synchronous sound that could record and match sound with the filmed image. In fact, however, these so-called silent films were surrounded by orchestral and other musical accompaniments and sound effects in the theater. Not only do these films sometimes have complex relationships between the images and the scores that accompanied them, but they also offer students rich analytical opportunities in exploring the creative ways that (1) sound and silence can be implied or suggested and (2) intertitles adapt literary descriptions and dialogue to film.

理论上，声音的使用和编辑可以像图像一样复杂和智能。当然，声音在电影中有很多维度和用途。可以用音高、响度或音色来描述；它可以在电影中作为直接声音（在拍摄图像时录制）或后期配音（稍后在工作室添加的声音和对话）出现。电影声音可以采取对话、音乐或噪音（雷声或汽车紧急刹车）的形式，这些声音中的任何或所有声音都是自然或人工产生的。电影声音与图像和叙事有多种关系：最广泛地说，它的来源可能是图像中的物体或动作，因此作为屏幕上的或同步的声音，或者它的来源可能在电影画面之外，作为屏幕外的或异步的声音声音。无论是在银幕外还是银幕上，叙事声音的来源都在电影的叙事世界中（例如当角色开始唱歌时），而非叙事声音的来源则在该世界之外（例如在电影中的管弦乐谱的背景音乐中）。浪漫的场景）。它甚至可以在它作为声音桥梁链接到的图像之前或之后（例如，当角色的评论形成通往下一个图像的桥梁时）。

In theory, sound can be used and edited with as much complexity and intelligence as images can. Certainly, sound has many dimensions and uses in film. It can be described according to pitch, loudness, or timbre; it can figure in a film as direct sound (recorded when the image is being shot) or postdubbed sound (sound and dialogue added later in the studio). Movie sound can take the form of dialogue, music, or noise (thunder or a car screeching to a halt), any or all of these sounds being naturally or artificially produced. Film sound can have a multitude of relations to the image and the narrative: most broadly, its source may be an object or action in the image, thus as onscreen or synchronous sound, or its source may be outside the film frame as offscreen or asynchronous sound. Whether offscreen or onscreen, diegetic sound has its source in the narrative world of the film (such as when a character breaks into song), while nondiegetic sound has its source outside that world (such as in the background music of an orchestral score during a romantic scene). It can even precede or follow the image to which it is linked as a sound bridge (when a character’s remark, for example, forms a bridge into the next image).

与分析电影中的视觉细节一样，精确的词汇和术语总是能够推进电影声音的分析，一些讨论电影声音的有用技术术语包括：

As with the analysis of visual details in a film, a precise vocabulary and terminology always advance the analysis of film sound, and some useful technical terms for discussing film sound include the following:

  • 声音连续性描述了声音的评分和混合，以在场景或序列中创建统一的氛围或音调。
  • Sound continuity describes the scoring and mixing of sound to create a unified atmosphere or tone in a scene or sequence.
  • 声音蒙太奇组合了不同的声音片段，以在这些声音之间创建分离和意想不到的关系。
  • Sound montage composes different pieces of sound to create disjunctions and unexpected relations between those sounds.
  • 环境声音描述了围绕主要动作和对话的背景噪音或音乐。
  • Ambient sound describes the background noises or music that surround the main action and dialogue.
  • 重叠对话是人物言语的同时混合和重叠。
  • Overlapping dialogue is a simultaneous mixing and overlapping of characters’ speech.
  • 语音关闭源自曾经或将在屏幕上看到但在听到声音时不在屏幕上的发言者。
  • Voice-off originates in a speaker who was or will be seen onscreen but is not at the time the voice is heard.
  • 画外音是叙述者或评论员的声音，他们通常不属于故事或故事的一部分，角色也听不到。在传统纪录片中，这种超凡的声音通常被称为“上帝的声音”。
  • Voice-over is the voice of a narrator or commentator who typically is not part of the story or diegesis and cannot be heard by the characters. In conventional documentaries, this transcendent voice is often referred to as “the voice of God.”
  • 叙事提示是使用声音或音乐来支持故事中的某个时刻或主题，例如两个角色相遇时的浪漫小提琴主题。当这些提示突然且特别引人注目时，它们有时被称为“毒刺”。
  • Narrative cueing is the use of a sound or piece of music to support a moment or motif in the story, such as a romantic violin motif when two characters meet. When these cues are sudden and especially dramatic, they are sometimes called stingers.

纵观电影史，人们可以找到仅声音就成为分析主要主题的电影。一个著名的例子是 Jean-Marie Straub 和 Danièle Huillet 的《安娜·玛格达莱娜·巴赫编年史》（The Chronicle of Anna Magdalena Bach，1968），在配乐中巴赫优雅的音乐与巴赫身体和经济困难的痛苦故事之间建立了复杂的对立。弗朗西斯·科波拉的《对话》（1974）讲述了一个专门从事声音监视的人的故事，他试图仅通过声音发现真相，最终对视觉世界失去了所有信心。声音的一些最迷人和最具挑衅性的用途出现在 20 世纪 30 年代初期的电影中，当时声音首次被引入电影中。在一部早期的有声电影《三十九级台阶》（1935）中，希区柯克将声音作为情节的中心元素：在关键时刻，他通过将女人的尖叫声和机车的汽笛声联系起来，创造出戏剧性的声音搭配。不同的图像（图 3.10和3.11）。

Throughout film history, one can find movies in which the sound alone would make a major topic for analysis. A well-known example, Jean-Marie Straub and Danièle Huillet’s The Chronicle of Anna Magdalena Bach (1968), sets up a complex opposition between the graceful music of Bach on the sound track and the tormented story of Bach’s physical and financial troubles. Francis Coppola’s The Conversation (1974) recounts the story of a man who specializes in sound surveillance, who tries to discover the truth through sound alone, and who finally loses all faith in the visual world. Some of the most fascinating and provocative uses of sound are found in films of the early 1930s, when sound was first being introduced into the movies. In one early sound film, The Thirty-Nine Steps (1935), Hitchcock employs sound as a central element in the plot: At a critical moment, he creates a dramatic sound match by connecting a woman’s scream and the whistle of a locomotive to link disparate images (Figures 3.10 and 3.11).

要写关于声音的文章，我们必须首先学会关注声音——真正地听到它。这并不意味着电影中对声音的更明显或戏剧性的使用——保罗·托马斯·安德森的《血色将至》（There Will Be Blood ，2007）中带有奢华而复杂的音轨的电影，或者围绕音乐表演组织的电影，如《Shine a Light》（2008） ），马丁·斯科塞斯关于滚石乐队的音乐会电影——无法激发出好的文章。他们当然可以。但因为一篇好的文章应该揭示直觉、仔细和辨别性的思维，所以一篇关于声音的好文章通常会关注普通观众和听众通常无法理解的内容。

To write about sound, one must first learn to attend to sound—truly to hear it. This does not mean that the more obvious or dramatic uses of sound in film—in movies with the lavish and complex sound tracks found in Paul Thomas Anderson’s There Will Be Blood (2007) or in films organized around musical performances like Shine a Light (2008), Martin Scorsese’s concert film about the Rolling Stones—cannot inspire good essays. They certainly can. But because a good essay is one that reveals intuitive, careful, and discriminating thinking, a good essay on sound will often attend to what might normally escape a normal viewer and listener.

图 3.10三十九步（1935 年）：创建过渡和链接...

Figure 3.10 The Thirty-Nine Steps (1935): creating transitions and links...

 

因此，一位关于电影声音的作家可能会首先直率地提出以下问题：

A writer about sound in film might therefore begin by bluntly asking the following:

  • 在特定场景或序列中声音与图像的关系是什么？如何完善这个问题的答案以揭示电影中声音的目标、成就甚至失败？
  • What is the relation of the sound to the image in specific scenes or sequences? How might the answer to that question be refined to reveal the aims, achievements, or even failures of sound in the movie?
  • 声音是用来链接图像的，还是声音具有与图像一起开始和结束的传统作用？
  • Is the sound used to link images, or does the sound have the conventional role of beginning and terminating with the image?
  • 声音是否变得比图像更重要？这种不寻常策略的原因是什么？
  • Does sound ever become more important than the image, and what is the reason for this unusual strategy?
  • 音乐剧中的音乐数字与叙事结构有什么特殊关系吗（例如，当角色需要逃避幻想时，它们是否会出现）？
  • Do the musical numbers in a musical have any special relation to the narrative structure (for instance, do they occur when the characters need to escape into fantasy)?
  • 为什么最近的一些电影中人物对话重叠或含糊不清，导致难以理解人物？除了帮助讲述故事之外，对话还有其他目的吗？
  • Why does the dialogue of the characters overlap or seem mumbled in some recent movies so that it is difficult to understand the characters? Does the dialogue serve some other purpose than to help tell the story?
  • 沉默在这部电影中扮演什么角色？
  • What role does silence play in this movie?
  • 是否有可以识别角色或动作的声音主题？
  • Are there sound motifs that identify the characters or actions?
  • 声音的节奏是否支持或与剪辑的节奏相对应？
  • Does the rhythm of the sound support or serve as counterpoint to the rhythm of the editing?
  • 如果你必须从这部电影中选择三个关键声音序列，你会选择哪一个，为什么？
  • If you had to pick three key sound sequences from this movie, which would they be, and why?

图 3.11 ...通过声音匹配。

Figure 3.11 ... through sound matches.

 

这些问题只是电影声音和特定电影可能激发的众多疑问中的一个例子。聆听所有电影声音并写下它，就像戈达尔的《每个人都为自己》（1980）中的角色所表现出的好奇和怀疑一样，他们不断听到背景音乐并想知道它来自哪里以及为什么。法国著名电影制片人（也是声音领域的早期创新者）René Clair 在 1929 年撰写的文章中详细描述了电影中声音技术的首批成功之一：

These questions are only a sample of the many inquiries that movie sound and particular movies might inspire. Listen to all film sound and write about it with the same curiosity and suspicion exhibited by the characters in Godard’s Every Man for Himself (1980), who continually hear background music and wonder where it’s coming from and why. Here a renowned French filmmaker (and early innovator with sound), René Clair, writing in 1929, detailed one of the first successes with sound in the cinema:

目前在伦敦上映的所有电影中，《百老汇旋律》取得了最大的成功。这部新的美国电影代表了自两年前《爵士歌手》问世以来有声电影所取得的所有进步的总和。对于任何对复杂的录音技术有所了解的人来说，这部电影都是一个奇迹。导演哈利·博蒙特和他的合作者（除了演员之外，大约有十五人，在片尾字幕中都提到了名字）似乎很乐意解决视觉和声音录制的所有困难。演员们移动、行走、奔跑、说话、喊叫和低语，他们的动作和声音被灵活地再现，如果我们不知道科学和细致的组织为我们准备了许多其他的奇迹，这似乎是一个奇迹。在这部电影中，没有什么是偶然的。它的制作者以工程师的精确度工作，他们的成就对于那些仍然认为电影创作可以在被称为灵感的混乱条件下进行的人来说是一个教训。

Of all the films now showing in London, Broadway Melody is having the greatest success. This new American film represents the sum total of all the progress achieved in sound films since the appearance of The Jazz Singer two years ago. For anyone who has some knowledge of the complicated technique of sound recording, this film is a marvel. Harry Beaumont, the director, and his collaborators (of whom there are about fifteen, mentioned by name in the credit titles, quite apart from the actors) seem to delight in playing with all the difficulties of visual and sound recording. The actors move, walk, run, talk, shout, and whisper, and their movements and voices are reproduced with a flexibility which would seem miraculous if we did not know that science and meticulous organization have many other miracles in store for us. In this film, nothing is left to chance. Its makers have worked with the precision of engineers, and their achievement is a lesson to those who still imagine that the creation of a film can take place under conditions of chaos known as inspiration.

 

在《百老汇旋律》中，有声电影第一次找到了合适的形式：它既不是戏剧也不是电影，而是一种全新的东西。飞机静止不动的有声电影的诅咒已经消失。摄影机是可移动的，角度也像一部优秀的无声电影一样多变。演技是一流的，说话的贝西·洛芙超越了我们过去所喜爱的沉默的贝西·洛芙。音效的运用非常巧妙，如果其中一些仍然显得多余，那么其他的值得作为例子。

In Broadway Melody, the talking film has for the first time found an appropriate form: it is neither theater nor cinema, but something altogether new. The immobility of planes, that curse of talking films, has gone. The camera is as mobile, the angles are as varied as in a good silent film. The acting is first-rate, and Bessie Love talking manages to surpass the silent Bessie Love whom we so loved in the past. The sound effects are used with great intelligence, and if some of them still seem superfluous, others deserve to be cited as examples.

 

例如，我们听到关门声和一辆汽车开走的声音，同时看到贝西·洛夫痛苦的脸从窗户里看着我们看不到的离开。这个短场景的整体效果集中在女演员的脸上，无声电影必须将其分解为几个视觉片段，而它的卓越之处在于通过声音实现的“场所统一”。在另一个场景中，我们看到贝西·洛芙（Bessie Love）躺着，若有所思，悲伤不已。我们感觉她快要哭了；但她的脸消失在淡出的阴影中，现在黑色的屏幕上出现了一声抽泣。

For instance, we hear the noise of a door being slammed and a car driving off while we are shown Bessie Love’s anguished face watching from a window the departure which we do not see. This short scene in which the whole effect is concentrated on the actress’s face, and which the silent cinema would have had to break up in several visual fragments, owes its excellence to the “unity of place” achieved through sound. In another scene we see Bessie Love lying thoughtful and sad; we feel that she is on the verge of tears; but her face disappears in the shadow of a fade-out, and from the screen, now black, emerges a single sob.

 

在这两个例子中，声音在适当的时刻取代了枪声。正是通过这种经济手段，有声电影才最有可能确保原始效果。(93–94)

In these two instances the sound, at an opportune moment, has replaced the shot. It is by this economy of means that the sound film will most probably secure original effects. (93–94)

 

动画、3D 和新媒体

ANIMATION, 3-D, AND NEW MEDIA

 

近年来，作为更大规模的数字革命的一部分，新媒体和新技术已成为延伸或跨越传统叙事电影边界的电影和媒体文化的主要组成部分。虽然动画电影从一开始就已成为电影史的一部分，但举一个重要的例子，过去十五年发展和完善的数字动画流程催生了动画电影的复兴——从《玩具总动员》（1995 年）到《超级大坏蛋》 （2010 年） ——能够创建比以往更精致、更复杂的图像。动画电影视野不断扩大的结果之一是双层叙事的发展，这些叙事可以同时向儿童和成人讲述，这在日本动漫电影中尤其明显，例如两部《攻壳机动队》电影（1996年、2004年） ）。然而，无论主要针对儿童还是成人（例如 2008 年的动画纪录片《与巴希尔跳华尔兹》），动画电影都会引出以下首先要开始分析的问题：

In recent years and as part of the larger digital revolution, new media and new technologies have become a major part of film and media cultures that extend or cross the borders of traditional narrative cinema. While animated films have been a part of film history since its beginning, to take one important example, digital animation processes developed and refined in the last fifteen years have generated a renaissance of animated movies—from Toy Story (1995) to Megamind (2010)—capable of creating more elaborate and sophisticated images than ever before. One result of the expanding vision of animated cinema has been the development of narratives with bi-level addresses whose stories can speak at once to children and adults, especially apparent in Japanese anime films such as the two Ghost in the Shell films (1996, 2004). Yet, whether aimed mainly at children or at adults (as, for instance in the 2008 animated documentary Waltz with Bashir), animated films elicit these first questions with which to begin an analysis:

  • 如果这部电影跨越了儿童和成人的世界，那么这种重叠在电影中是如何形成的，又是如何发展出独特的主题和世界观的？关于想象力的作用？关于现实的本质？
  • If the film straddles the world of children and adults, how does this overlapping take shape in the film and how does it develop unique themes and perspectives on the world? About the role of imagination? About the nature of reality?
  • 动画如何以及为何根据其形式和主题使电影中人类世界与非人类世界之间的关系复杂化？
  • How and why does animation complicate the relations between the human world and the nonhuman world in the film as a function of its forms and themes?

最近，最著名的是詹姆斯·卡梅隆 (James Cameron) 的《阿凡达》( Avatar ) (2009) 宣布的 3-D 已成为特效漫长历史中的最新技术创新，这一历史可以追溯到乔治·梅里爱 (Georges Méliès) 1902 年的月球之旅以及早期的 3-D 实验20世纪50年代。由于近年来数字和计算机程序和设备的显着进步，电影现在可以以 3D 形式拍摄（尽管最近的许多电影仅具有后期制作增强功能），甚至是最不可能的电影，例如《电锯惊魂 3D》 (2010) 或Jackass 3-D (2010) 试图利用令人惊讶的现实主义，让观众体验电影，就像身临其境一样。然而，与较早的特效一样，学生应该立即提出 3D 的一些基本问题：特效在多大程度上显着增强了叙事主题和我们对电影的理解？3-D 在多大程度上只是装点门面？

More recently, and most famously announced by James Cameron’s Avatar (2009), 3-D has become the latest technological innovation in a long history of special effects that extends back through Georges Méliès’s 1902 Trip to the Moon and through early experiments with 3-D in the 1950s. Thanks to the remarkable advances in digital and computer programs and equipment in recent years, movies can now be filmed in 3-D (although many recent films feature only postproduction enhancements) and even the most unlikely films, such as Saw 3D (2010) or Jackass 3-D (2010), attempt to take advantage of an often astonishing realism that allows spectators to experience a film as if physically inhabiting it. As with older special effects, however, students should immediately ask some fundamental questions of 3-D: To what extent do the special effects add significantly to the themes of the narrative and our understanding of the film? To what extent is 3-D merely window dressing?

最后，也许也是最重要的一点是，数字革命已经开始极大地改变我们观看电影的方式。人们不仅通过互联网、CD-ROM 或 iPod 观看更多的电影，而且越来越多的艺术和信息被创造出来，以便通过这些新媒体工具来观看和理解。如果您有愿望或机会撰写有关此类新媒体产品的文章，请考虑以下问题作为起点：

Finally and perhaps most important, the digital revolution has begun to dramatically change how we view movies. Not only are people watching more movies through the Internet, CD-ROMs, or iPods, but more and more art and information is being created to be seen and understood specifically through these new media vehicles. If you have the desire or opportunity to write about these kinds of new media products, consider these questions as a starting point:

  • 与传统电影或视频相比，图像、故事或声音如何强调它们与观众之间的独特互动？这如何帮助解释他们的目的和目标？
  • How do the images, stories, or sounds emphasize, more than traditional films or videos, a unique interactivity between them and the viewer? How does that help explain their aims and goals?
