A school play is much more important than any intimacy she and Conrad may have shared in the hospital: “That was the hospital; this is the real world.” She exudes a cheerfulness and enthusiasm that Conrad’s troubled spirit cannot match, and in many ways, she seems to be becoming a replica of Conrad’s mother, interested only in appearances and unable to respond to male “substance.”

 

常态与平凡的主题回归。

The theme of normality and the ordinary returns.

 

即使是最具救赎性的女性角色，他新找到的女朋友珍妮，最终也抛弃了他。再次在一家餐馆，她试探性地联系了他，询问他自杀未遂的情况。他回应说她是“第一个问这个问题的人”，然后他开始回答她，这似乎是电影中第一个治疗性的沟通行为。就在这时，他们被一群吵闹的男性打断了（主要是描述电影中另一个主题的运动员）；她的反应是咯咯地笑，并允许他们把她从桌子上拉下来，从而破坏了她和康拉德之间的潜在联系，康拉德显然因这件事而感到震惊。从这个场景的逻辑来看，她显然是康拉德向她敞开心扉后令他失望的人，后来她试图解释说，她因被一群男性单挑而感到尴尬而笑了。实际上，她和电影中的其他女性一样，为了所谓的女性礼节感而牺牲了康拉德。

Even the most redemptive female character, his newly found girlfriend, Jeannine, ultimately abandons him. Again at a restaurant, she tentatively reaches out to him by asking him about his suicide attempt. He responds by saying she is “the first person to ask” such a question, and he begins to answer her in what appears to be the first therapeutic act of communication in the movie. Just then, they are interrupted by a rowdy group of males (mostly the athletes who describe another theme in the film); she reacts by giggling and allowing them to pull her from the table, thus destroying the potential bond between her and Conrad, who is visibly shaken by the incident. In the logic of this scene, she is clearly the one who has failed Conrad after he opens up to her, and later, she tries to explain it by saying she laughed out of embarrassment at being singled out by a group of males. In effect, she, like the other females in the movie, sacrifices Conrad to a so-called feminine sense of propriety.

 

关于女性问题的争论通过康拉德女友的重要性而扩大，她以礼节的名义代表着“弱点”。

The argument about the problem with women is expanded through the significance of Conrad’s girlfriend, who represents “weakness” in the name of propriety.

 

从女性角色的软弱和得体到男性角色需要从那个世界中分离出来，在男性友情中重生的急剧转变。论文的第一部分描述了对这种结合的抑制；本节描述了如何通过拒绝女性来重新发现这种联系。作者的句子中插入了对话短语来阐明要点。

Sharp transition from the weakness and propriety of the female characters to the need for the male characters to separate themselves from that world to be reborn in male camaraderie. The first part of the paper described the suppression of that bonding; this section describes how that bonding can be rediscovered through the rejection of women. Phrases of dialogue are inserted into the writer’s sentences to make the point.

 

在《普通人》中，这种礼节感与女性的弱点结合在一起，这一点在父亲重生为男人的次要情节中得到了最好的体现。在与一位商业伙伴（两人都是慢跑运动员）的谈话中，他对自己未能解雇“在你脸上嚼口香糖”的无能女秘书感到遗憾。当他向康拉德的精神科医生寻求治疗方法来应对妻子的冷漠时，他摆脱了这种新的男性关系，意识到妻子用女性气质支配了他，让他变得多么软弱。（在儿子的葬礼那天，她让他换了衬衫，因为它看起来不太对劲。）父亲发现他需要坚强，他不再爱他的妻子，因为她可能“美丽”且“不可预测”而是“不坚强，不给予”。康拉德通过同一位精神科医生以及他与凯伦“软弱”自杀的对抗，发现自己拥有超强的力量，这就是他在划船事故中幸存下来的原因。这种力量最终让男人们能够驱逐软弱且具有破坏性的母亲，随着她的离开，他们可以自由地在男人的拥抱中结合在一起。

In Ordinary People, this sense of propriety becomes aligned with a feminine weakness that is seen best in the subplot of the father’s rebirth as a man. In his conversation with a business partner (both jogging athletes), he regrets his inability to fire incompetent female secretaries who “crack gum in your face.” And when he turns to Conrad’s psychiatrist while looking for a way to deal with his wife’s coldness, he comes away from this new male bond realizing how weak his wife has made him by dominating him with her femininity. (She made him change his shirt the day of their son’s funeral because it didn’t look right.) The father discovers that he needs to be strong, that he no longer loves his wife because she may be “beautiful” and “unpredictable” but is “not strong, not giving.” Conrad discovers, through the same psychiatrist and his confrontation with the “weak” suicide of Karen, that he has superior strength, which is why he survived the boating accident. That strength is what finally allows the men to banish the weak and destructive mother, and with her departure, they are free to bond in a male embrace.

 

对论点的简洁总结将观点具体化在一个场景和一个镜头中。

A concise summary of the argument crystallizes the point in a single scene and shot.

 

因此，普通人是坚强但不自知的男性，以及因不允许男性与男性建立联系而辜负男性的女性。在这部电影的普通风格中，两个男人交流的镜头成为电影渴望的目标（在结局中达到），而在电影中最具启发性的场景之一，当父亲准备采取行动时母亲和儿子的两张快照，母亲拒绝参加。要点很明显，即使是无意的：如果与男性的亲密两次射门是对诚实现实的考验，那么在《普通人》中，女性显然被排除在它及其所代表的现实之外。

Ordinary people are therefore men who are strong but do not know it and women who fail those men by not allowing them to bond as men. In the ordinary style of this movie, the two-shot of men communicating becomes the longed-for goal of the movie (attained at the conclusion), and in one of the most revealing scenes in the movie, when the father prepares to take a snapshot, a two-shot, of mother and son, the mother refuses to participate. The point is obvious, even if unintentional: If an intimate two-shot with a male is the test of an honest reality, in Ordinary People women are clearly excluded from it and the reality it represents.

 

练习

Exercises

  1. 确定最适合特定电影的方法或方法。根据这种方法写出三到四个段落来讨论该电影。
  2. Identify the approach or method that seems most appropriate for a specific film. Write three or four paragraphs that discuss that film according to that method.
  3. 选取单部影片从两种不同方法的角度进行讨论。为每种方法专门写两段，并展示每种方法如何为该电影提供不同的视角。
  4. Select a single film to discuss from the angles of two different methods. Devote two paragraphs to each method and show how each offers different perspectives on that film.

5

写作风格和结构

5

STYLE AND STRUCTURE IN WRITING

 

也许写电影时最大的诱惑和最常见的危险就是像“在看电影”一样对待你的材料。描述和分析你所看到的内容，就好像它只是一次随意谈话的主题或为你的朋友或同学“先睹为快”，最终不会产生一篇有效且优美的文章。关于任何主题的优秀写作都可以通过轻松的风格来提高，但是电影的即时性的诱惑不应分散您对电影论文所需的关心和准备的注意力。以下指南概述了良好写作的许多基本步骤和工具。如果它们很明显，就让它们简单地起到提醒作用。

Perhaps the greatest temptation and the most common danger in writing about film is to approach your material as if you are simply “at the movies.” Describing and analyzing what you have seen as if it is only the subject of a casual conversation or a “sneak preview” for your friend or classmate will not, finally, result in an effective and polished piece of writing. Good writing about any topic is improved by a relaxed style, but the lure of film’s immediacy should not distract you from the care and preparation that a film essay requires. The following guidelines sketch many of the fundamental steps and tools underlying good writing. If they are obvious, let them act simply as reminders.

在《白天换夜晚》（1973）中，导演弗朗索瓦·特吕弗评论了电影的宏伟构想与计划的具体执行之间不可避免的差距。写电影也是类似的。在这两部作品中，我们想法的最终表达都涉及调整和工作，正如特吕弗在谈到他的电影时所暗示的那样，这些调整和工作可能会改变甚至改进最初的构想。这意味着，最重要的是，执行这些想法的工具（在本例中是有效写作的原则）必须像作者构思这些想法时一样小心谨慎。我们都看过一些基于绝妙创意但由于技术不佳而失败的电影。作家应该警惕类似的错误。

In Day for Night (1973), director François Truffaut comments on the inevitable gap between the grand conception of a film and the nuts-and-bolts execution of that plan. Writing about film is similar. In both, the final expression of our ideas involves adjustments and work that, as Truffaut suggests about his movie, may change and even improve that original conception. This means, above all else, that the tools for executing those ideas—in this case, the principles of effective writing—must be attended to with the same care that the writer took to conceive of those ideas. We have all seen movies that are based on a brilliant idea but fall flat because of poor technique. Writers should be wary of a similar mistake.

当观众使用前面章节中讨论的各种方法和批评词汇来观看和反思电影时，实际撰写文章会变得容易得多。如果一个人有条不紊地遵循这些步骤，那么通常对寻找想法和论点的一些焦虑应该会得到缓解。

When a viewer watches and reflects on a movie using the various approaches and critical vocabulary discussed in the previous chapters, the actual writing of an essay can be considerably easier. Some of the usual anxiety about finding ideas and arguments should be relieved if one methodically follows those steps.

如果你记下了很好的笔记，那么你在“预写”阶段已经走了很长的路。论文的下一个最关键的元素是一个明确的主题——论文——它可以让你从一个可行的角度来理解一部或多部电影。这种明确的重点还将使您能够在有限的页数内进行彻底的分析，同时，沿着足够广泛的路线扩展主题，以吸引读者感兴趣的。即使您的讲师向您介绍了一个一般性主题，您通常也必须重新调整主题，使其更加具体和个性化。在 DW 格里菲斯 (DW Griffith) 的《一个国家的诞生》 (1915)中讨论种族主义对于十页纸的论文来说可能是一个太大的主题。相反，一篇专注于真正次要细节的文章，比如电影中场景中使用的家具，对于一篇长篇文章来说可能过于琐碎，除非巧妙地处理并通过研究来发展。

If you have taken good notes, you have gone a long way in the “prewriting” stage. The next most crucial element of the essay is a clearly focused topic—a thesis—that will allow you to get at the film or films from a workable angle. This clear focus will also allow you to do a thorough analysis in a limited number of pages and, at the same time, expand the topic along broad-enough lines to keep your reader interested. Even if your instructor presents you with a general topic, you will usually have to refocus it so that it is more specific and personal. Discussing racism in D. W. Griffith’s The Birth of a Nation (1915) could prove too large a topic for a ten-page paper. Conversely, an essay focused on a truly minor detail, like the furniture used for one set in that movie, could prove too trivial for a long essay unless handled with dexterity and developed through research.

正如我们所指出的，你的论文的范围和重点将取决于你预见的读者。知情的观众不会对熟悉的情节或“格里菲斯是一位美国电影制片人”之类的信息感兴趣。作者越早确定读者，文章的参数就越早形成。这是撰写电影的关键一步，因为你所说和看到的大部分内容，特别是在第二次放映期间，都将受到这些参数的指导。

The scope and focus of your essay will depend, as we have noted, on the audience you foresee for it. An informed audience will not be interested in a familiar plot or such information as “Griffith was an American filmmaker.” The sooner a writer determines the audience, the sooner the parameters of the essay will start to take shape. This is a critical step in writing about film, because much of what you say and see, particularly during a second screening, will be guided by those parameters.

写作第一阶段的另一个中心任务是概述你的主题。许多熟练的作家不使用大纲，认为它太狭窄了。其他人则认为提纲是绝对必要的，特别是因为电影的转瞬即逝的性质。在最好的情况下，编剧会勾勒出一个大纲，同时将笔记组织成一个连贯的电影观点。大纲可以采取任何形式，从一系列观察和想法到一系列要点，再到正式编号和分段的论证蓝图，并配有标题和副标题。大纲可以为论证的逻辑提供真正的帮助。当您第二次或第三次观看电影时，经过深思熟虑的大纲可能非常有价值。它成为一种取景器，使您能够发现在第一次放映时遗漏的重要细节。这里，在一名学生为托德·海恩斯的《我不在那儿》（2007）撰写的一篇论文的简要大纲中，作者使用了完整的句子来确保完整的想法将定义论证的主要部分（图 5.01）：

Another central task of the first stage of writing is outlining your topic. Many skillful writers do not work with an outline, finding it too constricting. Others find outlining absolutely necessary, especially because of the fleeting nature of a film. Under the best circumstance, a writer sketches out an outline while organizing notes into a coherent point of view on the film. An outline can take any form, ranging from clusters of observations and thoughts to a series of main points to a formally numbered and sectioned blueprint of an argument, complete with headings and subheadings. Outlines can provide real assistance with the logic of an argument. An outline that is clearly thought out can be invaluable when you are viewing a movie for a second or third time. It becomes a kind of viewfinder that enables you to spot significant details missed on the first screening. Here, in one student’s brief outline for a paper on Todd Haynes’s I’m Not There (2007), the writer uses full sentences to make certain that complete ideas will define the main sections of the argument (Figure 5.01):

莎朗·康威

Sharon Conway

 

我不在那儿和身份的发明

I’m Not There and the Invention of Identity

 

I. 虽然托德·海恩斯关于鲍勃·迪伦一生的电影《我不在那儿》乍一看似乎是一部典型的“传记片”，但它引人注目地使用六位不同的演员来代表迪伦，这只是最戏剧性的迹象。对人类身份以及身份如何不断重塑和重塑的更复杂和更广泛的调查。

I. While Todd Haynes’s film about the life of Bob Dylan, I’m Not There, might at first glance appear to be a typical “biopic,” its striking use of six different actors to represent Dylan is only the most dramatic indication of a more complex and wide-ranging investigation of human identity and how identities are constantly being reshaped and reinvented.

 

图 5.01 写一篇关于像《我不在那儿》（2007）这样复杂的电影的文章总是会受益于清晰概述文章逻辑的计划。

Figure 5.01 Writing an essay about a film as complex as I’m Not There (2007) will always benefit from a plan that clearly outlines the logic of the essay.

 

二. 传记片是一种常见的传统电影类型，通常聚焦于历史上的名人。

II. Biopics are a common and traditional film genre focused usually on a famous individual from history.

 

A。传统传记片依靠叙事的连贯性和连续性来表现其主题

a. Traditional biopics rely on narrative coherency and continuity to represent its subject

 

b. 传统音乐传记片的两个例子：《格伦·米勒的故事》(The Glenn Miller Story ) (1953) 和《门》( The Doors ) (1991)

b. Two examples of traditional music biopics: The Glenn Miller Story (1953) and The Doors (1991)

 

三．迪伦的一生呈现出一系列的矛盾和不可预测的变化

III. Dylan’s life appears as a series of contradictions and unpredictable changes

 

A。从流浪汉生活到基督教

a. From life as a hobo to Christianity

 

b. 从迪伦的歌曲中看出迪伦的身份

b. Dylan’s identities through his songs

 

四．《我不在那儿》并没有掩盖迪伦生活中的矛盾和变化，而是将它们庆祝为个人身份的灵活性、创造力和创造力的见证。

IV. Rather than disguise the contradictions and changes in Dylan’s life, I’m Not There celebrates them as a testimony to the flexibility, creativity, and inventiveness of the individual identity.

 

A。六位不同的演员如何塑造不同的迪伦身份

a. How six different actors create different Dylan identities

 

b. 从最大意义上讲，身份如何始终是一种表演

b. How identity is always a performance in the largest sense

 

C。支离破碎的叙事结构和戏剧性的电影风格如何强化发明的动力，成为现代身份的关键

c. How the fragmentary narrative structure and dramatic cinematographic style reinforce that dynamic of invention as the key to modern identities

 

五、结论：因此，海恩斯的电影标题包含了影片的一个略带讽刺意味的关键：而对于许多人来说，难以捉摸的迪伦可能并不“在那里”，因为他似乎经常改变角色和身份，缺乏永久的角色和身份。对于海恩斯来说，独特的自我正是使迪伦成为我们可以改变和成长的许多创造性方式的典范。

V. Conclusion: The title of Haynes’ film thus contains a slightly ironic key to the film: while, for many, the elusive Dylan may not be “there” because he seems to change roles and identities so often, the absence of a permanent, singular self is exactly what, for Haynes, makes Dylan a model for the many creative ways we can change and grow.

 

当论文写出来时，它可能会偏离这个大纲，并且肯定会变得更加明确和具体。然而，任何类型的大纲都可以成为您构建更复杂想法的基础。

When the paper is written, it will probably depart from this outline and will certainly become more defined and more specific. Yet, an outline of any kind can be the foundation on which you build more complex ideas.

正确的话

THE RIGHT WORDS

 

具体语言

Concrete Language

论文的实际写作涉及所有写作的基本准则，并且对于经常排练和回忆很重要。因为影评人是通过语言重新创作一部电影和对它的看法，所以敏感而准确的词语使用至关重要。具体性是一些最好的电影写作的核心，很大程度上是因为读者非常依赖场景或序列的可视化。此外，作者描述他或她所看到的内容的准确性通常是表达观点的最有说服力的方式。在看过维尔纳·赫尔佐格的《海市蜃楼》（1971）中的一个引人注目的片段后，一个缺乏经验的作家可能会忍不住写道，“有一系列奇怪的镜头，疯狂的对话和奇怪的人物。” 一位经验丰富的作家，就像下面这段话的作者一样，用生动具体的成语来赋予这些形象以活力来评论它们：

The actual writing of the essay involves guidelines that are basic to all writing and are important to rehearse and recall frequently. Because a film critic is recreating a film and a perspective on it through language, sensitive and accurate use of words is paramount. Concreteness is the heart of some of the best film writing, largely because the reader depends so much on the visualization of a scene or sequence. Also, the accuracy with which a writer describes what he or she sees is often the most convincing way to make a point. After seeing a striking sequence from Werner Herzog’s Fata Morgana (1971), an inexperienced writer might be tempted to write, “There was a series of strange shots, with crazy dialogue and odd characters.” An experienced writer, like the author of the following passage, revitalizes the images with a lively and concrete idiom to comment on them:

最强烈的序列可能是人间地狱的灾难性隐喻：一个紧张症鼓手和一个俗气的女钢琴家在妓院的一个小舞台上演奏一首她们已经演奏了一千遍的曲子，没有任何情感，无休止地走调。“在黄金时代，夫妻和睦相处，”评论员在正面拍摄他们的照片时说道，人文主义电影制片人必须展现出所有仁慈的残酷。一切。曲子结束时，他们仍然一动不动。没有掌声。（沃格尔 76）

The strongest sequence may be a catastrophic metaphor of hell on earth: a catatonic drummer and a tacky female pianist on a tiny stage in a brothel perform a piece they have played a thousand times without any emotion, endlessly, off-key. “In the Golden Age, man and wife live in harmony,” the commentator says, as they are photographed head-on, with all the merciful cruelty of a humanist filmmaker who must show everything. At the end of the piece, they remain immobile. There is no applause. (Vogel 76)

 

外延与内涵

Denotation and Connotation

外延和内涵是作者可以有效或无效使用的其他修辞工具。外延是单词的字典含义；因此电影和电影具有相同的外延。如果你指的是顺序，就不要说shot；如果您指的是好莱坞风格，请不要满足于古典风格，因为后者可能表示特定类型的好莱坞或欧洲电影。精确：说出你的意思，避免使用没有什么指示价值的词语，比如“事物”和“方面”。

Denotations and connotations are other rhetorical tools that can be used effectively or ineffectively by a writer. A denotation is the dictionary meaning of a word; thus film and movie have the same denotation. If you mean sequence, don’t say shot; if you mean Hollywood style, don’t be satisfied with classical style, because the latter term could indicate a specific kind of Hollywood or European movie. Be precise: Say what you mean and avoid words that have little denotative value, like thing and aspect.

内涵是您使用的单词的任何关联或含义。对于许多人来说，电影具有复杂的知识内涵，而电影则具有与大众娱乐相关的内涵。好莱坞和古典都带有许多内涵（例如商业或机构），作家在使用它们时应该注意它们。Keystone Kops 的创始人麦克·森尼特 (Mack Sennett) 警告人们不要使用不当的批评性语言，他说他的电影中有“奇迹和奇迹”，“再多昂贵的语法也无法解释”。

A connotation is any association or implication of the word you use. Film has for many people sophisticated, intellectual connotations, while movie has connotations associated with mass entertainment. Both Hollywood and classical carry a number of connotations (commercial or establishment, for instance) that a writer should be aware of when using them. Mack Sennett, the founder of the Keystone Kops, warned against inappropriate critical language when he said there “was a wonder and a miracle” in his films which “no amount of expensive grammar can explain.”

语气

Tone

一篇文章的语气可能有很大差异，从一些报纸评论家的俏皮讽刺，到一些电影理论家的自命不凡的说教主义。语气是你所使用的词语以及如何使用它们的总效果，每一篇文章都建立了一种语气，或“作家的声音”。注意你在论证中所采用的语气；有些语气不如其他语气合适。讽刺、幽默和愤怒是表达引人入胜且令人信服的论点时最无效的语气。一篇论文的开头是：“这部所谓的艺术电影永远无法吸引普通观众”，立即指出作者是一个过于偏见而无法做出平衡判断的人。可以用更平衡的语气表达同样的观点：“艺术电影的问题在于，它们可能会疏远习惯于更容易理解的故事的公众。” 作家需要在随意的语气和正式的语气之间找到适当的折衷方案。这种妥协的性质将取决于你和你论文的具体主题。太多的俚语是行不通的，你通常不使用的自命不凡的词语也行不通。一个注重语气的作者会在整篇文章中保持一致的语气，不会在句子之间或段落之间改变语气。

The tone of an essay can vary considerably, from the jaunty sarcasm of some newspaper reviewers, to the pretentious didacticism of some film theoreticians. Tone is the total effect of the words you use and how you use them, and every essay establishes a tone, or “writer’s voice.” Be conscious of the tone of voice you are adopting in your argument; some tones are less appropriate than others. Sarcasm, humor, and anger are among the least effective tones to use in formulating an engaging and convincing argument. A paper that begins, “This so-called art film could never appeal to a normal audience,” immediately identifies the writer as someone too prejudiced to make balanced judgments. The same point can be made with a more balanced tone: “The problem with art films is that they may alienate a public used to a more accessible story.” A writer needs to find the right compromise between a casual voice and a formal one. The nature of that compromise will depend on you and the specific topic of your essay. Too much slang won’t work, nor will pretentious words that you normally don’t use. A writer conscious of tone will maintain a consistent one throughout the essay, not changing tone of voice from sentence to sentence or paragraph to paragraph.

最后，请注意不要在单词周围使用引号来试图创造一种间接或巧妙的语气或讽刺。如果你的意思是一个角色的行为表现得像一个占主导地位和压迫性的男性刻板印象，那么不要仅仅满足于简单地写他是“一个‘真正解放’的人”。以这种方式使用的引号很少能解释任何事情。他们通常会模糊你的意思。

Finally, beware of using quotation marks around words to try to create an indirect or clever tone or sarcasm. If you mean that a character behaves like a dominant and oppressive male stereotype, don’t be satisfied by simply writing that he is “a ‘really liberated’ guy.” Quotation marks used in this way rarely explain anything. They usually blur what you mean.

重复和陈词滥调

Repetitions and Clichés

词语使用的一个常见困难是保持措辞的新鲜和多样化。经验丰富的作家依靠重复关键词来强调重点和连续性。但是，懒惰或不受控制的重复文字会导致散文乏味：在短文中重复提及“导演”可能会令人恼火。您可以通过替换专有名称（Romero）或冠词（he）来轻松纠正这种重复。当您发现自己陷入不必要的重复时，请改变您的描述和短语，但不要使用不适合您风格的术语来强制进行更改。

A common difficulty in word usage is to keep the diction fresh and varied. Experienced writers rely on the repetition of key words for emphasis and continuity. But the lazy or uncontrolled repetition of words results in tedious prose: Repeated references to “the director” throughout a short passage can be irritating. You can easily correct such repetition by substituting a proper name (Romero) or an article (he). When you find yourself locked into unnecessary repetitions, vary your descriptions and phrases, but don’t force a change by using terms that do not fit your style.

依赖陈词滥调的倾向是同一问题的一个版本：用快速且未经审查的语言使用来代替精确的表达。我们经常在电影评论中看到的歌曲片段和俏皮话是这种陈词滥调的极端版本​​。它们表明，像大片或每个人都应该看的电影这样的术语变得毫无意义。

The tendency to depend on clichés is a version of the same problem: the substitution of a quick and unexamined use of language for precise expression. The snatches of jingles and pat quips that we often find in movie reviews are an extreme version of this use of clichés. They indicate how meaningless terms like blockbuster or a film everyone should see become.

在接下来的段落中，罗宾·伍德使用了我们以前都听过的几个短语（“非常有问题”或“非常遗憾”），他围绕能量、荒谬、艺术家和暴力等词的重复来阐述他的观点。然而，伍德在这里展示了常见的表达方式如何有助于轻松的语气，以及单词的重复有时如何导致思想上的更细微的区别：

In the following passage, Robin Wood employs several phrases we have all heard before (“very much in question” or “a great pity that”), and he builds his point around the repetition of words like energy, ridiculous, artist, and violence. Here, however, Wood demonstrates how common expressions can contribute to a relaxed tone and how the repetition of a word sometimes leads to finer distinctions in thought:

萨姆·佩金帕的作品的价值仍然受到很大质疑。它的强度不是。表达这种能量和激情、这种对个人冲动的承诺的艺术至少需要尊重的关注。《狂野的一群》（1969）和《稻草狗》（1971），无论人们对它们的评价如何，都具有坦率和力量的结合，这表明艺术家并不害怕显得可笑；他们的作品充满了力量。那些自称觉得这些电影只不过是可笑的人可能正紧张地把自己与电影中凶猛而富有感染力的能量隔离开来。与此同时，人们可能会从一开始就评论说，在公众和大多数评论家眼中，佩金帕的温和且可以说是最好的电影……非常遗憾，却被电影中壮观而爆炸性的暴力所掩盖。更臭名昭著的作品——暴力无疑是他艺术个性的一个主要组成部分，但绝不是整个故事。(771–72)

The value of Sam Peckinpah’s work is still very much in question; its intensity is not. And art that expresses such energy and passion, such commitment to personal impulse, commands, at least, respectful attention. The Wild Bunch (1969) and Straw Dogs (1971), whatever one’s estimate of them, have that combination of candor and force which announces an artist who is not afraid of appearing ridiculous; those who profess to find them no more than ridiculous are perhaps nervously insulating themselves from the films’ ferocious and contagious energy. At the same time, one may comment at the outset that it is a great pity that, in the eyes of the public and most critics, Peckinpah’s gentler and arguably finest films...have been so overshadowed by the spectacular and explosive violence of the more notorious works—a violence that is certainly a major component of his artistic personality, but by no means the whole story. (771–72)

 

有效句子

EFFECTIVE SENTENCES

 

经济

Economy

作家应该瞄准两个关键的文体目标：经济和有趣。节约意味着准确地说出您需要说的所有内容，并减少不添加任何信息或不具有文体目的的词语和表达方式。

A writer should aim at two key stylistic goals: to be economical and to be interesting. Being economical means saying precisely all that you need to say and cutting words and expressions that add no information or serve no stylistic purpose.

许多作家陷入文字困境，无法想出充分表达思想的句子。当这种情况发生时，回到大纲并用特定的图像和序列来讨论你的想法将有助于开始句子的流动。然而，相反的问题也同样麻烦：有时候，一个作家随意地吐出一些文字，在这个过程中就失去了他或她的句子的意义。挑剔的人会注意到以下句子不必要的冗长：

Many writers get stuck for words and are not able to come up with sentences that adequately express a thought. When this happens, going back to an outline and talking through your ideas in terms of specific images and sequences will help start the flow of sentences. The inverse problem, however, is equally troublesome: Sometimes a writer who spews out words in haphazard fashion loses the meaning of his or her sentence in the process. A critical eye notices that the following sentence is unnecessarily wordy:

莉娜·维尔特米勒的这部影片《一扫而空》（ Swept Away ，1975）中有许多困难且要求很高的场景，这赋予了电影歌剧般的品质。

There are many difficult and demanding scenes in this film by Lina Wertmüller, Swept Away (1975), which give the movie an operatic quality.

 

削减和节约，作者将其修改为：

Cutting and economizing, the writer would revise it to the following:

莉娜·维尔特米勒的《一扫而光》（1975）是一部要求很高的歌剧电影。

Lina Wertmüller’s Swept Away (1975) is a demanding, operatic film.

 

通常，您可以通过注意冗余、冗长的结构（例如“有”）、被动语态的可纠正用法（“埃德加·赖特指导斯科特朝圣者对抗世界[2010]”来消除这种冗长的内容，而不是“斯科特·朝圣者对抗世界[2010] 由埃德加·赖特执导”），或者只是可以删除而不改变句子含义的单词。回顾下面这段话，作者应该已经意识到它的极端冗长了：

You can usually eliminate wordiness of this kind by watching out for redundancies, wordy constructions (for example, “there is”), correctable uses of the passive voice (“Edgar Wright directed Scott Pilgrim vs. the World [2010],” instead of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World [2010] was directed by Edgar Wright”), or merely words that could be deleted without changing the sense of a sentence. Reviewing the following passage, the writer should have recognized its extreme wordiness:

尽管它在电影交流方式中发挥着核心且明显重要的作用，但电影学术中最被忽视和忽视的研究领域之一被证明是电影对话的使用方式及其功能如何变化的许多变化和显着差异快速地穿越历史，戏剧性地从一个导演到另一个导演。

Despite its central and obviously important role in the way a movie communicates, one of the most overlooked and ignored areas of study in film scholarship is proving to be the many variations and appreciable differences in how movie dialogue has been used and how its functions have changed rapidly through history and dramatically from director to director.

 

在不牺牲信息的情况下，更好、更简洁的版本如下：

Without sacrificing information, the better, more succinct version reads as follows:

尽管电影对话起着核心作用，但大多数学者都忽视了它在电影中的演变以及不同导演对它的不同用途。

Despite the central role of film dialogue, most scholarship has overlooked its evolution in films and its various uses by different directors.

 

不同的句子结构

Varied Sentence Structures

有趣的风格需要的不仅仅是一个有趣的主题。它还需要一种以尽可能强烈的方式吻合和强调你的材料的句子来呈现主题，因为保持读者的兴趣——始终是任何作家的目标——需要句子以最有效的形式呈现你的分析。有些作者“突发奇想”，以生动的散文自然而闲聊地表达自己的观点。然而，我们大多数人往往会陷入文体惯例，其中学生写作中最常见的是简单陈述句的单一使用。为了摆脱这些陈规，我们使用了几种文体策略来使我们的句子更加灵活和有力。

An interesting style requires more than just an interesting subject to write about. It also requires a way of presenting the subject in sentences that dovetail and emphasize your material in the strongest way possible, because holding a reader’s interest—always a goal of any writer—requires sentences that present your analysis in its most effective form. Some authors “shoot from the hip,” naturally and chattily presenting their points in lively prose. Most of us, however, tend to get stuck in stylistic ruts, of which the most common in student writing is the unvaried use of simple declarative sentences. To escape these ruts, we use several stylistic strategies to make our sentences more flexible and emphatic.

相似之处引起人们对两个或多个事实或想法之间的关系或等式的关注：

Parallels draw attention to the relations between or the equation of two or more facts or ideas:

好莱坞电影有三个目的：娱乐、赚钱、宣传生活方式。[不要写“为了娱乐、赚钱和宣传一种生活方式。”]

Hollywood movies have three purposes: to entertain, to make money, and to advertise a way of life. [Do not write “to entertain, to make money, and advertising a way of life.”]

 

协调用连词（and、but、or等​​）连接两个相关的句子，结果是一个复合句和句型的节奏变化：

Coordination joins two related sentences with a conjunction (and, but, or, and so on), the result being a compound sentence and a rhythmic variation in your sentence patterns:

好莱坞电影主要是为了娱乐和赚钱，更不明显的是，它们的目的是宣传一种生活方式。

Hollywood movies are meant primarily to entertain and to make money, and less obviously, they aim to advertise a way of life.

 

从属将两个或多个点或句子组合成一个复杂的句子，重新分配这些想法以弱化某些点并强调其他点：

Subordination combines two or more points or sentences into a single complex sentence that redistributes those ideas to deemphasize some points and emphasize others:

尽管好莱坞电影的目的是娱乐和宣传一种生活方式，但它们的主要功能是赚钱。

Although Hollywood movies aim to entertain and to advertise a way of life, their primary function is to make money.

 

在下面的句子中，作者陷入了句子结构，行文断断续续，令人厌烦：

In the following sentences, the writer has gotten stuck in sentence structures, and the writing is choppy and tiresome:

英格玛·伯格曼是瑞典首屈一指的电影制片人。自 1944 年以来，他一直活跃在电影和戏剧领域。他最著名的电影可能是《第七封印》（1957），这部电影戏剧化地表现了典型的伯格曼对神学和社会焦虑的担忧。他视觉上最复杂的电影是《女神异闻录》（1966），它探讨了与图像、个性和电影具体相关的焦虑。

Ingmar Bergman is the premier Swedish filmmaker. He has been active in film and theater since 1944. His most famous movie is probably The Seventh Seal (1957), and this film dramatizes typical Bergman concerns with theological and social angst. His most visually complicated film is Persona (1966), and it examines that angst as it relates specifically to images, personalities, and the cinema.

 

作者修改了这些句子，通过平行、协调和从属关系，更有效、更经济地传达了材料：

Revising these sentences, the writer communicates the material far more effectively and economically through parallels, coordination, and subordination:

英格玛·伯格曼 (Ingmar Bergman) 自 1944 年以来一直活跃在电影和戏剧领域，是瑞典首屈一指的电影制片人。虽然《第七封印》（1957）是他最著名的电影，但视觉效果最复杂的是《女神异闻录》；第一个戏剧性地戏剧化了伯格曼对神学和社会焦虑的典型关注，第二个则审视了与图像、个性和电影相关的焦虑。

Active in film and theater since 1944, Ingmar Bergman is the premier Swedish filmmaker. Although The Seventh Seal (1957) is his most famous movie, his most visually complicated is Persona; while the first dramatizes typical Bergman concerns with theological and social angst, the second examines that angst as it relates to images, personalities, and the cinema.

 

在使这些句子更加简洁的同时，作者也使它们更加强调：在第一句中，将有关伯格曼过去的不太重要的信息置于次要地位；在第二部中，通过创建平行短语来比较两部电影，并将不太有趣的《第七封印》置于从属地位。原来的句子可以通过多种方式重组。它们的结构不仅应由经济性决定，还应由作者想要强调的内容决定。

In making these sentences a bit more economical, the writer has also made them more emphatic: in the first sentence, by subordinating less important information about Bergman’s past; in the second, by creating parallel phrases that compare the two films and by subordinating the less interesting Seventh Seal. The original sentences could have been restructured in many ways. Their structure should be determined not only by economy but also by what the writer wishes to emphasize.

当您根据笔记和思考撰写初稿时，最好不要费力寻找确切的单词或最经济的短语。在这个阶段，您的目标是尽可能快速、完整地将您的想法写在纸上。纠正和润色句子的时间通常是当你修改草稿时，此时你应该对如何改进你的写作更加敏感。

When you are composing your first draft from notes and reflections, it is probably best not to labor over finding the exact word or the most economical phrase. At that stage, your objective is to get your ideas down on paper as quickly and as completely as you can. The time for correcting and polishing sentences is usually when you revise that draft, when you should be more sensitive to how you can improve your writing.

段落连贯

COHERENT PARAGRAPHS

 

在电影中，构成场景的元素（演员、道具等）成为镜头的一部分；许多镜头发展成一个场景，然后发展成一个序列，序列可以组合起来形成一个叙述。一篇文章的成长可以根据类似的方案来概念化。也许写作从来都不是那么简略，然而，正如准确而足智多谋的词语使用会产生生动的句子一样，结构良好的句子也会成为统一和连贯的段落。

In a movie, the elements that compose the mise-en-scène (actors, props, and so on) become part of a shot; many shots develop into a scene and then a sequence, and sequences can be combined to form a narrative. The growth of an essay can be conceptualized according to a similar scheme. Perhaps writing is never quite so schematic, yet, just as an accurate and resourceful use of words leads to lively sentences, well-constructed sentences become unified and coherent paragraphs.

好段落没有固定的长度，给定论文也没有绝对正确的段落数。一篇五百字的文章通常有四到五个段落，而一个展开的段落通常至少包含四到五个句子。然而，段落的数量及其各自的长度将取决于你的论点中的想法。理想情况下，论文中的段落数量来自于全面且构思良好的大纲。如果你只有两三个段落或非常短的段落，那么你的论点可能缺乏好的想法，或者这些想法可能没有经过充分考虑或得到具体支持。（尽管新闻写作，例如报纸评论，经常依赖于非常短的段落，但这通常不是适合批判性文章的段落。）

There is no set length for a good paragraph nor is there an absolutely correct number of paragraphs for a given paper. A five-hundred-word essay normally has four or five paragraphs, and a developed paragraph usually contains at least four or five sentences. However, the number of paragraphs and their respective lengths will depend on the ideas in your argument. Ideally, the number of paragraphs in an essay follows from a thorough and well-conceived outline. If you have only two or three paragraphs or very short paragraphs, your argument may be short on good ideas, or those ideas may not have been thought out fully or supported concretely. (Although journalistic writing, such as a newspaper review, frequently relies on very short paragraphs, this is usually not the kind of paragraphing appropriate for a critical essay.)

无论该段落有几个句子还是十几个句子，它都必须包含一个清晰地将句子统一起来的想法。这种统一的思想应该在每个段落的主题句中明确表达，该句子明确了该段落的指导思想。当您将这句话放在段落的开头时，您可以帮助读者遵循整个段落的思路。有时你的主题句将是第二句。主题句很少是不必要的，并且在大多数情况下，您不应该使用简单复述某些情节的情节句来代替主题句。一般来说，主题句锚定段落并宣布其中心思想，即使该思想随后是通过两个或三个其他相关思想发展起来的。请注意，以下段落的中心思想（“西方英雄的休息”）在第一句中得到了明确的体现。另请注意作者如何通过适当放置的“对比”来创建平滑过渡（来自上一段关于黑帮电影的内容）：

Whether the paragraph has a few sentences or a dozen, it must contain an idea that clearly unites its sentences. This unifying idea should be made explicit in the topic sentence of each paragraph, a sentence that pinpoints the guiding concept of the paragraph. When you locate this sentence at the beginning of a paragraph, you help the reader to follow the train of thought throughout the paragraph. Sometimes your topic sentence will be the second sentence. Very rarely is a topic sentence unnecessary, and in most cases, you should not use, in place of a topic sentence, a plot sentence that simply retells some of the plot. Generally, a topic sentence anchors the paragraph and announces its central idea, even if that idea is then developed through two or three other related ideas. Note in the following paragraph that the central idea (“the repose of the Western hero”) is clearly identified in the first sentence. Note also how the author creates a smooth transition (from the previous paragraph about the gangster film) through the appropriately placed “by contrast”:

相比之下，西方英雄是一个安宁的人物。他像黑帮一样孤独，而且有些忧郁。但他的忧郁来自于“简单”地认识到生活不可避免地是严肃的，而不是来自于他自己气质的不相称。他的孤独是有机的，不是由他的处境强加给他的，而是亲密地属于他并证明了他的完整性。歹徒必须暴力地拒绝他人或将他们暴力地吸引到他身边。西方人并不是因此被迫去寻求爱；而是被迫去寻求爱。也许他已经准备好接受它，但他的要求从来不会超过它所能给予的，我们经常看到他处于爱情至多是无关紧要的境地。如果他爱着一个女人，她通常无法理解他的动机；他发现无法向她解释“反对”这些东西是没有意义的：它们属于他的世界。（战秀137）

The Western hero, by contrast, is a figure of repose. He resembles the gangster in being lonely and to some degree melancholy. But his melancholy comes from the “simple” recognition that life is unavoidably serious, not from the disproportions of his own temperament. And his loneliness is organic, not imposed on him by his situation but belonging to him intimately and testifying to his completeness. The gangster must reject others violently or draw them violently to him. The Westerner is not thus compelled to seek love; he is prepared to accept it, perhaps, but he never asks of it more than it can give, and we see him constantly in situations where love is at best an irrelevance. If there is a woman he loves, she is usually unable to understand his motives; and he finds it impossible to explain to her that there is no point in being “against” these things: they belong to his world. (Warshow 137)

 

这里分别描述了西方英雄的特征：他的人生观、他的孤独感、他对爱与暴力的感受。然而，每一个都可以被提及并服从于他的“休息”的中心主题。与大多数优秀的段落一样，这一段的特点是有一个概括而清晰的开头，然后通过具体的要点得出一个强有力的、强调的结论。

Here, characteristics of the Western hero are described separately: his perspective on life, his breed of loneliness, his feelings about love and violence. Each, however, can be referred to and is subordinate to the central topic of his “repose.” Like most good paragraphs, this one features a general and clear beginning and then moves through specific points to a strong and emphatic conclusion.

下一个段落示例具有更复杂的结构。请注意它成功地使用了过渡（“更一般地说”、“但是”、“但是”等）来连接句子的各个部分、单独的句子和单独的段落：

The next example of paragraphing has a more complicated structure. Note its successful use of transitions (“In more general terms,” “yet,” “however,” and so on) to connect parts of sentences, separate sentences, and separate paragraphs:

就音质而言，四十年代中期的平均电影，无论是在好莱坞、法国还是英国，都比二十年代末的原始作品有了显着的进步。然而，更一般地说，四十年代的电影仍然是早期电影的直系后代。该过程的每一步都得到了改进——从麦克风到打印机，从放大器到扬声器——但基本的光学记录和打印技术基本保持不变。直到战后，得益于德国战时技术，随着磁记录技术的完善，整个录音行业，特别是电影音轨才取得了巨大的飞跃。然而，与所有重要的技术发展一样，磁记录革命立即遇到了经济阻力。毫无疑问，磁记录更容易，使用更轻，更移动的设备，成本更低，并且产生明显更好的结果；然而，剧院不具备播放用磁条代替传统光学音轨的电影的能力。正如好莱坞将声音的到来推迟了数年一样，出于经济原因，它也将更好的声音的到来推迟了数十年。在磁记录技术普遍应用四分之一个世纪后，很少有剧院（通常只有高价、首映、大城市的品种）配备了磁音响设备。具有讽刺意味的是，多年来，使用超级音响设备的普通业余电影制作人都拥有比附近电影院更好、更先进的声音再现设施。

In terms of sound quality, the average film of the mid-forties, whether in Hollywood, France, or England, represented a significant improvement on the original efforts of the late twenties. In more general terms, however, the films of the forties remained the direct descendants of those earlier films. Every step of the process had been improved—from microphones to printers, from amplifiers to loudspeakers—yet the fundamental optical recording and printing technology remained basically the same. Not until after the war, thanks in part to German wartime technology, did the sound recording industry in general and the film sound track in particular take a quantum leap forward with the perfection of magnetic recording techniques. As with all important technological developments, however, the magnetic recording revolution met with immediate economic resistance. There was no question that magnetic recording was easier, used lighter, more mobile equipment, cost less, and produced decidedly better results; theaters, however, were not equipped to play films which substituted a magnetic strip for the traditional optical sound track. Just as Hollywood delayed the coming of sound for years, it has for economic reasons delayed the coming of better sound for decades. Over a quarter of a century after the general availability of magnetic recording technology very few theaters (usually only the high priced, first run, big city variety) are equipped with magnetic sound equipment. Ironically, for years, the average amateur filmmaker working with super-sound equipment has possessed better and more advanced sound reproduction facilities than the neighborhood cinema.

 

尽管如此，好莱坞还是能够以另一种方式利用新技术。尽管世界各地的电影制片人继续使用光学声音进行发行拷贝，但他们很早就开始以磁性模式进行自己的所有录音（到 1971 年底，好莱坞 75% 的原始制作录音、音乐配乐和配音都是由在磁记录设备上完成）。播放结束后，磁记录将音轨与图像以及图像的光学技术进一步分离。现在，可以轻松地独立于图像单独录制、混合和重新混合任意数量的声源（从而简化了现在通常与新的宽屏幕格式结合使用的立体声的操作）。（奥特曼48）

Nevertheless, Hollywood was able to capitalize on the new technology in another way. Though filmmakers around the world continued to use optical sound for distribution prints, they very early began to do all their own recording in the magnetic mode (by the end of 1971, 75 percent of Hollywood’s original production recording, music scoring, and dubbing was being done on magnetic recording equipment). Finishing what the playback had begun, magnetic recording divorced the sound track still further from the image and from the image’s optical technology. Now, any number of sound sources could easily be separately recorded, mixed, and remixed independently of the image (thus simplifying the manipulation of stereophonic sound now often coupled with the new wide-screen formats). (Altman 48)

 

这些段落相当复杂，部分是因为提供了大量信息，部分是因为第一段中有多个想法在起作用。具体来说，作者就像一枚双面硬币一样讨论两个想法：一方面是二战后时期声音技术的进步（在开头句中已经宣布）；另一方面，好莱坞未能实现这些进步。

These are rather complicated paragraphs, in part because a great deal of information is proffered and in part because more than one idea is at work in the first paragraph. Specifically, the writer is discussing two ideas like a kind of two-sided coin: On one side, there are the advances made in sound technology in the post–World War II period (announced in the opening sentence); on the other side, there is the failure of Hollywood to implement those advances.

作者通过绘制战前到现代的发展逻辑来平衡和对比这两种发展，并通过“然而”等关键过渡词将它们连接起来。还要注意这种来回的进展是如何巧妙地集中在第一段的中间，以“毫无疑问”开头的句子；这句话有一个平行结构，它的两半被分号分开，每一边代表该段落所表达的双重观点的一个版本。此外，大量的具体细节和历史事实也增强了该段落的连贯性和生动性。（当你写的论文更具分析性而不是历史性时，这类信息可能不是必要的、可用的或适当的，但总是试图用电影中确凿的事实或具体细节来巩固和充实你的主题句的想法。 ）

The author balances and contrasts these two developments by mapping the logic of their progression from the prewar period to modern times, and he connects them through key transition words like however. Notice also how this back-and-forth progression is deftly focused in the middle of the first paragraph with the sentence beginning “There was no question”; this sentence has a parallel structure, its two halves divided by the semicolon and each side representing a version of the twofold point the paragraph is making. Also, the coherence and vividness of the paragraph are enhanced by numerous concrete details and historical facts. (When you are writing papers more analytical than historical, this kind of information may not be as necessary, available, or appropriate, but always attempt to solidify and flesh out the idea of your topic sentence with hard facts or concrete details from the film.)

最后，这篇文章展示了两个段落之间的巧妙过渡，打开了“尽管如此”一词和“以另一种方式”短语。确保句子之间和段落之间的过渡能够增加文章的清晰度、连贯性和流畅性。使用专门适合此目的的单词或短语，例如“进一步”或“事实上”，是增加连贯性的一种方法；第二种方法是重复上一段末尾的关键词，就像本文作者对好莱坞和技术所做的那样。始终确保您的读者能够遵循从一个段落到下一个段落的逻辑过渡。

Finally, the passage demonstrates a neat transition between the two paragraphs that turns on the word nevertheless and the phrase “in another way.” Make sure your transitions between sentences and between paragraphs add clarity, coherence, and fluidity to your essay. Using words or phrases specifically suited for this purpose, like furthermore or in fact, is one way to increase coherence; a second method is repeating key words from the end of the previous paragraph, as this writer does with Hollywood and technology. Always make sure that your reader can follow a logical transition from one paragraph to the next.

介绍性段落

INTRODUCTORY PARAGRAPHS

 

我们中的许多人——比如《安妮·霍尔》（ Annie Hall，1977）中的阿尔维·辛格（Alvy Singer），即使迟到几分钟也拒绝入场——都知道开始是多么重要。尽管许多好莱坞电影很快就陷入了平庸的故事和风格，但前十分钟可以提供整个体验中最迷人和最具创新性的序列（这是让您坐在座位上的一种方式）。开头对于任何演讲都至关重要，无论你的论文有多长，正确写好第一段可能是对你的论文最重要的修改。

Many of us—like Alvy Singer, who in Annie Hall (1977) refuses to enter a movie even a few minutes late—know how important a beginning is. Although many Hollywood films settle quickly into mediocre stories and styles, the first ten minutes can provide the most captivating and innovative sequence of the entire experience (which is a way of keeping you in your seat). Beginnings are crucial to any presentation, and no matter how long your essay will be, getting that first paragraph right could be the most important revision of your essay.

如果一篇文章要传达信息或表达观点，就必须引起读者的兴趣，而介绍性段落是首先应该激发读者兴趣的地方。以一连串陈词滥调开始你的论文——弗兰克·卡普拉是一位美国导演，他的电影很受欢迎，等等——不太可能鼓励你的读者继续阅读。即使当读者（比如你的导师）不得不读完一篇开头平淡的文章时，第一段也会对你的工作产生期望。第一段是理想的地方让你的读者清楚地了解你的主题是什么以及你打算如何发展它：论文陈述准确而具体地说明了论文的论点是什么。即使在冗长而雄心勃勃的文章中，这个方向也被明确宣布为对读者的路标和挑衅：

An essay must hold a reader’s interest if it is to communicate information or make a point, and the introductory paragraph is where that interest should first be piqued. Starting your paper with a string of commonplaces—that Frank Capra was an American director, that his films were very popular, and so on—is not likely to encourage your reader to continue reading. Even when a reader (say, your instructor) is obliged to finish reading an essay with a dull beginning, that first paragraph creates an expectation about your work. The first paragraph is the ideal place to give your reader a clear sense of what your topic is and how you intend to develop it: the thesis statement that tells exactly and specifically what is the argument of the essay. Even in long and ambitious essays, that direction is clearly announced as a signpost and provocation for the reader:

20 世纪 30 年代末，公众对好莱坞的讨论发生了变化。偏僻城镇的牧师仍然可以通过在银幕上谴责罪恶来煽动群众，各地的法官和改革者仍然坚持认为电影导致易受影响的年轻人犯罪。然而，在学术界、文学界以及主要报纸和杂志中，电影制片人被视为拥有创造国家神话和梦想的力量的人，受到更多的尊重、敬畏甚至嫉妒。（斯克拉195）

In the late 1930s, public discussion about Hollywood changed. Clergymen in backwater towns could still raise a crowd by railing against sin on the silver screen, and judges and reformers here and there continued to maintain that movies led impressionable youth to crime. Among academics and in literary circles, however, and in the principal newspapers and magazines, the moviemakers were regarded with considerably more respect, awe and even envy, as the possessors of the power to create the nation’s myths and dreams. (Sklar 195)

 

这篇文章的标题“文化神话的形成：沃尔特·迪士尼和弗兰克·卡普拉”吸引了许多读者的注意，他们认识这两个名字，但不一定将他们放在共同点上。然而，与所有好的开头一样，介绍性段落并不简单地重申该标题（“本文将讨论沃尔特·迪士尼和弗兰克·卡普拉电影中的文化神话”）。相反，它用更普遍、同时更具体的术语来介绍其主题。该段落从特定的历史参考（1930 年代末）开始，描述了那些认为电影无聊的人和那些认为电影是重要文化媒介的人之间争论的具体历史转变。以这场辩论为背景，该段落转向了关于迪士尼和卡普拉电影创造社会神话的力量的论文。

The essay’s title, “The Making of Cultural Myths: Walt Disney and Frank Capra,” catches the attention of many readers who recognize both names but would not necessarily place them on common ground. As with all good openings, however, the introductory paragraph does not simply restate that title (“This essay will discuss cultural myth in the movies of Walt Disney and Frank Capra”). Instead, it introduces its topic in terms that are more general and, at the same time, more concrete. Starting with a specific historical reference (the late 1930s), the paragraph describes a specific historical transition in the debate between those who thought the movies were frivolous and those who believed they were an important cultural medium. With that debate as a background, the paragraph moves to its thesis about the power of the movies of Disney and Capra to create social myths.

注意：无论您在开始撰写第一段之前还是在完成最终草稿之后制定标题，始终使标题成为您第一段中的信息丰富且有吸引力的条目：它应该足够广泛，以表明您的主题范围，但足够具体以引起读者的兴趣。对于前面的例子来说，“文化神话”这个标题太笼统了。“沃尔特·迪士尼和弗兰克·卡普拉”就太古怪和不清楚了。

NOTE: Whether you formulate a title before you begin writing this first paragraph or after you have finished a final draft, always make the title an informative and enticing entry into your first paragraph: It should be broad enough to suggest the scope of your topic but specific enough to get your reader interested. “Cultural Myths” would have been far too general a title for the previous example; “Walt Disney and Frank Capra” would have been too quirky and unclear.

开头段落应明确研究对象（此处为 1930 年代末的电影制作人）和作者关注的主题（此处为历史和文化神话）。通常，重点是对特定电影或电影部分的分析。您可以通过从一般命题转向具体的论点陈述来组织第一段。或者，如最后一个示例所示，您可以从具体示例转向您的论文将要发展的更一般（但不是太一般）的论文。

An opening paragraph should identify the object of study (here, moviemakers of the late 1930s) and the topic the writer is focusing on (here, history and cultural myths). Often, the focus is the analysis of a particular film or part of a film. You can organize a first paragraph by moving from a general proposition to a specific statement of your argument. Or, as the last example shows, you can move from specific examples to a more general (but not too general) thesis that your paper will develop.

引入挑衅性的引言或特定的图像是为第一段注入活力的一种方法。无论你使用什么方法，你的目标都是立即让你的读者相信你有一些值得说的话，一个需要宣扬的论点，以及一些并不明显的观察结果。尽管论文的其余部分将在这些最初的命题上进行发展和扩展，但您应该在这里非常清楚地说明您的论文的内容以及您将使用什么方法来研究您的主题。如果你根据论文的长度和限制来撰写和集中这一段，那么这篇论文会更容易写：没有什么比大规模的论文陈述更常见和更具灾难性了（“这是一项对黑天鹅的研究[2010] ”）当作者怀疑他或她能否找到足够的内容来表达一个更狭隘的主题时，就会提出这个问题。

Introducing a provocative quotation or a specific image is one way to energize a first paragraph. Whatever method you use, your aim is to convince your reader immediately that you have something worthwhile to say, an argument that needs airing, observations that are not readily apparent. Although the rest of your paper will develop and expand on these first propositions, you should make very clear here what your essay is about and what method you will use to investigate your topic. If you compose and focus this paragraph to fit the length and limits of your paper, that paper will be much easier to write: Nothing is more common and more disastrous than the massive thesis statement (“This is a study of Black Swan [2010]”) formulated when a writer doubts he or she can find enough to say about a more narrowly focused topic.

从很多方面来说，第一段是整篇文章中最难的；它假定你非常了解论证的走向，尽管一些结论通常是在写作本身中得出的。尽管在初稿中制定介绍性段落很重要，但您应该计划在稍后的草稿中重新检查和重写该段落。到那时，有效的第一段将变得更容易写。

In many ways, the first paragraph is the most difficult of the essay; it presumes you know pretty much where the argument is going, although some conclusions are often arrived at in the writing itself. Although it is important to formulate an introductory paragraph in the first draft, you should plan to reexamine and rewrite that paragraph in a later draft. At that point, an effective first paragraph will become much easier to write.

结论段落

CONCLUDING PARAGRAPHS

 

对于一些学生来说，得出结论的一个流行策略是用稍微不同的词语重新表述开篇论文（“因此，我已经证明了……”）。然而，这种方法常常显得机械而乏味。结论段落，就像开头段落一样，最好能让读者注意到它，并意识到其中提到的一些有趣的事情可能超出了文章的范围。一些总结并不一定是一个坏主意，特别是当一个论点有点复杂或涉及时；即便如此，应该检索早期的想法，不仅是为了提醒读者已经说过的话，而且是为了强调最后的、通常更广泛的观点，正如汤姆冈宁在他对 1902 年月球之旅的讨论的结论中所做的那样：

For some students, a popular strategy for reaching a conclusion is to rephrase the opening thesis in slightly different words (“Thus, I have shown...”). This approach, however, frequently seems mechanical and dull. A concluding paragraph, like an opening paragraph, is best when it makes your reader attend to it and to sit up and realize that something interesting has been said that may have implications beyond the bounds of the essay. Some summary is not necessarily a bad idea, especially when an argument has been a bit complicated or involved; even so, earlier ideas should be retrieved not merely to remind the reader of what has been said, but to emphasize a final, often more expansive, point, as Tom Gunning does in this conclusion to his discussion of the 1902 Trip to the Moon:

也许最重要的是，正如我在本文开头所说，《月球旅行记》并不是作为被遗忘的早期电影历史的化石而存在，而是作为一部充满活力和想象力、视觉设计和幽默感、技术的电影。创新和惊奇感至今仍然让观众感到高兴。也许比任何其他早期电影更能体现早期电影的高昂精神，以及新媒体标志的发现和创新的兴奋。当梅里爱讲述他对未来的童话般的愿景时，他的舌头紧紧地贴在脸颊上，其中科学家仍然装扮成巫师，而月球上的居民则表演杂技特技。但他也表达了人性渴望到达月球，漫步地球卫星表面，寻找前人未曾去过的奇迹。(78-79)

Perhaps most important, as I stated at the opening of this essay, A Trip to the Moon endures not as a fossil of a forgotten early history of the cinema, but as a film whose energy and imagination, visual design and sense of humor, technological innovation and sense of wonder still delight audiences today. Perhaps more than any other early film, it embodies the high spirits that marked early cinema, the excitement of discovery and innovation that marked the new medium. Méliès’s tongue was lodged firmly in his cheek as he presented his fairy-tale vision of the future, in which scientists still dress as wizards and the inhabitants of the moon perform acrobatic stunts. But he also expressed the human desire to reach the moon, to walk the surface of the earth’s satellite, to find wonders where no one had gone before. (78-79)

 

正如冈宁的结论所表明的那样，结论不应试图过于简洁地总结复杂的论点，全面的概括是有风险的。一些最有效的结论在该特定文章的范围内结束了一个论点，同时也向其他问题开放了它。

As Gunning’s conclusion demonstrates, conclusions should not attempt to wrap up a complex argument too neatly and sweeping generalizations are risky. Some of the most effective conclusions close an argument within the range of that particular essay, at the same time opening it to other questions.

在结束对莱妮·里芬斯塔尔的电影和摄影作品的讨论时，理查德·梅兰·巴萨姆小心翼翼地从具体到一般，参考了历史人物和标题，得出了一些关于这位女性和她的作品的明确结论，同时又保持了相对平衡和开放的态度。引导读者思考其他问题的有意识的语气：

In concluding a discussion of Leni Riefenstahl’s films and photographic work, Richard Meran Barsam moves carefully from the specific to the general, referring to historical figures and titles, arriving at some definite conclusions about the woman and her work yet maintaining a relatively balanced and open-minded tone that points the reader toward other questions:

努巴的电影将与她的其他作品相似，因为它将再次表达她从小就充满想象力的特殊世界。莱妮·里芬斯塔尔的世界是一个截然不同的世界，一个充满水晶洞穴的世界，一个自认为是超人的人的世界，一个通过电影变得神圣的人体的世界，一个黑暗而陌生的平原上的精锐战士的世界。这个世界确实存在，但在她的想象中却变成了一个截然不同的实体。莱妮·里芬斯塔尔（Leni Riefenstahl）受到她对这个实体（当然，这就是她的艺术）的信仰的保护，与日常生活的大部分地区保持着距离。她不明白为什么那个世界的很多人不接受她或她的传说；当她出版她的努巴照片时（对某些人来说，这是一种大胆而引人注目的忏悔行为），她认为这些文件将表明她对人类诚实、善良和与自然一体的信念。当然，努巴的照片确实展示了这些方面，但它们是一个正在消失的世界的照片。对全人类来说幸运的是，她拍摄的希特勒照片代表了另一个已经消失的世界，但世界不会忘记，她发现拍摄这些照片并创造神话，将其注入到意志的胜利中是必要的，甚至可能是有利的。恐怖的力量。莱妮·里芬斯塔尔是一位真正神秘的女性，她与她为自己创造的传奇作斗争，即使它包围了她生命的最后几年。莱妮·里芬斯塔尔 (Leni Riefenstahl) 是一位传奇人物，与她创造的世界密不可分。她拥有自代达罗斯以来每一位艺术家所梦想的东西，除了堕落的力量、承认错误的力量以及超越艺术与生活之间脆弱障碍的力量。(37)

The Nuba film will be similar to her other work because it will express again the special world that has engaged her imagination since she was a child. Leni Riefenstahl’s world is a world apart, a world of crystal grottoes, of men who think they are supermen, of the human body made godlike through film, of elite warriors on a dark and foreign plain. This world exists in fact, but it becomes in her imagination a very different entity. Protected by her belief in that entity, which is, of course, her art, Leni Riefenstahl remains apart from much of the everyday world. She cannot understand why many people in that world will not accept her or her legends; as she publishes her Nuba photographs (to some, a bold and striking act of penance), she thinks that these documents will show her belief in man’s honesty, goodness, and oneness with nature. The Nuba photographs do show those aspects, of course, but they are photographs of a disappearing world. Fortunately for all mankind, her photographs of Hitler represent another world that has disappeared, but the world will not forget that she found it necessary, and perhaps even advantageous, to make those pictures and to create the myths that infuse Triumph of the Will with its terrifying power. A truly enigmatic woman, Leni Riefenstahl fights against the legend that she has created for herself, fights against it even as it encloses the final years of her life. Leni Riefenstahl is one with her legend, inseparable from the world that she has made. She has what every artist since Daedalus has dreamed of, except the power to fall, to admit error, and to transcend the fragile barrier that stands between art and life. (37)

 

对于某些人来说，这里最后的华丽辞藻可能看起来有点过分了。然而，结论和开头总是比其他段落更具修辞性，无论它们是否选择更实事求是的在语气上，作者应该努力从文字中表达尽可能多的内容——尤其是在文章的关键点上。

For some, the final rhetorical flourish here might seem a bit much. Conclusions and openings are always more rhetorical than other paragraphs, however, and whether or not they choose a more matter-of-fact tone, writers should strive to get as much out of their words as possible—especially at the crucial points in an essay.

修改和校对

REVISIONS AND PROOFREADING

 

一个常见且危险的写作错误是认为一旦完成了一份好的论文草稿，最重要的工作就已经完成了。尽管对某些人来说，对该论文的修改似乎很简单，就像润色完成的材料一样，但优秀的作家知道，写作中最重要的步骤之一是仔细进行一个或多个详细的修改，然后对每一行进行重点校对。没有人第一次就能写出完美的草稿，大多数优秀的作家都会经过几遍草稿，然后才能对一篇文章感到满意和安全。如果你感到疲倦，请提醒自己：电影剧本在导演开始拍摄之前可能要经过十几次重写，而一旦电影拍摄完毕，剪辑可能会成为又一系列的修改。在初稿和修改之间留出的时间应该让你能够以新的眼光来看待这篇文章。检查你的逻辑、主题句和论文陈述（它仍然符合你写的论文吗？）。检查一下你是否在论证和发展你的论文，而不是仅仅断言它。准备好更改、删除和添加文章的大小部分，以改进其论点和风格。通读文章，注意是否有尴尬的表达、句子和段落之间的过渡不良以及不精确的用词。你的例子仍然有意义吗？你们的报价准确吗？如果有时间，请将论文再次放在一边，然后进行最后一次修改。最后，校对意味着以新的眼光重新阅读文章，注意拼写、标点符号或语法方面被忽视的错误。如果这些看起来只是次要细节，请记住，与许多电影一样，在写作中，外表的重要性永远不应该被低估。

One common and dangerous writing error is to presume that once a good draft of the paper has been finished, the most important work has been done. Although revisions of that essay may seem simply, for some, like polishing the finished material, good writers know that one of the most important steps in writing is to move carefully through one or more detailed revisions, followed by a focused proofreading of each line. No one writes a perfect draft the first time, and most good writers go through several drafts before they feel comfortable and secure with an essay. If you grow weary, remind yourself: Film scripts may be subjected to a dozen rewrites before a director starts to film, and once the film is made, its editing may become another series of revisions. The time you allow between your first draft and your revision should permit you to look at the essay with fresh eyes. Check your logic, topic sentences, and thesis statement (does it still fit the paper you wrote?). Check to see that you argue and develop your thesis rather than merely assert it. Be prepared to change, delete, and add both small and large parts of the essay in order to improve its argument and style. Reading through the essay, watch for awkward expressions, poor transitions between sentences and paragraphs, and imprecise words. Are your examples still relevant? Are your quotations accurate? If you have time, put the paper aside again and then do one last revision. Finally, proofreading means rereading the essay with fresh eyes, watching for overlooked mistakes in spelling, punctuation, or grammar. If these seem like minor details, remember that, with writing as with many films, the importance of appearance should never be underestimated.

撰写有效论文的清单

CHECKLIST FOR WRITING AN EFFECTIVE ESSAY

 

每个作家都有个人的方法和策略。以下是一些摘要指南、建议和提醒：

Each writer has personal methods and strategies. The following are some summary guidelines, suggestions, and reminders:

  1. 为看电影做好准备。在你看一部电影之前，先问一些关于电影拍摄时间和地点的初步问题，以及你自己对这部电影的期望。询问您的哪些其他兴趣（技术、艺术、商业）可能会在撰写电影时为您指明一个好的方向。
  2. Be prepared for a movie. Before you see a film, ask preliminary questions about when and where it was made and about your own expectations concerning it. Ask which of your other interests—technology, art, business—might point you in a good direction when writing about film.
  3. 学会仔细看电影并做笔记。当您对电影做出回应时，让您的一般性初步问题变得更加具体和具体。其中最重要的是什么？其中最不寻常的是什么？
  4. Learn to look carefully at the movie and to take notes. Let your general, preliminary questions become more specific and concrete as you respond to the movie. What seems most important in it? What seems most unusual about it?
  5. 让你的问题引导你进入一个易于管理的主题，其中涉及电影的主题及其技术和形式特征。像《公民凯恩》中的身份追寻这样的主题对于一篇短文来说可能太大了；一个更引人注目的话题是“凯恩的童年：身份危机的开始”。第二个主题更加集中的焦点将使您能够详细检查场景和序列。
  6. Let your questions lead you to a manageable topic that involves both the themes of the film and its technical and formal features. A topic like “The Search for Identity in Citizen Kane” is probably too large for a short essay; a much more compelling topic would be “Kane’s Childhood: The Beginning of an Identity Crisis.” The more concentrated focus of the second topic will allow you to examine scenes and sequences in detail.
  7. 决定主题后，尝试至少再观看一次电影。此时展开您的笔记，填写您在第一次筛选时可能错过的详细信息。
  8. Try to view the movie at least one more time after you have decided on a topic. Expand your notes at this point, filling in details you may have missed during your first screening.
  9. 不断澄清你的论点；将您的笔记传输到计算机文件（如果您愿意，也可以将笔记卡或笔记本传输到计算机文件中）。首先陈述你想要解决的问题或疑问，开始你的论证。然后利用电影中的具体证据和你对它的解释来收集并列出你讨论的具体要点。好的论文通常从争议较少的主题点开始，转向有关风格和技巧的更复杂的点。请记住，您假设读者已经看过这部电影，但需要确信您想要表达的观点。
  10. Keep clarifying your argument; transfer your notes to a computer file (or note cards or a notebook if you prefer). Begin your argument with a statement of the problem or question you intend to address. Then assemble and lay out the specific points of your discussion, using concrete evidence from the movie and your interpretation of it. Good essays usually proceed from less debatable thematic points to more complex points about style and technique. Remember, you are presuming that the reader has seen the movie but will need to be convinced of the point you wish to make.
  11. 许多作家发现以大纲形式勾画出一篇文章的组织很有用。根据您的习惯和偏好，您的大纲可能非常完整和详细，也可能非常笼统和粗略。如果您在组织和段落方面遇到困难，您将希望使其尽可能完整。对于大纲的每个部分，您甚至可能希望编写完整的句子作为标题；这些稍后可能会成为你的主题句。
  12. Many writers find it useful to sketch out the organization of an essay in outline form. Depending on your habits and preferences, your outline may be very complete and detailed or rather general and sketchy. If you tend to have trouble with organization and paragraphing, you will want to make it as complete as possible. For each section of the outline, you may even wish to write full sentences as headings; these may later become your topic sentences.
  13. 开始写。对于许多专业人士和学生来说，这是最困难的部分，我们都有太多的方法来推迟它（做更多笔记、再​​次观看电影、检查电子邮件等等）。延误并不会让任务变得更容易。创建大纲会有所帮助，因为它由实际写作组成，但当它没有足够帮助时，您应该自由或随机写下您的想法。退后一步，想象向朋友解释您的主题。目的只是为了写出一些句子；您可以稍后重新整理和完善您的想法。
  14. Begin to write. For many professionals as well as students, this is the most difficult part, and we all have too many ways to put it off (taking more notes, watching the movie again, checking your email, and so on). Delays do not make the task any easier. Creating an outline can help because it consists of actual writing, but when it does not help enough, you should write down your ideas freely or randomly. Step back and imagine explaining your topic to a friend. Aim merely to get some sentences written; you can re-sort and refine your ideas later.
  15. 当你写作时，不断思考你的主题，进一步推动你的想法。在我们开始表达我们的想法之前，我们大多数人都不知道我们对一个复杂主题的确切想法。写作本身成为一个我们应该充分利用的发现过程。通过勾勒出你所写内容的轮廓来检查你的逻辑。完善你的第一段和结论。考虑一些关于你的方法的更大问题。主要是历史的还是形式主义的？您对电影的文化认同感兴趣吗？如果您强调某种特定方法，请决定在论文早期应在多大程度上承认您的方法。
  16. As you write, keep thinking about your subject, pushing your ideas further. Most of us don’t know exactly what we think about a complex subject until we start to articulate our thoughts. Writing itself becomes a discovery process of which we should take full advantage. Check your logic by sketching an outline of what you have written. Polish your first paragraph and conclusion. Consider some larger questions about your approach. Is it mainly historical or formalistic? Are you interested in the cultural identity of the film? If you are emphasizing a particular method, decide to what extent your approach should be acknowledged early in your paper.
  17. 定期保存并备份计算机上的所有写作内容。
  18. Regularly save and back up all your writing on your computer.
  19. 修订; 总是修改。在初稿和修改之间留出尽可能多的时间，最好是几天。仔细校对您的最终修订，以发现任何小错误或印刷错误。注意：修改至少一份纸质草稿可能非常有用 - 即使您打算提交论文的电子副本 - 而不是直接在计算机上修改，因为当写作时更容易发现错误硬拷贝。
  20. Revise; always revise. Allow as much time as possible between your first draft and your revision of it, preferably a few days. Follow your final revisions with a careful proofreading to catch any minor mistakes or typographical errors. NOTE: It can be very useful to revise at least one draft on a hard copy—even if you intend to submit an electronic copy of the essay—rather than revising directly on the computer, since errors are easier to spot when the writing is in hard copy.
  21. 按照有关页边距、脚注等的准则打印出一份干净的副本（参见第 155-162 页）。确保您没有违反或违背任何有关剽窃的规则（参见第 160-163 页）。
  22. Print out a clean copy, following the guidelines about margins, footnotes, and so on (see pp. 155–162). Be certain you are not breaking or bending any rules about plagiarism (see pp. 160–163).

练习

Exercises

  1. 使用每个部分的标题和副标题概述文章的论点。使用完整的主题句作为标题。
  2. Outline an argument for an essay using headings and subheadings for each section. Use full topic sentences for the headings.
  3. 写一个介绍性段落的三个不同版本，以便每个版本的论文变得越来越具体。
  4. Write three different versions of an introductory paragraph so that the thesis becomes more and more specific with each version.

6

研究电影

6

RESEARCHING THE MOVIES

 

研究可以改善任何写作。通常，很少有人在观看一部电影或开始写一篇关于它的文章时，会看到所有的事实或其他观点的记录。当您与朋友交换意见时，详尽的背景信息可能没有必要，甚至没有相关性。然而，一旦你有一个观点要表达或有一个论点要提出，一旦你与你所说的内容有利害关系，那么你对这个主题和与之相关的问题了解得越多，它就会越令人满意写一下它。

Research improves any piece of writing. Normally, few people see a film or begin to write an essay about it with all the facts or a record of other opinions before them. When you exchange opinions with a friend, exhaustive background information may not be necessary or even relevant. Yet as soon as you have a point to make or an argument to present, as soon as you have a stake in what you are saying, then the more you know about the subject and the issues related to it, the more satisfying it will be to write about it.

两个同样聪明的朋友可能会观看保罗·施拉德（Paul Schrader）的《三岛：四章人生》（1985），尽管每个人可能对此都有非常敏感和明智的反应，但了解日本文化或作家兼电影制片人三岛由纪夫生平事实的人对电影会有更丰富、更详细的解读，能够更好地支持她或他的评价（图6.01）。尽管两人都可能理解这些主题，并认识到复杂的结构和风格是他们对这些主题做出反应的核心因素，但观众仍能将它们与施拉德的其他电影联系起来，例如《美国舞男》 (1980)、 《痛苦》 (1997) 或《痛苦》 。 Walker (2007) 将能够发现那些知识较少的观众无法察觉的有关痴迷和疏离的主题的变化和复杂性。如果这个人也花时间阅读施拉德的书《电影的先验风格》、三岛的一些文学作品，以及有关施拉德与日本著名作家遗孀之间的问题的一些内容，那么这个人就可以提供有关这部电影的信息和见解，从而使他的电影与众不同。或者她的文章“只是另一种观点”。一个经过充分研究的论点，一个能够提供普通观众知识范围之外的事实和观察结果的论点，往往能够区分一种观点的权威性和复杂性与另一种观点的印象。

Two equally intelligent friends may watch Paul Schrader’s Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985), and although each may have perfectly sensitive and sensible responses to it, the one who has knowledge of Japanese culture or the facts of writer and filmmaker Yukio Mishima’s life will have a richer and more detailed reading of the movie and be able to support her or his evaluation better (Figure 6.01). Although both may understand the themes and recognize that the elaborate structure and style are central ingredients in their reaction to these themes, the viewer who can connect them to other Schrader films, such as American Gigolo (1980), Affliction (1997), or The Walker (2007), will be able to detect variations and complexities in motifs concerning obsessiveness and alienation that escape the less knowledgeable viewer. If that person also takes the time to read Schrader’s book Transcendental Style in Film, some of Mishima’s literary work, and something about Schrader’s problems with the widow of the celebrated Japanese writer, that person could offer information and insights about the movie that would distinguish his or her essay from “just another opinion.” A well-researched argument, one that brings to bear facts and observations outside the ken of the average viewer, is often all that distinguishes the authority and sophistication of one perspective from the impressions of another.

您可以通过多种不同的方式使用研究。它可以融入到你的文章中，以其他作者的权威来支持你自己的观点，或者它可以用来引入你希望反对的共同看法。请注意作者保罗·朱利安·史密斯 (Paul Julian Smith) 如何巧妙地组织和简化大量的背景研究西班牙电影制片人胡里奥·梅德姆 (Julio Medem) 以此作为他对电影《混沌安娜》 (Chaotic Ana ) (2007) 的讨论的开始：

You can use research in a number of different ways. It can be integrated into your essay to support your own points with the authority of other writers, or it can be used to introduce a common perception against which you wish to argue. Notice how this writer, Paul Julian Smith, skillfully orchestrates and streamlines considerable background research on Spanish filmmaker Julio Medem as a way of beginning his discussion of the film Chaotic Ana (2007):

图 6.01三岛和保罗·施拉德：研究人和电影制片人。

Figure 6.01 Mishima and Paul Schrader: researching the man and the filmmaker.

 

因此，电影学者被这一罕见的作者电影例子所吸引也就不足为奇了。罗布·斯通 (Rob Stone) 在其 2007 年关于导演的书中称赞梅德姆的作品是一种持续的亲密叙事，他声称这种作品是基于独特的个人参考和美学。努里亚·特里亚纳-托里比奥（Nuria Triana-Toribio）在《西班牙国家电影》中提出了更具批判性的说法……表明学者们抓住了梅德姆作为一位艺术家，他所谓的视觉纯洁性“赎回了西班牙电影的商业罪过”，捍卫了其在国内外的荣誉。最近出版的一本关于 Medem 的西班牙文书籍《Contra le certeza》（反对确定性……）结合了批判性文章和对导演的广泛采访。也许自相矛盾的是，这个标题表明，正是梅德姆的不确定性——他的意识形态怀疑论和他拒绝明确引导观众——提供了任何导演的作品都必须展示的持续指导线索。(30)

It is no surprise, then, that film scholars have been drawn to this rare example of auteur cinema. In his 2007 book on the director..., Rob Stone has celebrated Medem’s work as a continuing intimate narrative which he claims is based on uniquely personal references and aesthetics. Nuria Triana-Toribio has offered a more critical account in Spanish National Cinema..., suggesting that scholars have seized on Medem as an artist whose supposed purity of vision “redeems the commercial sins” of Spanish cinema, defending its honor at home and abroad. One recent Spanish volume on Medem, which combines critical essays and extensive interviews with the director, is called Contra le certeza (Against Certainty...). The title suggests, paradoxically perhaps, that it is Medem’s uncertainty—his ideological skepticism and his refusal clearly to direct his audience—that provides the constant guiding thread that any auteur’s oeuvre must exhibit. (30)

 

我们中的许多人可能很难在简短的介绍中总结如此多的学术资料，有时，一个单一的挑衅性引文就足以找到你自己的观点。然而，无论您在何处使用研究，如果您明智地使用它，它都可以快速证实和指导您的写作。

Many of us might have trouble summarizing so many scholarly sources in a short introduction, and sometimes a single provocative quotation is enough to locate your own point of view. Yet, however and wherever you use research, it can quickly substantiate and direct your writing if you use it wisely.

电影论文作者传统上分为两个阵营，这两个阵营因其不同的研究方法而不同。一组由批评家和评论家组成，另一组由学者和历史学家组成。第一阵营的人通过自己对电影价值的分析和感受来解读电影，通常认为没有必要研究银幕以外的材料。然而，学者型历史学家主要关心的是其他材料：电影制作的历史、对电影的批评反应、理论假设以及他们看电影时手头没有的事实或信息。对于学者历史学家来说，理解一部电影需要对决定银幕上出现的内容的思想和历史背景进行大量研究。对于评论家或评论家来说，奥森·威尔斯的《伟大的安伯森一家》（1942）不言而喻。故事的力量和电影的风格将成为讨论的焦点。然而，对于历史学家来说，威尔斯与工作室的斗争以及他无法按照自己的方式完成剪辑成为分析中最重要的部分。

Writers of film essays are traditionally divided into two camps that are distinguished by their different approaches to research; one group is made up of critics and reviewers, the other of scholars and historians. Those in the first camp interpret a film through their own analysis and feelings about the value of the movie, and researching material other than what is on the screen is usually considered unnecessary. The scholar-historians, however, are concerned mostly with that other material: the history of the movie’s production, critical responses to it, theoretical suppositions, and facts or information that are not at hand when they go to the movies. For the scholar-historians, understanding a movie involves a significant amount of research into the ideas and historical background that have determined what appears on the screen. For the critic or reviewer, Orson Welles’s The Magnificent Ambersons (1942) speaks for itself; the power of the story and the style of the movie would be the focus of the discussion. For the historian, however, Welles’s battles with the studio and his inability to complete the editing on his own terms become the most important part of the analysis.

有些作家强调学术或个人的批判性反应，但大多数作家介于两者之间。报纸或杂志的合格审稿人通常会带来相当多的先验知识（关于电影史、导演或电影背景）特定的电影）来影响他们对电影的讨论。同样，优秀的历史学家不会只是积累“枯燥的事实”或涵盖与我们喜欢或不喜欢一部电影无关的理论问题。他们的调查基于希望更多地了解某些电影的含义或我们重视它们的原因。

Some writers emphasize either scholarship or a personal critical response, but most writers operate somewhere in between. Competent reviewers for a newspaper or a magazine usually bring a fair amount of prior knowledge (about film history, the director, or the background of a particular film) to bear on their discussion of a movie. Likewise, good scholar-historians do not just accumulate “dry facts” or cover theoretical issues that have little to do with why we like or dislike a film. Their investigations are based on a desire to throw more light on what certain movies mean or why we value them.

研究涉及从检查日期到检查电影的整个经济历史等各种内容。无论您的主题是对单部电影的解读还是对其背后技术的描述，良好的研究都应该塑造您对如何理解和欣赏这部电影的感受。研究并不是简单地积累事实或装饰；而是。一个好的作家总是会进行研究，例如明确为什么它对她的论点很重要，她同意或不同意其他立场，以及她打算如何使用它。作为讨论贝蒂·戴维斯四部电影中“消失的女人”的前奏，下一段的作者使用了对戴维斯其他电影的历史研究，以及对与戴维斯直言不讳的职业生涯相关的印刷材料的研究，作为明确的一部分陈述了对该材料的参与以及她的论点的理由：

Research involves anything from checking a date to examining the entire economic history of a film. Whether your topic is an interpretation of an individual movie or a description of the technology behind it, good research should shape your feelings about how the film can be understood and enjoyed. Research is not simply accumulated facts or ornamentation; a good writer always engages research, making clear, for instance, why it is important to her argument, where she agrees or disagrees with other positions, and how she intends to use it. As a prelude to a discussion of the “vanishing woman” in four Bette Davis films, the writer of the following paragraph uses historical research on Davis’s other films, as well as research on print material related to Davis’s outspoken career, as part of a clearly stated engagement with that material and rationale for her argument:

出于多种原因，我没有研究格洛丽亚·斯旺森（Gloria Swanson）在《日落大道》 （1950）中饰演消失的女人的常见例子，而是将贝蒂·戴维斯（Bette Davis）作为本次调查的替代人物。首先，或许也是最重要的一点是，戴维斯在她的职业生涯中至少四次扮演一位正在消逝的明星，真实地体现了这位明星不断消失和重新出现的循环：在《危险》（阿尔弗雷德·E·格林，1935年）中，她因此获得了奥斯卡奖; 关于夏娃的一切（约瑟夫·曼凯维奇，1950）；《星星》（斯图尔特·海斯勒，1952）；宝贝简发生了什么？（罗伯特·奥尔德里奇，1962）……戴维斯对职业消失的真正可能性并不陌生。1962 年 9 月， 《简宝贝》完成后不久，她在好莱坞商业报纸上刊登了一则广告，内容是：“三个孩子（10、11 和 15）的母亲，离婚者，美国人。三十年的电影演员经验。手机仍然比传闻中的更友善。想要在好莱坞找到稳定的工作。”……贝蒂·戴维斯的星光不断照亮消失与回归的矛盾空间，在这个空间中，视觉和能见度都紧张而不稳定。（贝克曼 161–62）

Rather than examine a common example of Gloria Swanson as the vanishing woman of Sunset Boulevard (1950), I have taken Bette Davis as an alternative figure for this inquiry for a number of reasons. First and perhaps most importantly, Davis literalizes the star’s endless cycle of vanishing and reappearing by playing a fading star no less than four times within the course of her career: in Dangerous (Alfred E. Green, 1935) for which she won an academy award; All about Eve (Joseph Mankiewicz, 1950); The Star (Stuart Heisler, 1952); and Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? (Robert Aldrich, 1962).... Davis was no stranger to the real possibility of professional disappearance. In September 1962, soon after the completion of Baby Jane, she placed an ad in the Hollywood trade papers, stating: “Mother of three—10, 11, and 15—divorcee, American. Thirty years’ experience as an actress in motion pictures. Mobile still and more affable than rumor would have it. Wants steady employment in Hollywood.”... The starlight of Bette Davis repeatedly illuminates the ambivalent space of vanishing and return, a space in which both vision and visibility and are strained and unstable. (Beckman 161–62)

 

如何开始研究

HOW TO BEGIN RESEARCH

 

作者进行多少研究以及进行何种类型的研究取决于可用时间和项目长度等变量。用三个月的时间写一篇二十页的论文将意味着并需要更多研究比两周内到期的五页论文更重要。两天内写成的评论通常只包含作者立即可用的研究或在新闻稿中找到的研究；一篇学术论文将涉及数月的研究。

How much and what kind of research a writer does depends on variables such as the time available and the length of the project. Having three months to write a twenty-page paper will presume and require more research than a five-page essay due in two weeks. A review written in two days normally contains only the research that the writer has immediately available or that is found in press notes; a scholarly essay will involve research done over many months.

可用研究材料的质量和数量取决于电影及其发行时间。一位作家开始创作一部经典电影，例如维克多·弗莱明的《乱世佳人》（1939 年）或马塞尔·卡尔内的《天堂之子》（1945 年），他会发现大量的论文和书籍，无法在合理的时间内令人满意地审查。相反，在上映后的几个月里，即使是一部广为人知的好莱坞电影，例如《达芬奇密码》（2006）或《滑稽戏》（2010），通常也只产生报纸和杂志的评论和采访，而作家选择写最近的一部外国电影或一部不知名的第三世界电影可能很难找到哪怕是一两个简短的评论。这些材料的用处截然不同：对一部电影的十几篇肤浅评论或一本关于导演的咖啡桌书可能只提供情节摘要或八卦的变化，而一篇简短的、明智的评论或一本出色的书可以为您提供帮助您自己的想法的完整基础或背景。研究是一项习得的技能，优秀的作家会开发出快速找到可用内容并有效地整理出与他或她的论文最相关的内容的方法。

The quality and amount of research material available depend on the film and when it was released. A writer who begins work on a classic film, such as Victor Fleming’s Gone with the Wind (1939) or Marcel Carné’s Children of Paradise (1945), finds more essays and books than can be satisfactorily examined in a reasonable time. Conversely, in the months immediately after its release, even a highly publicized Hollywood film, such as The Da Vinci Code (2006) or Burlesque (2010), usually has generated only newspaper and magazine reviews and interviews, and a writer choosing to write on a recent foreign movie or an unheralded Third World film might have trouble locating even one or two short reviews. The usefulness of these materials is extremely different: A dozen superficial reviews of a film or a coffee-table book on a director may offer little more than variations on plot summaries or gossip, while a small, intelligent review or one exceptional book could provide you an entire foundation or backdrop for your own ideas. Research is a learned skill, and the good writer develops methods of quickly finding what is available and efficiently sorting out what is most pertinent to his or her essay.

每个人都会发展自己的研究技术。有些人喜欢在看电影之前阅读背景材料。有些人在思考自己对电影的立场，然后调查该立场如何与现有观点形成对比或补充时，效果会更好。许多作家的习惯介于这两个极端之间。

Each person develops an individual research technique. Some people prefer to read background material before seeing a movie. Some work better when they think through their position on a film and then investigate how that position contrasts with or complements the existing body of opinion. Many writers’ habits fall somewhere between these extremes.

即使在看电影之前，也可以尝试通过考虑一些初步问题来了解它（例如，它的制作时间和目标观众；请参阅第 2 章）。看完电影后，明确你对这部电影的看法以及你最感兴趣的是什么。（写一些你觉得无趣的东西可能是最困难的写作类型。）一旦你勾勒出对一部电影的想法，然后将这些想法集中在一两个主题上，你就拥有了指导你的研究的参数。当你的主题多年来产生了大量批评文献时，这种初步的关注尤为重要，因为它可以让你区分哪些研究与你的论点相关，哪些不相关。例如，打算为希区柯克电影撰写文章的学生很容易被大量有关该导演的书籍和评论文章吓倒。当学生将研究重点放在“希区柯克的《惊魂记》中声音的使用”时，任务立即变得更容易管理。请记住，尽管某些科目可能证明对于一篇论文来说太大了，如果你仔细考虑的话，很少有人会太小。最重要的指导是你自己的兴趣。

Even before seeing the movie, try to get a sense of it by considering preliminary questions (for example, when it was made and its intended audience; see Chapter 2). After seeing the movie, clarify what you think about it and what interests you most. (Writing about something you find uninteresting can be the most difficult kind of writing.) Once you have sketched your ideas about a movie and then focused those ideas on one or two topics, you have the parameters within which to direct your research. This kind of preliminary focus is particularly important when your topic has generated a great deal of critical literature through the years, because it allows you to distinguish what research is relevant to your argument and what is not. The student who intends to write on a Hitchcock film, for instance, can easily be intimidated by the large number of books and critical essays about that director. When the student focuses the research on “the use of sound in Hitchcock’s Psycho,” the task immediately becomes more manageable. Keep in mind that although some subjects may prove too large for a paper, very few are too small if you think carefully about them. The most important guide is your own interest.

研究应该以开放和辨别的心态进行。一个好的作家愿意被重新引导到新的道路上，并在必要时改变立场。研究希区柯克和声音的学生在阅读其他作家的作品后，可能会决定单独研究音乐，或者对希区柯克与伯纳德·赫尔曼的合作进行更多研究，以发现他们如何影响他后期电影中的声音。作者对电影史某个时期（例如纳粹德国或非西方文化时期）的严肃著作相对较少感到失望，必须准备好通过阅读一些更一般的文化或政治史来探索电影史本身之外的主题。研究既发展又检验作家的想法。调整或改变想法是研究的乐趣之一。

Research should be done with an open and discriminating mind. A good writer is willing to be redirected down new paths and, if necessary, to change a position. The student researching Hitchcock and sound may, on reading other writers, decide instead to work on the music alone or to do more research into Hitchcock’s’s collaborations with Bernard Herrmann to discover how they affected the sound in his later films. The writer disappointed with the comparatively little serious work on a period in film history, such as that of Nazi Germany or in non-Western cultures, must be ready to explore topics outside film history itself by reading some more general cultural or political histories. Research both develops and tests a writer’s ideas. Adjusting or changing ideas is part of the excitement of doing research.

诀窍是学会识别什么对你的论文重要，什么不重要，什么要保留，什么要丢弃。只有当您同时准备好想法并灵活地改变它们时，这个过程才会变得更容易。事实上，雷内·克莱尔在《电影是如何制作的》中对电影制作的描述暗示了研究和撰写电影的类似过程：“电影的想法有时诞生于作者的脑海中，但更多时候电影公司的意图是制作电影一部电影，因此在现有的想法中寻找最适合它的想法”（226）。

The trick is to learn to recognize what is important to your essay and what is not, what to keep and what to discard. The process is made easier only when you are, at the same time, prepared with ideas and flexible about changing them. Indeed, René Clair’s description of filmmaking in “How Films Are Made” suggests a similar process for researching and writing about film: “The idea for a film is sometimes born in an author’s mind, but more often a film company has the intention of making a film and is thus moved to search among existing ideas for the one that suits it best” (226).

当您研究了一个主题并修改了最初的想法时，建议再次观看这部电影。随着对自己想说的内容的敏锐感知，您总是会发现新的信息并找到以前错过的支持您想法的图像。正如你的研究会受到你看完电影后的第一个想法的影响一样，你对自己想说的话的感觉也会通过再次观看这部电影而变得更加敏锐。因此，第二章开头引用的戈达尔声明的反面是：“说得更好，看得更好。”

When you have researched a subject and reworked your original idea, it is advisable to see the movie again. With a sharpened sense of what you want to say, you will invariably discover new information and find previously missed images that support your ideas. Just as your research is influenced by your first ideas after seeing the movie, your sense of what you wish to say is sharpened by seeing the film again. The inverse of Godard’s pronouncement quoted at the beginning of Chapter 2 is thus, “Said better, seen better.”

研究材料

THE MATERIALS OF RESEARCH

 

研究材料通常分为第一手来源和第二手来源。主要来源是电影本身以及电影中直接涉及的材料。次要来源是您读到的有关电影的书籍、文章和评论。因此，想要为乔治·罗伊·希尔的电影撰写文章的人首先会寻找主要来源：电影本身、音轨录音，甚至剧本（如果有的话）。在查阅第一手资料后，作者可能会调查第二手资料，例如评论、电影史或有关希尔的书。

Research materials have conventionally been divided into primary sources and secondary sources. Primary sources are the films themselves and the material directly involved in the films. Secondary sources are the books, essays, and reviews you read about the movie. Thus, a person wishing to write on the movies of George Roy Hill would go first to the primary sources: the movies themselves, a recording of the sound track, and even the script, if available. After consulting the primary sources, the writer may investigate secondary sources, such as a review, a film history, or a book about Hill.

主要资源

Primary Sources

在电影研究中，即使获得主要来源也可能会带来一些困难。传统上，对电影的研究一直受到真正的障碍的阻碍，即无法准确地按您想要的时间和频率观看电影。如果你的主题是一部恰好在当地剧院上映的主流电影，那么这个困难就会有所缓解，因为你可以多次观看这部电影——至少在你的经济能力允许的情况下。不过，通常情况下，您感兴趣的电影不会定期发行，因此需要采取特殊策略来补充首映。

In film research, even gaining access to a primary source may pose some difficulties. Traditionally, researching a movie has been inhibited by the real obstacle of not being able to see the movie exactly when and as often as you would like. If your subject is a mainstream movie that happens to be playing at a local theater, this difficulty is relieved somewhat because you can see the movie several times—at least for as long as your financial resources hold out. Frequently, though, the films that interest you are not in regular distribution, and special strategies are required to supplement a first screening.

DVD 和数字下载
